description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history

photos.photodesc: A Midsummer Night's Dream, Ballet Philippines, CCP, Manila, 1989 (Edna Vida Collection)

text:
1951. Story, William Shakespeare. Choreography, TrudlDubsky-Zipper; music, Felix Mendelssohn; scenario and costume design, Trudl Dubsky-Zipper; set design, Ernest Korneld; slide paintings, Ralps Fabri of New York, Korneld and Dubsky-Zipper; slide color photos, E.Z. Izon. Dancers: Tony Carrion as Theseus, Pacita Madrigal-Warns as Hippolyta, Marcelino Garcia as Lysander, RemediosdeOteyza as Hermia, Roberta Cassell as Helene, LucioSandoval as Egeus, TonyLlacer as Oberon, Trudl Dubsky-Zipper as Titania, BenjaminVillanuevaReyes as Puck, and Albert Eisiendl as Bottom. Premiered on 1 Sep 1951 at the Rizal Memorial Coliseum. Restaged on 27 Aug 1953 at the Far Eastern University Auditorium under the auspices of the ManilaSymphony Orchestra.

When first done, it marked the return of the Zippers to Manila after an absence of three years since 1947, and was considered the most ambitious dance project at that time and an unprecedented development in dance scenario in the Philippines. The first production alsocommemorated the 32nd anniversary of the AsociacionMusicaldeFilipinas.

The choreography was conceived as an imaginative combination of classical ballet and modern dance. Hippolyta and the Fairies of Dawn danced on pointes, while the rest of the cast danced in character shoes or on bare feet. Philippinejusiwas used for the costumes of Titania and the fairies. Scenic projection was introduced. Tights—then hardly available locally, pointe shoes, makeup, backdrop paintings, orchestral scores, musical instruments, and other equipment were donated from New York.

The foremost ballet schools in Manila agreed to dance together in one production. These were RemediosdeOteyza’s Classical Ballet Academy, AnitaKane’s School of the Classic Dance, Pacita Madrigal-Warns’ Manila Ballet Academy, Benjamin and Remedios Villanueva’s YWCA Ballet School, and the ballet dancers of the University of the Philippines. They were joined by noted professionals and students. The amateur dancers were transformed into expressive dancers in three months through the skill of the choreographer. The cast was an impressive total of 64 dancers, with a 23-member women’s choir.

In the 1953 restaging, the narrator was Gerard A. Burke, an Irish actor for stage, television, and radio. RicardoCassell’s StudioDanceGroup replaced the defunct Manila Ballet Academy. Jose Velez was Theseus, Ging Severino was Hippolyta, Jack Flores was Lysander, Alcuin Pastrano was Demetrius, Hetty McKay was Hermia, EddieElejar was Oberon, and Rally Calvo was Bottom.

AliceReyes used the same Shakespearean story in her own three-scene version also to Mendelssohn, premiered on 3 Sep 1976 by the CCP Dance Company (now BalletPhilippines) at the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP). Reyes starts with the quarrel of the Fairy King and Queen, Oberon and Titania, but over a Chinese (Joseph Nañas) rather than an Indian boy. The role of Puck was portrayed by TonyFabella, Oberon by NonoyFroilan, and Titania by EffieNañas.

EdnaVida premiered her own A MidsummerNight’s Dream on 16 Mar 1989 for Ballet Philippines at the CCP. It was a one-act ballet in 10 scenes. Instead of starting with Oberon and Titania, Vida opened the ballet with the case of the four lovers being reviewed by the Athenean king and queen Theseus and Hippolyta upon the request of Hermia’s father, Egeus. She restored the Indian boy in the rivalry between Oberon and Titania, and calls Bottom and his companions the laborers. At the end, when harmony is restored, Oberon and Titania enter the court of Theseus and Hippolyta in the celebration of a triple wedding, and Puck dances into the happy night. Froilan reprised his role of Oberon while Sofia Zobel danced the role of Titania and ConradDy-Liacco the role of Puck. Written by Corazon G. Iñigo and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

photos.photodesc: Adarna, Ballet Philippines, CCP, Manila, 1990 (Bayani ng Sayaw 1998 Dance Calendar, NCCA)

text:
1990. Modern ethnic ballet in two parts. Choreography, EdnaVida; music collage, Edna Vida in consultation with LucreciaR.Kasilag and Rudy Vidad; libretto, NicanorG.Tiongson; lighting design, Alex de Guzman; set and costume design, SalvadorBernal. Dancers: EnricoLabayen / Jinn Ibarrola / Stanley Cañete (Gat Mabait); Amuer Calderon (Gat Malakas); Jun Mabaquiao (Gat Makisig); Melissa Cuachon / Gina Katigbak / Nicole Gaston (Adarna); Leon Koning (Raha Magpantay / Kapre); Joanne Ko / Sofia Zobel (Bai Liwanag); HazelSabas / ToniLopezGonzales (Sarimanok); NonoyFroilan (Kaapoan). Premiered by BalletPhilippines on 13 Dec 1990 at the Main Theater, now the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, of the Cultural Center of the Philippines.

Based on the traditionalkorido(metrical romance),this interpretation emphasizes the allegorical meanings of the IbongAdarna story with Filipinized setting and characters. The illness of the king, for example, is symbolic of the State’s moral deterioration. The ballet also transforms the magical bird into an enchanted princess. Act 1 starts in the kingdom of Palanyag where Raha Magpantay (The Just) and his wife Bai Liwanag (The Enlightened) live with their three sons—Malakas (The Strong), Makisig (The Handsome), and Mabait (The Good). All is peaceful until the king dreams that Mabait has been mauled by two villains. He falls ill and the court physician advises that only the song of the Ibong Adarna can cure him. One after the other, the three sons go to Bundok Tabor in search of the magical bird. When it is Mabait’s turn, he saves the firefly Ningning, as she is beset by akapre(tobacco-smoking ogre) andhigante(giant). In gratitude, Ningning brings him to a celebration of Kislap, queen of the fireflies and the air spirits; Kaapoan, king of the dwarfs and the earth spirits; and Kalipay, queen of the fairies and the water spirits. They all advise the prince on how to capture the Adarna. It lives in Batong Pilak, sings seven seductive songs, and scatters its droppings. The song lulls the listener to sleep while the droppings turn him to stone. Mabait is given a golden knife with which to cut himself, and seven bitterdayap(lime) to keep him awake, a golden cage for the Adarna, as well as living water to pour over the stones beneath the bird’s tree. He flies off with Ningning in a magical vinta, the Caracoa.

Act 2 reveals the rainbow-hued Adarna to Mabait as an enchanted princess, Bai Marilag, princess of the kingdom of Kawayan, who refused her father’s choice for a husband and was condemned to live as a bird until loved by one pure of heart. As Mabait pursues her, he hears the Adarna’s seven songs depicting the seven human frailties: lust, pride, envy, sloth, avarice, gluttony, and anger. Kept awake by Ningning and the pain of his dayap-soaked wounds, Mabait captures the Adarna. Ningning pours water on the stones beneath the tree and the brothers Malakas and Makisig come back to life. But they ungratefully maul Mabait and sail away with the Adarna. The abandoned Mabait is healed by Kislap who helps him fly back to his father’s kingdom.

Malakas and Makisig are hailed in Palanyag, but the Adarna refuses to sing to cure the king. Mabait descends from the sky amid thunder and lightning, and the Adarna starts to sing. The king revives, banishes his two villainous sons, and names Mabait his heir. The Adarna turns back into Bai Marilag and marries Mabait. Adarna is the second attempt to use the folkloric material of the korido. This version was especially important in charting directions for Philippine dance, as its libretto was Filipinized and utilized ethnic motifs and movements. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

photos.photodesc: Alice Reyes’s Amada, CCP, Manila, 1970 (Rudy Vidad, Ballet Philippines Collection)

text:
1969 Moderndance in one act and three scenes. Choreography, AliceReyes . Premiered at Sarah Lawrence University, USA in 1969. Premiered by Alice Reyes and Modern Dance Company on 19 Feb 1970 at the Main Theater, now the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). Music, LucreciaR.Kasilag; lighting design, TeodoroHilado; set design, RobertoChabet; costume design, ArturoCruz. Dancers: Alice Reyes (Doña Amada), EddieElejar (Don Rafael), TinaSantos (Tadtarin). In subsequent performances: lighting design, MoninoDuque, KatschS.J.Catoy, and Alex de Guzman; set design, SalvadorBernal. Dancers in succeeding performances: EsterRimpos / JoyCoronel / ElizabethRoxas / EdnaVida (Amada); ManuelMolina / TonyFabella / NonoyFroilan (Don Rafael); Ester Rimpos / CecileSicangco (Tadtarin).

Inspired by NickJoaquin’s short story, “Summer Solstice,” the principal characters of this modern one-act ballet in three scenes are the aristocratic couple, Don Rafael and Doña Amada. The setting is 19th century Manila, a city to which young men were returning from Europe bringing with them the Age of Byron, instead of the Age of Victoria. Traditional male dominance is suddenly shaken by the summer solsticetadtarinritual that climaxes on the feast of Saint John the Baptist. Women suddenly reign supreme, and dark frenzied rites celebrate death and resurrection; primitive impulses shatter the veneer of urbanity, and Hispanic molds and patterns. In the end, Don Rafael prostrates himself before Amada’s feet.

As a student at Sarah Lawrence University, Reyes presented Amada as her master’s thesis in 1969. When she returned to Manila, the work highlighted her first modern dance concert. Roberto Chabet’s debut paved the way for later stage designers for modern dance. Lucrecia R. Kasilag’s music for the ballet is atonal and serial with irregular rhythmic meters of fives and sevens. She uses intermittent percussive sounds of drums, sticks and gongs, and piano that had no definite melody, giving the effect of tension and irresolution.

The choreography has a distinct Spanish flavor, especially in the solo variations of Amada, and Filipino ethnic movements, juxtaposed with the strong influence of Martha Graham in the dramatic sections of the tadtarin rituals. Reyes’s first major modern choreographic work elicited mixed reactions from the critics and audiences then, but has now emerged as a milestone in Filipino modern dance.

Amada was performed in the Visayan Summer Dance Tour in Apr 1970; at the Shell House in London, United Kingdom in Jun 1972; at the Teatro de la Zarzuela in Madrid, Spain, where the company opened the Afro-Asiatic Festival in Jul 1972; at the 50th anniversary celebration of the American Dance Festival in Durham, North Carolina in Jun 1984; and in other countries like the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, China, Australia, France, Germany, Italy, Greece, and various Southeast Asian countries. Written by Edna Vida

photos.photodesc: Anak-Bulan, CCP Dance Company, CCP Manila, 1976 (Rudy Vidad, Ballet Philippines)

text:
(Moon Child). 1976. Modern ballet in one act. Choreography, LydiaMadarang-Gaston. Music, RosalinaAbejo RVM; lighting design, MoninoDuque; set design, Salvador Bernal; costume design, SalvadorBernal andRafaeldelCasal. Premiered by the CCP Dance Company, now BalletPhilippines, at the Main Theater, now the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, of the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP). Dancers: Lydlyd Gaston (Isabel), EsterRimpos (Her Mirror Image), NonoyFroilan (Lover), Lydia Madarang-Gaston (Nursemaid).

In this one-act ballet based on NickJoaquin’s story, “MayDayEve,” ayaya(nursemaid) frightens her wards into bed. Only the brave Isabel dares go to the mirror; it reflects her own image, and that of a young man. She enters the mirror, and another world, where there is a ball. She imitates her image dancing with the man, in a pas de trois. Taking the man for herself, she performs a pas de deux with him and is part of that world for a while. In the end, she must return to her own world. In reality, she is found sprawled before the mirror holding a candle; no one believes her story. Alone, she returns to the mirror that shows her the same man, but now cold, conceited, and cruel. Yet she accepts him and her fate.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history

photos.photodesc: Andres KKK, Philippine Ballet Theatre, CCP, Manila, 1996 (Philippine Ballet Theatre Collection)

text:
1996. Contemporary ballet in two acts. Choreography, Gener Caringal ; libretto, Lilia Quindoza-Santiago; music, Jesse Lucas; lighting design, Dennis Marasigan;costume design, Arturo V. Cruz; set design, Ricardo Cruz. Premiered by Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT) on 29 Nov 1996 at the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). Alternating dancers: Melvin Martinez, Ronilo Jaynario, Lucas Jacinto (Andres); Maritoni Rufino, Melanie Motus, Guada de Leon (Oryang); Quincy Jacinto (The General), Andrei Roslovtsev (SpanishGuardia Civilor Constable), Orlando de Leon (Teodoro Patiño), Rachel Gavieta (Honoria), and Iouri Vyskubenko (Fraile). In restagings, Andres was played by Quincy Jacinto, Marvin Ryan Arizo, Jared Tan, and Lemuel Capa, while Oryang was performed by Maricar Medina, Faye Abigail Tan, and Bianca Trocino.

PBT’s Andres KKK celebrated the centennial of the revolution in 1996, focusing on the rise and fall of Andres Bonifacio, thesupremo(leader) of the revolutionary force, and concluding with a controversial depiction of his death. Act 1 opens with Andres dancing a solo to Bonifacio’s own “Pag-ibig sa Tinubuang Lupa” (Love for the Motherland), with voice over narration by actor Joonee Gamboa. The supremo then rallies his countrymen in “Sandugo” (Blood Pact). The male members of the ensemble slash their arms to symbolize their pledge of brotherhood in the Katipunan. The civil guards, led by an arrogant Spanish general, walk through the town, while the womenfolk busy themselves to conceal the activities of the newly-formed revolutionary army. One of the women is Oryang, or Gregoria de Jesus, with whom Andres falls in love. They get married in a typical rural Filipino celebration, with guests dancing with kumintang (circular or wavelike hand movements from the wrist) gestures and sway balance steps. After this, a trio shows how Teodoro and Honoria Patiño divulge the Katipunan’s activities to a Spanish friar. Upstage in silhouette, Katipunan members witness the revolutionary wedding of Bonifacio and Oryang.

A tableau of oppressed Filipinos is strategically placed to resemble the mise-en-scene in Juan Luna’s Spoliarium. Andres looks at the tableau and is inflamed to launch the revolution to liberate his countrymen. In a sequence of dances, Bonifacio calls on the Katipunan brothers and sisters who wave Katipunan flags, tear up their cedula at Balintawak, take up arms, and rush forward toward the audience in a cry of battle.

Act 2 opens with the fighting seen in slow motion through clouds of smoke and strobe lights. The smoke of battle clears to show a wasteland of bodies, with the survivors tending to the wounded or burying their dead. Andres takes his wife and brothers to Cavite to mediate in the struggle between the Magdalo and the Magdiwang factions. But an unnamed general orders his men to arrest and torture the Bonifacio brothers and rape Oryang,even as Aguinaldo stands and moves with authoritative arrogance as head of the dictatorial government. Bonifacio’s death is symbolically portrayed. He is tied to a swing, which rises over the stage spot where the Magdalo soldiers raped his wife. From that swing, he sees the atrocities below. A shot rings out and Andres is killed. The dance ends with revolutionaries dancing to “Bayan Ko” (My Country). They hand over the Philippine flag to a living Gregoria de Jesus, who walks toward the audience, offering the flag to the nation.

Andres KKK was restaged at the CCP in 1997 and 2008, and had outreach performances in 1998.Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

photos.photodesc: Ang Babaylan, Teatro Amakan, UP Visayas Auditorium,Iloilo City, 1988 (CCP Collection)

text:
(The Shaman). 1988. Dance drama in two acts. Choreography, Basilio ; script, lyrics, and direction, EdwardDefensor; music, Ang Taga-aton, with the “Kapinangan’s Theme” by Arlene Chongson; set design conceived by Defensor and Basilio, executed by Fundador Tan; masks by Fundador Tan. Premiered by Teatro Amakan of the University of the Philippines (UP) Visayas on 10 Nov 1988 at the UP Visayas Auditorium, Iloilo Cliy. Cast: Rey Formacion (Bangotbanwa), Raoul Cañonero (Datu Sumakwel), Geraldine Montelibano (Kapinangan), and Fundador Tan (Gurong-gurong).

The story weaves together tales and incidents from pre-Spanish and Spanish colonial times, focusing on the role of thebabaylanor shaman—Bangotbanwa in Act 1, and the female and male babaylanes in Act 2, who lead the people in struggling against the Spanish authorities.

The dance drama in two acts highlights crucial spoken dialogues, but it is mostly told in dance inspired by folk practices. Occupational dances are interspersed with ritual and combat scenes. The ritual dances are performed with bolo and capes, china bowls, palaspas (palm fronds), and the manangyad (legendary long necklace) of Kapinangan, Datu Sumakwel’s wife. Love dances, a spring ritual dance with fairies, and Kapinangan’s bath are more stylized, as is a mimetic dance between a boar and Sumakwel’s aide, Gurong-gurong. Act 2 dramatizes a series of encounters between the natives headed by a succession of babaylan, and the Spanish civil and religious authorities. Seemingly ending in the defeat of the rebels, a youthful babaylan rises over dead bodies to martial their spirits, promising to invigorate the next generation that will reassert its claims for freedom. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

text:
(The Wedding). 1982. Ballet cantata in one act. Choreography, TonyFabella ; libretto, RamonP.Santos; music, Igor Stravinsky; lighting direction, MoninoDuque; set design, AmielLeonardia; costume design, Alfonso Guinoo. Premiered by the University of the Philippines College of Music Dance Ensemble on 2 Dec 1982 at the Main Theater, now the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, of the Cultural Center of the Philippines. Dancers: AnnaVilladolid (Bride), LutherPerez (Groom), Ianne Damian and Jojo Isorena (Parents of the Bride), Leila Florentino and Rey Magnaye (Parents of the Groom).

The ballet cantata is adapted from Les Noces,a traditional Russian wedding, which was premiered by the Ballet Russe de Diaghilev on 13 Jun 1923 at Theatre Gaite-Lyrique, Paris. Originally choreographed by Bronislava Nijinska, there are other versions by Jerome Robbins, Lar Lubovitch, and Jiri Kylian.

Against a cyclorama are bold pylons of intersecting beams before which the chorus stands on tall risers, set off by four grand pianos and a percussion ensemble. These are visible through a gauze curtain across the whole stage and a central boulder-platform. To the right are the bride and her bridesmaids forming a wedge, and to the left are the groom and his friends, forming another wedge. As the chorus sings, the sitting bride moves anxiously as though doing her hair. Her maids imitate her, assure, surround and turn her round and round. They all move out on space, still mirroring the bride’s anxiety and sustaining her. The bride’s mother comes to support her. The maids adorn the bride’s arms and hide her. The standing groom and his friends move assertively. The friends wind a long headband around the groom as they go round and round him. His father blesses him and his mother gives him a long necklace. Led by the airborne groom, the men dance further out in space.

The parties of the bride and groom gradually cross each other’s spaces led by the respective parents. The bride’s mother dances a solo of grief. The respective parties return decked with grand ceremonial headdresses, Bukidnon style, followed by the similarly bedecked bride and groom with their long trains and capes. The gauze curtain opens on all, starkly revealing the singers, musicians, and high beams. The bride and groom flank a priest before whom the parents kneel and link arms, and the bridesmaids and friends lie prostrate. The bride and groom also link hands, blessed by the priest with a long scarf. As they go upstage, the rest dance in jubilation downstage. The bride and groom ascend the boulder-platform. Alone, the bride gradually strips herself of adornments and clothes, as though following a prescribed ritual that she both fears and submits to. When the groom returns naked, she is the more afraid, needing his reassurance. A male solo seems to still everything. Finally, all that remain are the pianos, lights hanging from the beams, and the bride and groom standing still and looking at each other. The ballet is commended for the adaptation of Stravinsky’s Les Noces to a Philippine setting and the establishment of cultural parallelisms between the Bukidnon indigenous group and the Russian peasantry. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history
text:
(The Wedding). 2002. Contemporary dance in two parts. Choreography, Flordeliza Fernandez-Punzalan; music, Igor Stravinsky; text adapted and translated by Ramon P. Santos, and conducted live by Josefino Toledo; costume design, Liza Fernandez. First premiered as Ang Kasal, Unang Bahagi ( Les Noces, Part One) by UP Dance Company on 28 Feb 2002 at the Abelardo Hall Auditorium, University of the Philippines (UP). Premiere of the full ballet on 26 Sep 2002, also by UP Dance Company. Dancers: Elena Laniog, Ernest Hojilla, Angela Lawenko, Herbert Alvarez, Andrew Baris, Ava Maureen Villanueva, Marielle Alonzo, Yvonne Torres, Nina Hayuma Habulan, Brizel Maribbay, Bea Puno, Joyce Comia, and Clarissa Mijares.

Ang Kasal is a Filipino version of Bronislava Nijinska’s Les Noces, to the original music by Igor Stravinsky with choreography adapted from a Cordillera setting. At the premiere, the Filipino translation by Ramon Santos was sung live by soprano Aileen Espinosa Cura, mezzo soprano Janet Sabas Aracama, tenor Jonathan Malicsi, bass Reuel Tica, and the UP Concert Chorus; accompanied by pianists Benjamin Dia, Carolyn Kleiner Cheng, Beverly Shangkuan, and Mauricia Borromeo; and percussionists Leo Roque, Gomer Giron, Aimee Mina, Francis Miranda, William Lazaga, and Noel Villanueva.

The production is actually the second Ang Kasal. In 1982, Tony Fabella created a Filipinized version of Nijinska’s Les Noces, set to Stravinsky’s music, but using traditional Bukidnon rituals and culture. Even then, there were parallels between the indigenous Filipino traditions and the Russian peasant marriage customs as outlined in Nijinska’s work. Both Fabella’s and Fernandez’s versionsfollow the storyline of Les Noces, with the families of the bride and the groom preparing for the nuptial. The choreography by Fernandez, however, uses the cultural practices of the Cordilleran communities which are similar to the Russian peasant customs. Instead of the Russian folk symbolism of the braided hair joining the families, the dancers move around the bride and groom, mimicking how the people of the Cordillera dance in circular formation while playing their gongs in both festive and solemn celebrations. Instead of the traditional gong beat, the dancers move to Stravinsky whose opus was synchronized with the rhythmic structure and impulses of traditional Igorot dance.

While performed barefoot, there are still balletic elements in the movement, with sissonnes (jump like scissors), glissade s (joining steps), and pas de bourrees (beating steps) used alternatively with the shuffling movements of Cordilleran dance. The vocabulary, however, was also more modern in its successful fusion of the balletic, modern, and traditional styles. The intensity of the dancing, as dictated both by the traditional Cordilleran impulses and by the music of Stravinsky, is what makes Fernandez’s Ang Kasal impressive and memorable.

Ang Kasal was restaged twice in Kuala Lumpur: in Aug 2003 for the ASEAN Theatre Festival at the Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia, then in 2007 at the Tari International Festival at Akademi Seni Budaya Dan Warisan Kebangsaan (National Academy for Arts and Culture). Japheth Mari Cabling and Angella Betina Carlos restaged the work as part of their graduation recital for the UP College of Music Dance program in Mar 2013. Eunice Velasco and Minette Caryl Maza alternated as the bride, Jeiel Hernandez and Joshua Pinca alternated as the groom, Michael Barry Que and Mark Robles alternated as the groom’s father, and Aries Joy Manlapaz and Carissa Carmel Estrada alternated as the bride’s mother.Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history

photos.photodesc: Choreographer William Morgan as Simeona, leading the maglalatik dancers in Ang Pilya, Ballet Philippines, CCP, Manila, 1988 (Rudy Vidad, Ballet Philippines Collection)

text:
(Naughty Girl). 1988. Ballet in three acts. Choreography, WilliamMorgan ; scenario, JovenVelasco, from Jean Dauberval’s La Fille Mal Gardee (The Unchaperoned Daughter); music, Ferdinand Herold and Peter Ludwig Hertel; lighting design, KatschS.J.Catoy; set design and costume, SalvadorBernal. Premiered by BalletPhilippines on 18 Feb 1988 at the Tanghalang NicanorAbelardo, Cultural Center of the Philippines. Dancers: LisaMacuja / HazelSabas (Lisa); NonoyFroilan / BrandoMiranda (Kulas); WilliamMorgan (Simeona); ConradDy-Liacco (Alan); Jojo Lucila (Don Tomas).

The plot is essentially the same as in the original ballet: a girl is urged by her mother to marry a rich man’s stupid son; but she gets her way and marries her poor boyfriend. The setting is Lucban, Quezon in the 1920s. The events transpire during the feast of the farmer’s saint San Isidro Labrador, when the town is decorated with food products and the specialkiping, paper-thin translucent rice fritters, brightly colored and shaped like leaves. Act 1 opens on Mother Simeona and her adventurous daughter, Lisa, who consorts with Kulas despite the mother’s restrictions. Lisa’s friends help her to escape every so often. But Simeona has plans for Lisa to marry Don Tomas’ butterfly-chasing son Alan, who is quite “strange,” except to Lisa’s cousin, Ramona. A dance accentuating thetapis(overskirt) is performed in the first act. Act 2 features the feast and the procession, themaglalatik(coconut jam-maker) dance, and Simeona’s flamenco from hersarsuweladays.Kulas and Lisa manage to be on their own, and Alan spots Ramona for himself. But a storm breaks out and everyone runs for cover. Act 3 opens with preparations for the wedding. Simeona looks over Lisa’s dress. Meanwhile baskets of farm products are brought into Simeona’s house for the wedding. Simeona leaves for a while but locks up the house. But the clever Kulas has hidden himself among the baskets and surprises Lisa. Hearing her mother’s return, Lisa hides Kulas in her room. Suspicious, Simeona orders Lisa into her room, not knowing that Kulas is there. When Don Tomas and Alan arrive, the young lovers are found together in Lisa’s room. After a fainting spell, Simeona has to agree to their wedding, and to Ramona and Alan’s. Don Tomas then asks for Simeona’s hand. A triple wedding ends the ballet.

Ang Pilya is the first Filipino adaptation of the original 1789 Dauberval ballet set in a French provincial town. The premiere of Pilya drew positive reviews forVelasco’s adaptation of the 1789 La Fille Mal Gardee because itdeveloped the comedy and commentary of the ballet. William Morgan, combining Hertel and Herold’s scores, outsmarted himself with one of his most captivating choreographies, and with his own excellent portrayal of Simeona that entertained the audiences. The occupationalmaglalatikdance stood on its own and developed Simeona’s shawl-seducing flamenco; both beguile like the clog dance in Frederick Ashton’s classic.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history

photos.photodesc: Ang Sultan, Philippine Ballet Theatre, CCP, Manila, 2008 (Ador G. Pamintuan)

text:
(The Sultan). 1973. Moderndance in one act. Scenario and choreography, GenerCaringal ; music, DivertissementforPianoandOrchestra,adapted to the piano by LucreciaR.Kasilag; lighting design, TeodoroHilado and Monino Duque; set design, Duque; costume design, ArturoCruz. Premiered by the CCP Dance Workshop Company, now Ballet Philippines, on 12 Oct 1973 at the Main Theater, now the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, of the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP). Dancers: Lydlyd Gaston (Princess), EddieElejar (Sultan), and ReyDizon (Lover).

This one-act modern piece uses space to demarcate the areas of the men and of the women, and most of the conflicts arise from what happens to the main protagonists between them. The sultan is loftily borne by his men, among them the commoner who falls in love with the sultan’s daughter. The princess is surrounded by her handmaidens or guarded by the sultan himself. But the lovers meet in a pas de deux highlighted by supported poses and lifts. The commoner-lover is flogged, and the sultan decides to execute him with a lance. But as the sultan throws the weapon, the princess runs between the weapon and her lover, is pierced, and dies. The villagers turn away from the sultan, carry the princess away, and leave the sultan alone to grieve.

There was an earlier version of Ang Sultan titled Patriarch,set to music by Alan Hovahness. It was presented on 1 Jun 1973 for the Fourth CCP Summer Dance Workshop at the CCP. The princess was Lydlyd Gaston, the lover Rey Dizon, and the sultan Ronnie Leonardo.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

text:
(Song). 1982. Modern ballet in one act. Choreography, Basilio ; music and concept, RamonP.Santos; lighting design, MoninoDuque; set design, AmielLeonardia; costumes design, Basilio and Raquel Rey. Premiered by the University of the Philippines College of Music Dance Ensemble on 2 Dec 1982 at the Main Theater, now the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, of the Cultural Center of the Philippines. Dancers: Rebecca Rodriguez (aggressive woman), AnnaVilladolid (desperate woman), Del Caragan (man), and Susan Atizado (third woman).

Awit is a multimedia piece for four singers, three guitars, percussions, four dancers, a movable set, and special lights. As described by the composer, Awit is expression as perceived in various levels of consciousness through the different phenomena of silence, sound, light, melody, shape, motion, and space. Its depth is projected in the constant permutations in duration, intensity, the brightness and dimness of colors, lyricism, simplicity, complexity, gestures and accents, illusion, and reality. It derives its spirit from the music molded by years of living traditions and its totality is realized through the mystery of the human voice and the metaphor of the human body.

The dance happens on four overlapping ovular platforms that are echoed by four screen panels. Split pieces of one ovular idea, the screens are lit from behind, the sides or the front. The dancers are seen through these rising and descending screens as they trace a maze and find their individual confining screens at the end. The four dancers—three females and one male—progress from swaying minimally together as one, to separating, disturbing, and supporting each other. Following the music’s rise and fall, flow or stress, plucked accents or sustained rhythm, the dancers act out the following: an aggressive woman separates from the three, starts a combat with the man, and ends with them loving each other. Rejoining the two women behind, they make a foursome and do a rhythmic dance of linked hands, linked steps (canonic or unison), and crisscrossings, with Indian-style gestures and martial movements.

As the music becomes spare, one desperate woman dances out a personal cry of her own. She breaks up the huddled trio and brings each one to crying gestures. To a renewed rhythmic play, the man dances out his own urgent solo that leads to the women carrying him about to soothe and sustain him. They all move back to the ovular platforms as the panels start descending; they take separate places behind their respective screens. As the music and lights gradually diminish, they sway separately and reach out in spurts. The guitars are plucked with finality and the voices trail away in the dark.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

text:
(Priestess). 1993. Modern dance. Choreography, Agnes Locsin ; music, Maki Ishii; lighting design, Monino Duque; costume design, Dennis Maristany. Premiered by Ballet Philippines (BP) on 19 Aug 1993 at the 2nd Tokyo International Choreography Competition in Tokyo, Japan. Dancers: Gaye Galiluyo (Babalyan); Edmund Gaerlan, Dwight Rodrigazo, Alden Lugnasin, Gerald Mercado (attendants).

Babalyanis the Tagbanwa terminology forbabaylan, the Philippine term for “shaman” or “priestess.” Agnes Locsin used this word for the title of a 12-minute neo-ethnic dance she created for BP as entry to the 2nd Tokyo International Choreography Competition. It is based on apagdiwataritual from the Tagbanwa, an indigenous group of Palawan where Locsin did firsthand research on the ritual.

The dance begins with the Babalyan in a trance, bathed by a single spotlight, using her hands and fingers as representations of the coconut leaves traditionally used by a babalyan for rituals. She slaps her hands on her thighs, pivots toward the four male dancers and jumps into a sitting position on the men who catch her and sway gently as an imaginary hammock. The ritual progresses with the cleansing of cutlery, represented by the male bodies, to be used in the ceremony. In the next segment, the Babalyan goes through the routine of warding off evil spirits surrounded by the male dancers whose movements are designed to protect her. In the dance’s climax she uses angular and jerky movements to indicate her success in resisting the spirits and ends up lifted by the male dancers in a sitting position, quietly swaying like a hammock.

Babalyan is one of Locsin’s most creative and challenging dance pieces because she effectively uses plain movements, body parts, lighting, and music as representational elements in a pagdiwata ritual which traditionally requires a lot of material components. Her choreographic style is markedly neo-ethnic, but she pushes the boundaries of this medium to create a powerful and dramatic interpretation of the ritual. The music Locsin chose was Maki Ishii’s Expressionen, one of the five music pieces pre-selected by the organizers. She collaborated and experimented with the five dancers for movement exploration.

On 24 Aug 1993, Babalyan won the Silver Medal at the 2nd Tokyo International Choreography Competition and for Locsin, the Prince Takamado Award for excellence in choreography. Babalyan has become part of BP’s repertoire and has been restaged in numerous performances in the company’s local and international tours.Written by Nestor O. Jardin

text:
1990. Modern ethnic dance in one act. Scenario and choreography, AgnesLocsin ; music, Peter Gabriel; lighting design, Tony Esteban; set and costume design, SalvadorBernal. Premiered byBalletPhilippines 2 on 22 Mar 1990 at the Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino, Cultural Center of the Philippines. Dancers: Camille Ordinario (Victim); Annette Cruz, Annie Divinagracia, Christine Maranan, Isabel Gregorio, Leilani Hortaleza, and Je-an Salas (Bagobo braves).

Described as neo-ethnic, the dance draws inspiration from the once-feared ritual of human sacrifice that was practiced solemnly and secretly by the Bagobo of Davao. The work uses ethnic styles and values.

The dance centers on a bound sacrificial victim. Terrified, she can only stamp, twist, walk on her knees, roll, rise and fall, slowly, painfully, unable to use her arms. She dances to the unremitting drone of the music, with its humming and bellowing, flute and voice, shaken beat, and ostinato.

Against the victim are six Bagobo braves whom Locsin casts as women. Their severe black costumes, their Bagobo stance, steps, and rhythm eliminate all sexual bias. They move not like torturers but as an unequivocal natural force embodying the customary law enthroned by tribal traditions. Their choric power lies in their impersonal, almost supernatural, persona. They traverse the stage deliberately, ponderously as the victim runs around and amid them, incapable of escaping their hieratic poses and lunges. Their hands and stances are sculptural, almost monumental. Like a prisoner in the maze of the minotaur, the victim is trapped by the cruel inexorability of a supreme life-and-death code.

Neither narrative, literal nor ideological, the piece magically evokes the world of the numinous that the folk believe in. An intense experience that is uncompromising in the pursuit of its intent, its long-drawn ensemble process, heightened or attenuated at turns, creates a credible yet mysterious and primal world to which an urban audience is drawn.Written by Nestor O. Jardin

text:
1990. Neoclassical ballet in one movement. Choreography, Tony Fabella ; music, Jose Mari Chan, arranged by Archie Castillo; costume design, Sol Fernandez and Alexander Idea. Premiered by Philippine Ballet Theatre on 21 Sep 1990 at the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo of the Cultural Center of the Philippines. Dancers: Noreen Ostrea, Anna Marie Tirol, Rosalie Carreon, Maritoni Rufino, Liza de la Fuente, Guada de Leon, Liza Berroya, and Mylene Saldana.

Fabella’s witty choreography using Chan’s popular songs such as “Constant Change,” “Please Be Careful with My Heart,” and “Beautiful Girl” transformed a beauty contest runway into a display of beauty and grandeur. Far removed from the typical television pageant, the ballet evoked the fashion scene of the 1970s when beauty queens werede buena familia(to the manor born), imbued with elegance and opulence. In this way, Beautiful Girls successfully glamourized the PBT ballerinas and showed off their different facets.

The dancers, dressed in beautiful floor-length gowns, sashay in movements contrapuntal to each other, striking beauty poses now and then. Their gloved arms add glamour for effect, but instead of heeled stilettos, they dance en pointe. After a brief unison, the ladies exit the dance floor and a series of solos follow, each different from the last, highlighting the natural gifts of each ballerina such as beautiful extensions, height, suppleness, rhythmic timing, sultriness, dramatic flair, or bravura. The ballet ends with all the girls on center stage, in a tableau of glamour poses.

A shorter version was more regularly restaged after the premiere and was performed at the 20th anniversary of PBT in 2005. Included in the generations of dancers who were cast in this work are Melanie Motus, Katrina Santos-Mercado, Maricar Medina, Faye Lezama, Aileen Ruiz, Sharon Brendia, Faye Abigail Tan, Lea Baduria, Marites Cabael, Therese Arcinas, Tara Ferrer, Michelle Navarro, Jacqui Jacinto, Erica Marquez, Joan Geraldine Ayap, Tiffany Mangulabnan, Joni Galeste, Joey Atayde, Isabel Guidote, Lea de Guzman, Saeko Hayashi, and Rofel Artaiz.Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

text:
(Peace Pact Agreement / Transfer of Peace Pact). 2005. Indigenous Kalinga dance. Performed by Sumadel and Mangali Kalinga at Licoutan village, Tanudan municipality, Kalinga province, to celebrate the transfer of abodong, or peace pact, from father to son.

The Kalinga culture group is composed of about 47ili, or subgroups. A subgroup may reside in several villages; the Mangali Kalinga, for example, reside in eight villages in the municipality of Tanudan in the southern part of Kalinga province. The bodong is an agreement forged and maintained by at least two Kalinga subgroups, such as the Mangali Kalinga and the Sumadel Kalinga, to ensure that peaceful relations between their members prevail. The establishment or renewal of a bodong is a prolonged ceremony with feasting, the playing of musical instruments, singing, and dancing. The galigad is the transfer of a bodong from a peace-pact holder to someone else, usually his son. Thus, the galigad guarantees the continuity of a bodong from one generation to the next.

The participants perform communal dances on a field that has been cleared by the host villagers for the festivities. The dances are the men’s tadok / tachek, the women’s sangni,and a male and female couple’s seledsed/salidsid. A recent innovation is a choreographed dance performed on a stage but still consisting of the traditional foot and arm movements. The musical instruments accompanying these dances are thegangsa(gongs),balladong(flute), andkullitong(zither).

There are at least two Kalinga subgroups participating in the three-day celebration: one subgroup hosts about fifty representatives of the other subgroup, who come to the host village as guests and partners in the peace-pact agreement. When the guests arrive at the host village, they are welcomed by a group of about six gangsa players doing the tadok/tachek as a greeting dance. The inclusion of one or two female player-dancers among the men is a contemporary deviation from tradition because the tadok is traditionally exclusive only to men. Their dance space is not yet the main area where the major scenes of the bodong or galigad ceremony will be performed in the next two days. Here, it is just big enough for the six dancers.

The tadok is the basic Kalinga dance movement and a formation of a single line of player-dancers. The leader is their best gangsa player with the ability to play thesapul, the elemental melody providing the steady rhythm of the five other player-dancers. He also determines which way their line will go, now snaking to the right, now to the left, now turning to face the other way and reversing the direction of the line, thus allowing the last in line to be the leader. The basic foot movement is the dasudas, in whichthe dancers stay in place while moving their feet and playing their gongs. For variety, they may do the dallokog, in which they bend low, with their gangsa hanging a few inches above the ground; and the angububuot, in whichthe leader and followers dance backward while keeping in line.

In the evening after supper, both hosts and guests celebrate thedolnat(to warm up) by dancing alternately till midnight. The women now join the men but they form their own line with their own dance movement called the “sangni.”While doing the dasudas, they use two arm movements alternately: the dopa,withthe arms outstretched and flapping like a flying bird’s wings, and the angawak, with their hands on their hips. The dasudas is done continuously.

The first day of the celebration proper is the next day, consisting of a series of celebratory activities called theinum(to drink). The venue is outside the village, where the hosts have cleared a field to create a festival area for hundreds of participants. A stage for solo performances and the guests’ makeshift shelters are erected on this clearing. The sequence of activities is the following: the presentation of gifts composed ofdekot(sticky rice cake) and 100-peso bills arranged to form several Philippine flags; tadok dancing; the bodong or galigad ritual; a choreographed dance; and another type of communal dancing performed in pairs. Except for the communal dancing, all these are done on the stage.

After the presentation of gifts from the host group, it is now the guests’ turn to dance. This is in a tadok style distinctly different from the tadok of the hosts. The Sumadel Kalinga dance the tadok in the binowagan style, which is distinct from that of the Mangali men. The Mangali kick their left foot with their leg straight in front as they hop on the right foot. The Sumadel kick their right foot backward with right knee bent as they hop on the left foot. The Sumadel and the Bontok have this tadok in common. On the other hand, the Mangali and Sumadel women’s sangni are identical. Thus, they can dance together or exchange places, whereas the Mangali and Sumadel men must keep to their respective lines.

The second day of the celebration begins with the bodong or galigad ceremony, when speeches are made by the main participants vowing to be faithful to the terms of the peace pact. This is followed by a rehearsed dance by five young women on stage as two men play the balladong and the kullitong. This breaks three Kalinga traditions: First, the dance, now performed for an audience, takes on the nature of a “folk dance.” Second, it is done on stage, not on a communal space. Third, the two musical instruments accompanying this folk dance are traditionally played for private enjoyment. In this staged performance, the dancers stay in place as they do the dasudas while their arms alternate between the bird-like dopa motions, and the hands-on-hips angawak position. This choreography differs significantly from the women’s spontaneous sangni of the previous day, when they moved back and forth in a line.

The dancing then transfers to the festival grounds, where all take turns participating. The seledsed is danced to the accompaniment of thetuppaya, a particular style of gong playing. Six male youths play in the tuppaya style on apinakid(six-gong set). The tuppaya sound is created with the player’s palms slapping and sliding on the gong, which is laid on his lap. The seledsed is a mimetic dance between a man and a woman: the man as a rooster chasing a hen, and the woman as the hen evading the rooster. The dance movements involve a towel that each holds between his or her hands. After dancing for a while, they pass on their towels to another pair, who then replace them. More dancing, singing, and dekot presentations continue until late into the night.

On the third day, three activities conclude the celebration: the reading of the terms of the bodong; thetumangad(ritual wine drinking), and thepalpaliwat, which is a contest in oratory.Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

text:
(A Subanon Communal Celebration). 1997. Contemporary ballet in three sections. Choreography by Tony Fabella ; music by Leonard Eto and Motofumi Yamaguchi; lighting design by John Neil Ilao Batalla; set design by Ricardo Cruz; costume design by Tony Fabella. Premiered by Philippine Ballet Theatre in 1997 at the Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino, Cultural Center of the Philippines. Dancers: Maritoni Rufino, Ronilo Jaynario, and the company.

This work was presented during the 1997 Filipino Choreographers Showcase. The first two sections were solos for Rufino and Jaynario, both characterized as animals. Rufino was slick and supple as a snake, while Jaynario was frenetic and engaging as a monkey. These solos did not seem to connect to the main section of Buklog, nor did it have any apparent association with thebuklogritual, appearing instead to be explorations of movement.

The third section of Fabella’s Buklog was inspired by the Subanon indigenous dance of the same name. Performed during rituals for healing the sick and releasing their dead to heaven, the ritual includes building a structure of tall timber posts which support a bamboo platform, on which the ritual participants dance. The structure has a log pestle at the center below the platform, making sounds as it pounds into the hollowed earth as the ritual dancers bounce on it. This traditional dance has the Subanon holding hands in a circle, with jumping and crisscrossing steps.

Fabella’s movements for this modern adaptation of the ritual involved many circular steps and patterns, including quick pirouettes of different leg placements, as well as variations on bouncing and stamping to mimic the Subanon bouncing on their bamboo platform. The buklog is a communal ritual, so Fabella used the whole company to reenact the joyous coming together of the community. Dancers were grouped according to “type”—the high jumpers, the turners, the graceful, and brusque dancers; every so often, one soloist would break away from the small trios to punctuate their own section and then moved back into their small unison again. Then, Jaynario and Rufino entered the scene to lead the company in the building of the buklog structure, represented by theater scaffolding. The men brought in the metal pipes and assembled the scaffolding as the women bounced around them and eventually climbed the structure. The work ended with a jubilant unison, with dancers moving both on the floor and on the scaffolding. Rufino was positioned at the very top, assisted by Jaynario.

Buklog was restaged regularly for outreach and regional performances of the company. In Buklog, apparent was Fabella’s choreographic process, and his intuitiveness and affinity for the dancers he worked with.Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

text:
(Bundle Suite). 1972. A suite of modern dances. Choreography, AliceReyes ; music, traditional folk songs and MiguelVelarde’s “DahilSaIyo”; lighting design, TeodoroHilado; costume design, ArturoCruz. Premiered by the CCP Dance Workshop Company, later known as BalletPhilippines, on 14 Oct 1972 at the Main Theater, now the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, of the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP). Dancers: EsterRimpos, JoyCoronel, Irma Bringas, DenisaReyes, Florence Perez, TonyFabella, GenerCaringal, EnricoLabayen, FranklinBobadilla, and Romy Go.

Folk dance movements are interpreted into the modern-dance idiom to create dances that are light, airy, lyrical, even comic. Set to six popular songs, namely, “DahilSaIyo” (Because of You), “Chitchiritchit,” “Dandansoy” (Unfaithful), “ManangBiday,” “Salidummay,” and “Telebong,” the work is conceived for six pairs of dancers who perform in a solo, a duet, a trio, a quartet, and as an ensemble. At varied times, it is evocative, playful, and topical.

Bungkos was presented during the third anniversary celebration of the CCP Dance Workshop Company, with the UPMadrigalSingers providing the a capella music. This all-Filipino concert helped to promote the thrust for a distinct Filipino dance form.

The suite of dances has been performed in the United States, Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, China, Australia, Greece, Europe, and Southeast Asia as well as various Philippine cities and provinces.Written by Edna Vida

text:
1976. Modern ballet in one act and five scenes. Choreography, set, costume, and lighting design by EricV.Cruz ; music, Georges Bizet as arranged by Rodion Schedrin. Premiered by DanceConcertCompany on Jan 1976 at the Abelardo Hall, University of the Philippines, Diliman. Dancers: VellaDamian (Carmen), RupertAcuña (Don Jose), Eric V. Cruz (Escamillo), Teresita Carreon (Micaela).

The ballet in five scenes closely follows the opera narrative. Don Jose who leads the civil guards meets the sultry cigarette girl, Carmen, but soon takes her in because of a brawl she instigates. He releases her because of the passion she has instigated in him. Meanwhile, Escamillo, the matador, captivates Carmen in a tavern. Carmen reads her ill fate while camping out with gypsies. Here Don Jose turns his back on his childhood sweetheart Micaela, but Carmen rejects him. Escamillo is hailed victorious in a bullring. Carmen is confronted and finally killed by Don Jose.

This version created inimitable roles for Damian as Carmen and Acuña as Don Jose, and a most performed ballet from Dance Concert. Since the ballet was acquired by PhilippineBalletTheatre in 1989, it has featured MaiquiMañosa, Melanie Motus, and Maritoni Rufino as Carmen; NicolasPacaña, Rinat Gizatulin, and OsiasBarroso as Don Jose.

Carmen has also been plotted similarly by Rene Dimacali in Bacolod in 1976; jazzed up by AgnesLocsin for the Terpsichorean in Davao in 1977; doubled (i.e. with two Carmens) by EddieElejar for ManilaMetropolisBallet in 1980, to music by Mauricio Ohana. Carmen was also created in flamenco version for RoseBorromeo by RubenNieto (Don Jose), who drew from the Carlos Saura film, at the Light and Sound Theater Lounge, Makati in 1985. Another production was The ManyFaces of Carmen ( Her Temperaments )by Jane Dungca for St. Anne’s Dance and Music Studio, Nueva Ecija, premiered in Manila on 20 May 1988 at the Manila Film Center.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history
text:
1984. Modern ballet in one act and five scenes. Choreography and dance libretto, AliceReyes ; music, Georges Bizet, as arranged by Rodion Schedrin with additional music by Antonio Solera and Paco de Lucia; lighting design, KatschS.J.Catoy; set and costume design, SalvadorBernal. Premiered by BalletPhilippines on 14 Sep 1984 at the Main Theater, now known as Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). Dancers: EdnaVida / Mercedes Mañago (Carmen); NonoyFroilan (Don Jose); Butch Esperanza (Prosper Merimee); Romy Roxas (Escamillo); Jinn Ibarrola (Zuñiga).

This one-act ballet in five scenes is derived from the original novel by Prosper Merimee, which was also the source of Bizet’s opera. In Reyes’s version, the events are seen through the eyes of Don Jose who relates to Merimee the series of events which led to his imprisonment and execution. Don Jose is an army corporal, a simple and naive country lad aspiring for a better life. His life is suddenly disturbed when he meets and falls in love with Carmen, a very strong woman who flirts with him. She later leaves him for the bullfighter Escamillo, and in the last scene rejects Don Jose’s pleas to be taken back, saying she would rather die than live with a man she no longer loves and respects. Don Jose stabs her in desperation. Back in prison, Don Jose holds the rose Carmen threw at him, and at the end of his story gives it to Merimee before walking away to his execution.

Carmen fell into the hands of Reyes by pure accident. Originally meant for a guest choreographer, the arrangements did not pull through, and without a choreographer a few months before the scheduled performances, Reyes decided to choreograph the ballet herself. The pressure propelled Reyes to tell the story from the viewpoint of the other victim, Don Jose. The perspective rewarded a unique sentiment for the character who, in most versions, is relegated to the shadows of the story’s more colorful and dramatic lead, Carmen.

Carmen is the second full-length ballet of Ballet Philippines after Rama,Hari (Rama, King), presented through the CCP Outreach Division’s national touring program in 1987. It was repeated in Leningrad (now St. Petersburg), Union of Soviet Socialist Republics in 1988, and in Hong Kong in 1990. After Amada and Itim Asu (Onyx Wolf), this is the third ballet created by Alice Reyes which explored empowered women characters.
