photos.photodesc: Carmina Burana, CCP Dance Company, CCP, Manila, 1975 (Rudy Vidad, Ballet Philippines Collection)

text:
1975. Moderndance in one act. Choreography, AliceReyes . Music, Carl Orff; lighting design, MoninoDuque; set and costume design, SalvadorBernal. Premiered by the CCP Dance Company, later named BalletPhilippines, on 5 Sep 1975 at the Main Theater, now the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, of the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP). Dancers: TonyFabella, NonoyFroilan, GenerCaringal, ReyDizon, EsterRimpos, EffieNañas, EdnaVida, ElizabethRoxas, NesJardin, Florence Perez, Gina Mariano, Emellie Rigonan.

The text of Orff’s Carmina Burana (Songs of Beuren) was taken from an anonymous manuscript of goliardic verse discovered in 1893 in a monastery in Bavaria. The poems, which date back to the 13th century, were written by the wandering students of England, France, and Germany. Known as the Goliards, the students were better known for drinking, gambling, and rioting than scholarship. For his oratorio, Orff chose 24 poems out of the almost 200 published in 1847 by Johann Andreas Schmeller under the title Carmina Burana.The poems express the frustrations and joys inherent in man’s encounter with nature, and in the delights of drinking and love.

Keeping close to the temperament of the songs and text, Reyes’s dances are exuberant, erotic, and pagan, and build up to a spiritual climax that asserts life’s joys. The dances express the sacred and the profane, the earthy and the sublime. Vividly enhanced by Bernal’s design, the curtain rises on a stage laden with rocks embodying the earth, which are later transformed into medieval stained glass representing the divine. The ballet is considered by many to be one of Reyes’s most accomplished works.

Carmina Burana was featured in a special concert of the ManilaSymphonyOrchestra and the CCPPhilharmonicOrchestra in Oct 1984 with Helen Quach conducting. It was also presented at the Simon Bolivar Festival in Venezuela during its Bicentennial Celebration in 1983, garnering rave reviews from Venezuelan critics.Written by Edna Vida

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history

photos.photodesc: Carmina Burana, Ballet Philippines, CCP, Manila, 1995 (CCP Collection)

text:
1995. Modern ballet in 15 songs. Choreography, set and costume design, David Campos Cantero; music, Carl Orff; lighting design, Katsch S.J. Catoy. Premiered by Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT) on 21 Apr 1995 at the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, Cultural Center of the Philippines.Dancers: Guada de Leon, Maritoni Rufino, Mario Esperanza, Katrina Santos, Maricar Medina, Donnie Guarin, Patricia delos Santos, Stanley Cañete, Joey Herrera, Joel Matias, and artists of the PBT.

Carmina Burana is a series of dances to Carl Orff’s celebrated work, depicting medieval spirituality, sensuality, and penitence. It was created for PBT in 1994 by Spanish choreographer David Campos Cantero. A bookcase surrounds the stage and in between the gigantic leather-bound books are spaces from which dancers enter and exit. On top of the bookcase is a narrow platform on which some of the dances are performed.

Much of the ballet is arranged in intricate patterns. The dancing that moves through these patterns is generally comprised of simple balletic movements but at crucial times becomes intricate. The movements are sweeping and voluptuous, at times quirky and playful, always matching the demands of the dramatic music. The breathless flow of the movements, which is often interrupted by abrupt breaks following Orff’scomplex time signatures, presents an interesting atypical balletic action.

Campos does not use the entire Carmina Burana score with a 28-song cycle. He selects only 15 songs with each song less than three minutes each. The music of “O Fortuna” (O Fortune), which begins the ballet, is familiar to most audiences. The dancers are in hooded capes and faceless plaster masks. They jump on and move around square, red stools, creating patterns onstage with these stools and with each other. They also look directly at the audience several times, jutting their blank masks forward to create a chilling effect. These characters appear again in the middle of the ballet. At the end, a reprise of “O Fortuna,” they appear on top of the bookshelf, lording over penitents. Following “O Fortuna” is “Fortune Plango Vulnera”(I Lament the Wounds That Fortune Deals), a bravura pas de six (dance for six performers) with elaborate lifting and partnering to contrapuntal rhythms. Next is a somber trio to “Veris Leta Facies”(The Joyous Face of Spring)where two female waifs subtly attempt to seduce a praying young man. The trio ends with the man returning to his prayer. The next song, “Reie”(Round Dance), begins as young women carrying candles and walking on top of the bookcase enter from both sides of the stage, as in a procession. They perform a lilting dance andthe lights from the candles sway with them until they exit in a communal breath, rising in unison to an arabesque before running out. They enter again without candles and dance playfully to the “Tanz of Uf Dem Anger”(Dance in the Meadow). The male ensemble enters leaping to “Were Diu Werlt Alle Min” (If the Whole World Were Mine), and are joined again by the ladies, whom they lift over their heads in exultation. The celebration is interrupted by the penitence of a knight to “Olim Lacus Colueram”(Once I Swam in Lakes). He is tormented by Death, represented by a woman in chain mail and knightly armor, taunting him with a large sword. The knight tries to kill Death, but she persists, reminds him of his destiny, and then leaves him. He performs a solo to “Ego Sum Abbas”(I Am the Abbot). When he exits, the earlier masked figures peek into the library, then rush in and out of the bookcases to dance to “In Taberna Quando Sumus”(When We Are in the Tavern). After they make their way out between the large books, they return without their masks and capes. They now portray a new set of eight female dancers to perform “Veni, Veni, Venias”(Come, Come, Pray Come). Four male dancers join them to comprise four sets of pas de trois. As one girl in each set rushes offstage, every man lifts his remaining partner over his head and runs out, except the last couple. The remaining man gently sets his partner down to remove her gown. With this, “In Trutina”(On the Scales)begins. The woman appears to be naked. A second couple enters to join the first, repeating their confusingly sensual yet sublime pas de deux. This dance juxtaposes the sacred and the profane that Orff contrasts. “Tempus est Iocondum” (Time to Jest) is another playful romp between flirting couples, giving way to “Dulcissime” (Sweetest Boy), where the Angel of Death stands above the bookshelf, claiming a virgin. As he takes her to the afterworld, penitents enter in black cloaks to “Ave Formosissima”(Hail to the Most Lovely). Later, they throw off their cloaks to reveal the sacks underneath as “O Fortuna” (O Fortune) is reprised. When the music crescendos, the dance builds up to a climax as the curtain falls.

Carmina Burana was restaged in 1997 and 2003, twice in 2004, with special performances in Meralco Theater in 2006 and 2010.Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history

photos.photodesc: Company, CCP Dance Workshop Company, CCP, Manila, 1978 (Rudy Vidad, Ballet Philippines Collection)

text:
1970. Modern ballet in one act and three movements. Choreography, AliceReyes ; music, Johann Sebastian Bach; lighting design, TeodoroHilado; set design, RobertoChabet. Premiered on 24 Sep 1970 by the CCP Dance Workshop Company, now BalletPhilippines, at the Main Theater, later named the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). Dancers: Alice Reyes, EddieElejar, TinaSantos, TonyFabella, ManuelMolina, GenerCaringal, SteveVillaruz, Irma Bringas, Menchu de Jesus, Delia Javier, LuisLayag, Nini Gener, Cecile Santos. In subsequent performances: Set design, SalvadorBernal; lighting design, MoninoDuque, KatschS.J.Catoy, and Alex de Guzman.

This modern ballet shows the company at work, at leisure, and in performance, beginning with dancers warming up, the stage crew and anybody else who wishes to join the act milling about, against the background of a bare stage with equipment scattered about, and the overhead lights down. As the dancers execute individual and then group movements, everything gradually clears, the movements slowly coalesce and develop into a formal performance on stage. The “fun piece” ends with the dancers vying for prominent positions during the curtain call.

Company was premiered at the First Dance Workshop Scholarship Gala Concert. Its unorthodox beginning caused a stir, prompting some in the audience to leave the theater thinking that they had come to a dress rehearsal. The ones who stayed sat bewildered in their seats, losing their discomfort as the ballet slowly progressed into a more conventional “performance look,” at the end of which they applauded in relief. Company has since been included in touring programs that consist mostly of serious works, as an icebreaker and eye-opener, enjoying rave reviews from critics and delighted reactions from audiences worldwide. It has been performed in the United States, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, China, Italy, France, Germany, Spain, Great Britain, Greece, Australia, Japan, Taiwan, Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia, and Hong Kong as well as various cities and provinces in the Philippines.Written by Edna Vida

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history

photos.photodesc: Crisostomo Ibarra, Ballet Philippines, CCP, Manila, 2010 (Ballet Philippines Collection)

text:
2010. Contemporary ballet in two acts. Choreography, Paul Alexander Morales ; libretto, Paul Alexander Morales based on Jose Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere; music, Jed Balsamo; set and costume design, Jet Melencio; lighting design, Suyen Austero; videos, Ruelo Lozendo; cinematography, Regiben Romana; music mix, TJ Ramos. Premiered by Ballet Philippines (BP) on 15 Oct 2010, at the Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino, Cultural Center of the Philippines. Dancers: Jean Marc Cordero, Candice Adea, Angel Gabriel, Carissa Adea, and Katherine Trofeo.

The full-length ballet with a cast of only 15 dancers was created by Morales whose longtime interest in the novel Noli Me Tangere wasfurther heightened when he directed the musical of the same title by Bienvenido Lumbera and Ryan Cayabyab for Tanghalang Pilipino. The ballet was based on translations of the novel by Ma. Soledad Lacson-Locsin and Leon Ma. Guerreo. The work somatically rendered Philippine history and nationalism, with the visceral qualities distinct through the language of movement.

The ballet’s plot follows the novel’s story line but focuses mainly on Crisostomo Ibarra’s interactions with the characters, with the addition of imagined scenes. In the opening scene aptly titled “Alon” (Waves), Ibarra’s father appears as a ghost; this is an imagined scene set before the narrative begins. In “Kwadro” (Frame), Ibarra experiences being snubbed by the affluent during a party in Capitan Tiyago’s house. In “Salamin” (Mirror), Ibarra discovers the true circumstances of his father’s death and the manner of his father’s burial, both the handiwork of of Padre Damaso. Sisa’s character is introduced in “Awit” (Song) when theguardia civil(constable) accost and force her to reveal the whereabouts of her children. After, Ibarra and Maria Clara have the chance to meet and confirm their love for each other, exchanging symbols of their commitment.

In “Laro” (Game), the novel’s main plot and conflicts play out as Ibarra receives news that his project to build a school was approved. Elias appears and warns Ibarra about a plot to kill him. In this section, Sisa then begins her descent into insanity, Padre Salvi shows his lustful desires for Maria Clara, and Damaso’s corrupt ways are exposed. The scene ends with Ibarra threatening Damaso with a knife. In “Palabas” (Show), Ibarra is excommunicated by the church, amid the annual town festivities. Part of the festivities is the presentation of a show, a balletic respite with the Princesa’s technical exhibitions. Later, Salvi extracts a sample evidence of Ibarra’s handwriting to seal his doom in exchange for information on the identity of Maria Clara’s real father. Then events and truths unfold in a dance that mimics the chess game, which in the novel is played by Ibarra and Don Filipo. After all these events, Ibarra and Maria Clara get together again in the pas de deux, “Halik” (The Kiss). Finally, in“Agos” (Current), Elias and Sisa succumb to death, and Ibarra symbolically becomes Simoun in another imagined scene on a boat. To condense the 64-chapter novel into eight contemporary ballet scenes was a feat in itself. The predominant feel of the dance was contemplative.

In 2011, BP toured Crisostomo Ibarra in Singapore where it received a standing ovation, and in Vigan through a commission by the Office of the Government of Ilocos. That same year, BP 2 also performed the ballet in local schools and universities in Tuguegarao, Manila, Bacolod, Dumaguete, Bukidnon, and Cagayan de Oro. In 2012, it had its second run at the CCP Little Theater to celebrate Rizal’s Sesquicentennial. “Halik,” the pas de deux, was part of the company’s repertoire when it toured the United States in 2014 and when it joined the 2015 Asia Pacific Dance Festival held at the University of Hawaii.

Crisostomo Ibarra won the Outstanding Dance Production award at the 2010 Gawad Buhay Awards, as well as awards for Cordero, Carissa Adea, and Gabriel.Written by Regina Angelica Bautista

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history
text:
1988. Moderndance in one act. Choreography and costume design, AgnesLocsin ; scenario, AlSantos; music, Toto Gentica; Lighting design, Tony Esteban Jr; set design, Alvin Vega. Dancers: Wendy Panganiban (Monster), Jeng Halili (Maternal Leader), Ballet Philippines dancers, PhilippineEducationalTheaterAssociation Kalinangan Ensemble. Premiered by BalletPhilippines in Female Moves ( CCP Choreographers’ Showcase ) on 30 Oct 1988 at the Main Theater, now the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, of the Cultural Center of the Philippines.

The one-act ballet interprets the 1988 solar eclipse that plunged Davao and the country into overpowering darkness: as the mythological monster eating up the life-giving sun, and as the terror and violence reigning in southern Mindanao. The ballet starts starkly yet quietly with severely stooped figures dragging themselves on and off open platforms at various heights. The dancers seem to be led by a central leader or a suffering madonna. They all pound the ground with increasing speed and intensity. Then the monster, resembling both a blazing sun and a dragon, rises from the orchestra audience section and draws all forces and attention to herself. A black cloud of cloth blankets the people on stage. Then walk-on people from the streets get mobbed, liquidated, drowned, and devoured by the large, swirling vortex of darkness that the cloth has become. Eventually, the dancers under the black cloth create a murky maelstrom that envelopes the punching, kicking monster. They carry off the struggling monster into the wings. The eclipse ends, and placidity returns.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history

photos.photodesc: Darangen ni Bantugen, Philippine Ballet Theatre, CCP, Manila, 2008 (Samantha Lee)

text:
(The Epic Song of Bantugen). 2008. Contemporary ballet in two acts. Choreography, Gener Caringal and Ronilo Jaynario; music, Jesse Lucas; libretto, Ma. Lourdes Sanchez, based on the Maranao epic, Darangen; set and costume design, Salvador Bernal;lighting design, Jonjon Villareal; special effects designer (for second CCP staging), Andrei Roslovtsev. Premiered by Philippine Ballet Theatre on 14 May 2008 at the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). Dancers: Jared Tan and Marvin Ryan Arizo (Prinsipe Bantugen / Magali), Faye Abigail Tan (Diwata), Katherine Trofeo and Maxine Sy (Prinsesa Datimbang), Bianca Trocino and Pearl Angeli Diamante (Prinsesa Magimar), Joan Geraldine Ayap and Joni Galeste (Bird), Peter San Juan (Mabaning), Joel Matias (Datu Madali), Stephen Cañete (Datu Miskoyaw), Anatoly Panassiukov (Angel of Death).

Darangen ni Bantugen was commissioned by the Filipino Heritage Festival to highlight the National Heritage Month in May 2008. It was performed in the cities of Manila, Makati, Las Piñas, Marikina, Pasay, and Quezon City, and in the provinces of Bulacan and Nueva Ecija. In Oct 2008, it was performed at the 10th Asian Art Festival, in two cities in China. In May 2009, it toured the Visayas, particularly Cebu, Iloilo, Dumaguete, Victorias, Antique, and Roxas, then was staged at the CCP again on 10-12 Jul 2009. The Darangen, or Maranao epic song, was declared in 2005 as one of the world’s masterpieces of the Oral and Intangible Heritages of Humanity by the United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization. Composed of 17 cycles, the verses are chanted by Maranao elders, telling the history of the Maranao people, with the Prince Bantugen as a heroic ideal. The ballet is based on stories inspired by the epic, written by Sanchez and E. Arsenio Manuel. Lucas’s music uses indigenous wind and percussion instruments and prerecorded epic chants, featuring the musicians of the Philippine Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe. In restagings of the ballet, live percussion and chanting are performed along with the recorded music. Bernal’s grand designs for the ballet reflect the rich traditions of Maranao tapestry and culture, hinting at a royal opulence. The costumes maintained the traditional Maranao silhouettes of dress without constricting the dance.

The ballet opens with the arrival of Prinsesa Magimar at the Kingdom of Bumbaran, where she is to wed Datu Madali. However, she is attracted to the king’s younger brother, Bantugen. When Magali discovers the flirtation, he banishes Bantugen from the kingdom. A vision of another princess in a faraway land comes to the desolate prince, who then decides to make the journey to find her. As he travels alone, he encounters and overcomes vicious elemental forces: fire, earth, wind, and water. Although he survives these elements, the battles take a toll on his body and he calls for the help of adiwata(guardian spirit), his spirit protector. With the help of the other diwata, Bantugen is transported to the Kingdom between the Two Seas, home of Prinsesa Datimbang, the princess in Bantugen’s vision. While a healer tries to resuscitate the prince, the Angel of Death arrives and captures Bantugen’s soul. His pet bird then arrives, looking for her master, and finding him, requests Datimbang to bring his body back to Bumbaran.

Act 2 opens with the arrival of Bantugen’s body at Bumbaran. Members of the court are stricken with grief, prompting Datu Madali to forgive his late brother. The warriors Magali and Mabaning, Bantugen’s closest friends, ask permission to seek Bantugen’s soul in the Skyworld, to which they are led by the bird. The Angel of Death holds court over all the souls he has collected, but he is still lonely. Mabaning dresses up as a woman to entice the Angel of Death, and demands flowers for which the Angel leaves his court to pick some on earth. In his absence, the friends and the bird successfully free Bantugen’s soul from the Skyworld. Back at Bumbaran, the kingdom is under attack from Datu Miskoyaw who had decided that Bumbaran would be easy to conquer after Bantugen’s death. At the height of the battle, Bantugen’s soul is restored and he triumphantly defends the kingdom. The ballet ends with Bantugen’s wedding to Datimbang.

Darangen ni Bantugen is not structured as a typical classical ballet with divertissements and grandpas de deux, although the ballerinas perform onpointes, and the choreography has its foundations in ballet, stylized with Maranao folk dance gestures and flexions. The choreography also uses a lot of bamboo poles, alluding to the singkil but without clashing the poles together. Instead, they are used to carry Magimar onto the stage, similar to how the singkil princess enters in later versions of the folk dance, and also to form the Earth elemental monster that attacks Bantugen in Act 1. In place of divertissements, there are several segments that feature corps de ballet work: the dance of the maidens and warriors to back up Magimar’s flirtation with Bantugen, the dance of the diwata who dote on the injured prince, and the dance of the souls in the Skyworld. There are virtuosic solos for Bantugen and the Bird, while Bantugen performs a romantic pas de deux, each with Magimar and Datimbang. One of the highlights of the ballet is Mabaning’s seduction dance for the Angel of Death, executed by Peter San Juan, skillfully disguised in amalong(tubular cloth or garment).Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history

photos.photodesc: Darna, Ballet Philippines, CCP, Manila, 2003 (Ballet Philippines Collection)

text:
2003. Modern ballet in two acts. Choreography, Denisa Reyes and Alden Lugnasin; book, lyrics, and stage direction, Chris Millado; music, Jesse Lucas; beats and atmospherics, Malek Lopez and Noel de Brackinghe; sound design, Willy Munji; aerial movement, Gavin Robins; rigging consultant, Alex Fernando and Thumbie Remigio; lighting design, Shoko Matsumoto; technical director, Gerry Fernandez; costume design, Liz Batoctoy; set design, Boni Juan. Premiered by Ballet Philippines (BP) on 1 Aug 2003, at the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, Cultural Center of the Philippines. Cast: Christine Crame (Darna), Chin-chin Gutierrez / Tex Ordoñez (Valentina), Kris-Belle Paclibar, Mica Bernas, Carissa Adea, Hanedy Sala, Samantha Aviñante, Ruben de Dios, Clark Rambuyon, Irish Abejero, Jojo Mamangun, Myra Beltran, Roeder Camañag, Mio Infante, Raul Montessa, Jay Españo, Roy Rollada, Filomar Tariao, Tim Yap, JM Rodriguez, and the artists of BP.

Denisa Reyes’s Darna is a multimedia superhero spectacle, with elaborate flying fight scenes, backdrops of comic book pages, and a club disc jockey as narrator inciting audience participation to make the beloved Filipina comic book superhero come to life. In Act 1, Chris Millado’s libretto establishes the Narda-Tina animosity from their childhood, as well as the realization of their destinies to become Darna and Valentina, respectively. Darna’s power is a legacy handed down through generations among the women in Narda’s family. Her lola passes down the magic stone to her and she turns into the crime-fighting superhero known for the legendary cry, “Ding!Ang bato!” (Ding, the stone!). After Darna saves her town from volcanic destruction, she becomes a beloved figure and attains celebrity status that even politicians want photo opportunities with her. Valentina’s hair of snakes is also an enchantment, but one that the young Tina called upon herself. Valentina sings songs of loneliness and wrath and Darna becomes popular and moves to the city to pursue her career of saving the day. Act 1 ends with Valentina kidnapping Narda’s romantic interest, Arman.

In Act 2, Valentina enchants Arman to make him dependent on her so he backs away when Darna tries to save him. She reveals herself as Narda, to show “Ang Tunay na Ako” (My True Self), but Valentina takes advantage of this and steals the stone, swallows it, but turns into amanananggal, a segmenting ghoul whose upper body can fly. Valentina then becomes a parody of Darna, and is called Darna Kuno.Valentina then puts a spell on the entire town, placing the people under her power, and leading them into a portal of hell. Powerless, Narda is also affected, but her brother Ding tries to snap her out of the spell. Lola returns to teach Narda that she does not need the magic stone to be powerful because she must find the power within herself. Thus, Narda turns into Darna without the stone, and engages in a flying fight scene with Valentina. The latter takes the form of a serpent, but is still defeated by Darna, who also vanquishes Valentina’s army of snake men. The town declares a Darna day, and all celebrate in a techno-infused finale.

The production was successful in placing BP on the popular culture map but the dancing took a back seat in favor of the multimedia elements of the production. Technical problems prevented better choreography for the heroine, although her flying prowess was still a sight to behold. Christine Crame, who played Darna, became a familiar face to many Filipinos because of her repeated media exposure. Her face would be Darna to many people, until Angel Locsin played the role in a telenovela only a year later, in 2004. Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history

photos.photodesc: Diablos, PETA, Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, 1989 (PETA Library and Archives)

text:
(Demons). 1989. Moderndance and experimental dance drama in two acts; choreography and direction, DenisaReyes ; original script, AlSantos; concept for dance by Denisa Reyes, Al Santos, and RodyVera; musical direction, LutgardoLabad, RonnieQuesada, LucienLetaba, Vincent de Jesus, Linus Sto. Tomas, LouiePascasio; lighting design, SoxyTopacio; set and costume design, SalvadorBernal. Premiered by PhilippineEducationalTheaterAssociation (PETA) and Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) on 14 Apr 1989 at Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Fort Santiago, Manila. Cast: Chie Concepcion (Suwana), Jojo Atienza (Minokawa), Melvin Lee (Mao), PETA Kalinangan Ensemble.

Based on a Bagobo folktale, Diablos is a modern ballet and experimental dance drama in two acts, which makes powerful statements about the people’s struggle for the preservation of life versus the indiscriminate use of arms and nuclear power. The story is about Suwana, a woman about to give birth, who lives in a Bagobo town where people are suffering the ravages of war. The people believe that her child will save the enchanted land from the dark spell that is to be sown by the evil bird Minokawa. Foreseeing the end of his mystic powers over the people, Mao, thebabaylan(shaman), is overcome with jealousy. He invokes the spirit of Minokawa to conjure a bloody plan to kill the unborn children of the tribe. Through deception, Mao coerces the people to offer a mass sacrifice in preparation for the coming darkness or eclipse. Suwana escapes from the mass abortion and flees to the dark forest, coming into the care of the old Diwata. She is given a burning stone, a chain of bells, and a flock of birds to help fight the evil bird. In the final scene, the pregnant Suwana confronts Minokawa. She undergoes labor in the midst of the battle but the people protect her from the evil monster. The baby is born and Minokawa is vanquished. The sun reappears and the whole town celebrates.

Diablos as originally envisioned by Santos is a symbolic drama of rituals that are still a central element among most of Asia’s folk and traditional theater forms. Reyes integrated these Asian elements with her style of Western improvisational dance. Reconceptualizing her spatial designs of circles, diagonals, and angles to suit the unconventional structure of the open-air T-shaped stage in the ruins of an old Spanish fort, and working closely with artists who were limited in dance technique but brimming with creative energy, she evolved methods of using props, like bamboos, in ways that were innovative and visually stimulating. The PETA pool of musicians expanded and adopted their musical language to the styles and concepts of the choreographer. For Suwana’s crusade, they used melodies drawn from the musical cultures of Mindanao; for Minokawa’s nuclear aggression, they explored inorganic sounds and electronic synthesizers.Written by Edna Vida

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history

photos.photodesc: Dugso, CCP Dance Workshop Company, CCP, Manila, 1972 (Rudy Vidad, Ballet Philippines Collection)

text:
1972. Moderndance in one act. Choreography, AliceReyes ; music, RamonP.Santos; lighting design, TeodoroHilado; set design, RayAlbano; costume design, Marcella Lopez. Premiered by the CCP Dance Workshop Company, later known as BalletPhilippines, on 14 Oct 1972 at the Main Theater, subsequently named Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, of the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP). Dancers: GenerCaringal (High Priest), EnricoLabayen (Young Man), FranklinBobadilla (Rival), Irma Bringas (Young Girl), JoyCoronel and TonyFabella (Girl’s Parents), Marose Estella and Jose Antonio (Boy’s Parents), DenisaReyes, Florence Perez, EdnaVida, ElizabethRoxas, Cynthia Salang, Arlene de Guzman, Ronnie Leonardo, Max Luna, Romy Go (Members of the Tribe). In succeeding performances: lighting design, KatschS.J.Catoy, and later, Alex de Guzman; costume design, SalvadorBernal.

This modern ballet was inspired by the sacred dances that mark the turning points of tribal life among the Bukidnon of Mindanao. It depicts the initiation ritual presided over by thebabaylan(shaman) which marks a young man’s ascendance to manhood, courtship, and marriage. The dance culminates in an offering. All movements were choreographed to Ramon P. Santos’s music titled Dingding ngaDiyawa.Like many of his other works, Santos’s compositions are in the avant-garde idiom using Philippine folk material.

Being one of the early works that merged tribal and modern dance movements, Reyes’s Dugso is a source of inspiration for choreographers involved in the search for a uniquely Filipino dance form.Written by Edna Vida

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history

photos.photodesc: Encantada, Ballet Philippines, CCP, Manila, 1992 (Ballet Philippines Collection)

text:
(Enchantress). 1992. Modern ethnic dance in two acts. Choreography, AgnesLocsin ; libretto, AlSantos; music, JoeyAyala at ang Bagong Lumad; lighting design, TeodoroHilado; costume and set design, SalvadorBernal. Premiered by BalletPhilippines on 20 Feb 1992 at the Tanghalang NicanorAbelardo, Cultural Center of the Philippines. Dancers: CecileSicangco (Encantada); Joey Ayala (Estranjero), alternated by Gerald Mercado; Wendy Panganiban (Babaylan); Jinn Ibarrola, alternated by Melvin Martinez; Paul Morales and Lee Wen Cheng (Priests).

A sovereign spirit called Encantada rules over hills and dales, mountains, and streams. Upland, her medium is the Babaylan, a female shaman who leads a group of women called Kababaihan in a trance dance. This is expressive of and a call to nature, earthy and supplicative. In the lowlands, the converted Christians or Taongbayan worship an icon of the Virgin Mary, led by threefrailes(friars) who move in studied and gnarled piety. The people seem repressed to truly express their feelings.

Meanwhile, anindio(Christianized native)called Estranjero, rebelling against the oppression of the people, steals the jewelled icon and brings it to the mountains. Angered, the priests send out theguardias civiles(constables) in pursuit. The guards run after him like acrobatic monkeys. Estranjero is wounded, but is saved by the Encantada who descends from a mountain, and by the Kababaihan. Led by the Babaylan, they heal and baptize him. They all dance a celebration, as though purifying him and fructifying nature. Estranjero sings about the power of thediwata(guardian spirit)in “Biyaya ng Lupa” (Earth’s Blessings). The holy image is stripped naked, now pristine looking like the Encantada, and is passed around with reverence, in jubilation.

In Act 2, the priests send out the guards on a headhunt. Many heads roll or fly about. Estranjero himself is shot. Encantada grieves as the women gird for vengeance. A fight ensues where they are raped by the guards, symbolic of and paralleled by the rape of nature, which is personified by Kalikasan. The forest and pagan altars are burned as the priests reclaim the holy image. Overwhelmed, Encantada sheds tears enacted by the Babaylan, Kababaihan, and Kalikasan with their storm-tossed and wavelike bodies. This flood cleanses the mountains but devastates the lowlands and the cathedral. The waves bring back the holy icon to the Encantada, as though an image of herself is restored. Another ritual brings men and women together in joyful exultation and social harmony, implying the restoration of nature’s balance and the spirits’ appeasement.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history

photos.photodesc: Ensalada, Ballet Philippines, CCP, Manila, 1981 (Salvador F. Bernal Collection)

text:
(Salad). 1981. A suite of modern dances. Choreography, EdnaVida ; music, RyanCayabyab; lighting design, MoninoDuque; set and costume design, SalvadorBernal. Premiered by BalletPhilippines on 13 Nov 1981 at the Main Theater, now the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, of the Cultural Center of the Philippines. Dancers: Ester Rimpos, Malu Rivera, CecileSicangco, Gina Mariano, Tina Fargas, HazelSabas, Juliet Molina, Perry Sevidal, Florence Perez, BrandoMiranda, Ramon Victoria, Edward Malagkit, Jinn Ibarrola.

Ensalada is a group of dances in modern ballet interpreting the moods and temperament of four Filipino songs: “Limang-dipang Tao” (Five Armstretches), “BakyaMoNeneng” (Your Wooden Clogs, Neneng), “Tsismis” (Gossip), and “Mamang Kutsero” (Mr Rig Driver). Avoiding a literal interpretation of the lyrics, Vida utilized and drew inspiration from the common, everyday movements of typical Filipinos, like jogging, playing basketball, fanning oneself with ananahawfan, and the wriggling motions of a favorite Filipino pastime,kiliti(tickle). Because of its popular appeal, Ensalada has been performed in school gymnasia, town plazas, market halls, and hospital conference rooms during Ballet Philippines’ various local engagements, tours, and lecture-demonstrations.Written by Edna Vida

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history

photos.photodesc: Exultations, Dance Theater Philippines, Intramuros, Manila, 1984 (CCP Collection)

text:
1984. Modern ballet in one scene. Scenario and choreography, Basilio ; music, NicanorS.Abelardo’s SinfoniettaforStrings; costume design, ArturoCruz and Basilio. Premiered by DanceTheaterPhilippines on the occasion of Nicanor Abelardo’s 50th death anniversary on 15 Dec 1984 at Puerta Real, Intramuros, Manila. Dancers: Regina Debuque and Jonathan Terry (Central couple); Susan Atizado and Roberto Clemente, Rose Miranda and Eugene de los Santos (Other Couples).

Lines from the American poet Emily Dickinson helped generate the ballet: “Exultation floods me. I cannot find my channel / the creek turns sea at thought of thee.” The dance structure evolved from the way relationships among six dancers could be changed and interchanged in love-like partnerings, gestures, and movements.

In silence and to their own time, three women and three men walk forward and backward to the front. As they complete a line, the music wells up and they link and unlink among themselves. They make similar movements, but in ever changing relations and directions. With the music’s rise and fall, they indicate their separate or joint feelings. The three women are left alone to dance out their fears and longings, moving and gesturing together with slight variations. As in a trance, two of the men walk in and steal away two of the women, leaving the third and central woman alone. Soon she is joined by the central man who reaches out for her as she does for him. There are reservations, even resistance, until they quietly walk off together.

The two earlier couples return and link up in changing pairings. But the two men leave. The two abandoned women dance together. They are joined by the central man who dances with each of them in turn, and all three go off none too happily together. As they leave, the two men return with the central woman. She throws herself at each of them, until one of them drags her away. The man drops to the ground. In a line, the three women now glide in together, as the three men congenially circle behind them. They pair up, reach out, even cry, for each other. As the music wells up again to a dramatic coda, they mark stark partnerings. Along a multilevel diagonal line, they fix their indefinite relationships as the darkening lights catch them in silhouettes.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history
text:
1954. Modern ballet in four movements. Choreography, RobertaCassell (1st movement) and RicardoCassell (2nd, 3rd, and 4th movements); music, Peter Ilyich Tchaikovsky; lighting design, Alan M. Mittelsdorf and Fernando R. Nicolas; set design, Pancho Uytiepo; costume design, Mitos Sison. Premiered by StudioDanceGroup in Mar 1954 at the University of the Philippines, Diliman, Quezon City. Dancers: Ma. Luisa Abeto, Greta Monserrat Aguilar, Cristina Carrion, Elizabeth Guasch, MercyLauchengco, Mitos Sison, and Pancho Uytiepo.

In four movements, the ballet interprets the mood of the Tchaikovsky music in dance form. The style is abstract. The lonely motto prevalent in each of the four movements is tempered at the end with a calm and almost religious joy.

In the Philippines, it exemplifies the symphonic ballets espoused by Leonide Massine, who himself has done a version (in parts Action, Passion, Frivolity, and War) called Les Presages which was performed by Col de Basil Original Ballet Russe in 1933 in Monte Carlo. Written by R. Cassell and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

article_title: Filipinescas: Philippine Life, Legend and Lore in Dance
description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history

photos.photodesc: Leonor Orosa-Goquingco’s Filipinescas, Paris, 1961 (CCP Collection)

text:
1961. Modern ballet in five scenes. Choreography, LeonorOrosa-Goquingco ; music, Marina Leyran, Zenas Reyes, Luisa Torres, and Leonor Orosa-Goquingco; directed and produced by Leonor Orosa-Goquingco on 8 Jun 1961 at the Theatre du Vieux Colombier, Paris.

Filipinescas includes the first choreography about the legends of creation; of Philippine Lenten and Easter practices which include thepabasa(chanting of thepasyon),antipos,salubong(Easter Sunday meeting of Christ and the Virgin), theprusisyon(procession); the first duel; the first trading scene; the first wedding; the first native fiesta; native games, e.g.,palocebo(climbing a greasy pole),juego de prenda(looking for the missing bird),juego de anillo(game of rings), sipa(hopscotch);and Filipinescas ’signature dance—thesabong(cockfight)—the first graphic depiction of cockfight as a sport in a realistic setting, complete with a grand entrance of cocks,kristo(person who takes bets), and a rowdy group of bettors.

The individual folkloric pieces which comprise the whole ballet include “Eons Ago: The Legends of the Creation;” “Long, Long Ago: Tribal Story,” the first Philippine folkloric ballet woven around the death of a tribal warrior; and “Long Ago,” which divides into “Morolandia I” and “Morolandia II.” The first “Morolandia” features fishers and children at the beach, the arrival of avinta(boat), the fervid activity of the barter, and a duel of two prince-brothers over a beautiful princess. The second one shows a wedding ceremony and a court celebration. “Morolandia I” and “II” incorporate creative interpretations of ethnic dances found in the south. The other folkloric pieces are “The Arrival of the Spaniards and the First Conversion in the Philippines;” “Yesterday: Cuadros Filipinos,” celebrating native Lenten and Easter traditions in dance; “Today” (and a provision of the future): “The Bird and the Planters.” The latter is noted for being the first to weave the rice-planting cycle—from the planting and weeding to the threshing, pounding and winnowing of rice, and a new interpretation of the tinikling into a continuous, artistic whole.

Described as an epic saga, a combination of history, legend, and tradition, Filipinescas is a brilliant, unforgettable rebirth of Philippine cultural history and of the history and spirit of the Filipino people. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history

photos.photodesc: Filipino Komiks, Philippine Ballet Theatre, CCP, Manila, 1993 (Liza Delafuente-Castañeda Collection)

text:
(Filipino Comics). 1993. Story ballet in three acts. Choreography and libretto based on Mars Ravelo’s works, Gener Caringal; music, Chino Toledo; lighting design, Eric Cruz; costume and set design, Arturo Cruz; costume execution, Arturo Cruz and Tony Fabella and hand painted by Manny Molina. Premiered by Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT) on 22 Apr 1993 at the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, Cultural Center of the Philippines. Dancers: Lisa Macuja (Darna and Narda), Melanie Motus (Valentina), Osias Barroso Jr (Dario), Maritoni Rufino (Dyesebel), Noreen Ostrea (Bangenge), Katrina Santos (Banak), Ana Marie Tirol (Maya Maya), Cathy Lee (Rita Pagsinghot), Robert Policarpio (Ipe), and the PBT.

PBT’s season programming in the early 1990s consisted mostly of full-length classical ballets with one mixed bill concert titled Celebration of Philippine Ballets,a combinationof new and old choreographies from the members of its artistic council. However, in 1993, the company presented a full-length Filipino ballet, showcasing members of the company as popular comic book characters, led by Lisa Macuja as Darna/Narda and Melanie Motus as Narda’s former childhood friend and Darna’s nemesis, the snake-haired Valentina. Choreographed by Gener Caringal, the ballet featured dazzling set effects like Darna flying across the stage in an invisible harness.

The first act, which establishes the narrative of the story, has the envious antagonist Valentina chasing Narda, the newly crowned Queen of the Fiesta and heroine, all the way to the sea where she has no choice but to jump in. She is saved and aided by Dyesebel, who guides her to the enchanted octopus, Bangenge, from whom they retrieve theagimator magic stone that transforms Narda into a superhero. Bangenge is strapped to yards of black cloth representing her tentacles and moves mainly her upper body as she manipulates the black cloth.

The second act, one of the highlights of the performance, is set underwater with nimble mermaids and mermen led by none other than the most famous mermaid of Philippine folklore, Dyesebel. This section is a divertissement from the story, showcasing the company dancers defying mermaid laws as they execute arabesques underwater. Most of the movements are composed of traveling jumps to simulate the effect of swimming mermaids.

The third act opens with the villainous Valentina and her coterie of snake men, trying to seduce the unwitting Dario. He is eventually saved by the flying Darna who has a fight scene with Valentina. The ballet culminates in a Santacruzan-style wedding for Narda and Dario.

As a fun adventure ballet that embodied popular Philippine culture, Filipino Komiks received extensive media mileage and was well-attended and applauded by audiences. However, it was not quite critically celebrated; there were comments on the unnecessary length of certain sections that resulted in the campiness of the final scene. It was never restaged, perhaps because of the elaborate sets and expensive flying equipment. Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history

photos.photodesc: For the Gods, Ballet Philippines, CCP, Manila, 1985 (Ballet Philippines Collection)

text:
1985. Moderndance in one act. Choreography, DenisaReyes; music, Fabian Obispo; lighting design, KatschS.J.Catoy; costume design, SalvadorBernal. Premiered by BalletPhilippines on 17 Oct 1985 at the Main Theater, now the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, of the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP). Dancers: Edna Vida, Sofia Zobel, Tina Fargas, Gina Katigbak, Melissa Cuachon, Nicole Gaston.

This modern ballet was inspired by thedugso,a ritual dance of the Bukidnon of Mindanao, performed to give thanks to the gods for the harvest. The ritual involves the basic aspects of life: religiosity, birth, pain, freedom, and death. It starts with five women behind a central figure, a woman in the throes of childbirth. As in the dugso, they hold hands and stomp their feet in rhythmic progression. The dance progresses from the ritualistic and staid rhythmic patterns of the feet into more intricate and stylized movements involving the whole body, which conjure varied images of fertility. Towards the end of the dance, the woman joins the other women, her union with divinity affirmed with the ritual of birth and sacrifice.

In For The Gods,Reyes depicts Western dance movements as radiant and extensive while those of the Eastern dance are intensive. The contrast between sculptured images sweeping across the floor and the ritualistic beginning that is concentrated in center stage clearly define the influence of both cultures on the choreographer.

For TheGods was first presented in Apr 1984 at the Larry Richardson Dance Gallery in New York during a concert titled Neo-Filipino.In Manila, it was featured in Hiyas, a festival of original Filipino works that highlighted the 1985 CCP Annual Philippine Music Festival. Written by Edna Vida

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history

photos.photodesc: Giri, TEAM Dance Studio, CCP, Manila, 2004 (Francis Reyes, photo courtesy of Joelle Jacinto)

text:
(Strut). 2004. Contemporary dance in two sections. Choreography and lighting design, Eli Jacinto ; music, Pinikpikan; costume design, Joan Jacinto. Premiered by TEAM Dance Studio at the Cultural Center of the Philippines’ (CCP) Ballet Fest, Folk Arts Theater, CCP Complex, 2004. Dancers: Lucas Jacinto, Jacqui Jacinto, Joelle Jacinto, Sol Ogatis and Vanessa Terrado. Succeeding stagings were performed by Erica Marquez-Jacinto, Nina Sayoc, Frances Canto, Ika Katalbas, and Irene Canto.

Giri takes elements from indigenous Filipino dances and animal movements and combines these with abstract modern dance movements. Inspired by the behavior of roosters and chickens in the farmyard, the work depicts courtship drawn from folk dances that imitate birds. The title itself is taken from the children’s folk song, “Sitsiritsit,” specifically the line, “Ang babae sa lansangan, kung gumiri’y parang tandang” (“The lady on the street, she struts like a rooster”)

The dance opens with a male dancer who struts in circles, flapping his arms and executing steps very similar to those found in the Ifugao dance. Meanwhile a female dancer does a promenade en attitude at the other downstage corner. In between them are the rest of the female ensemble performing parallel tortillier steps in a diagonal line, waving their arms above them with hands flexed. This section contrasts the Filipino male’s vigor with the female’s demureness. The dance, however, does not depict the female as subordinate to the male. Sections in the dance display the women’s physical strength which matches the male’s cocky prancing to impress them. The first version of Giri ended with a man lifting a woman overhead to declare his choice. Later, Jacinto felt that women were not meant to be trophies to be won, and thus changed the ending where all of them finished in assertive poses, while the man crumpled, holding his head as if in defeat.

Jacinto was acknowledged for showing the difference between male and female in folk movements when the work premiered at the 2004 National Folk Dance Conference at the Folk Arts Theater. Giri was repeated several times in a short version performed at a Dance Development Conference in Nanning, China, in 2005, and at the 7th DLSU Arts Congress at the De La Salle University in 2014. Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history

photos.photodesc: Giselle, Philippine Ballet Theatre, CCP, Manila, 1988 (CCP Collection)

text:
1841. Classical ballet in two acts. Choreography, Jean Coralli and Jules Perrot, revised by Marius Petipa in 1884; scenario, Theophile Gautier and Vernoy de St. George, after Heinrich Heine. Premiered on 28 Jun 1841 at Theatre de l’Academie Royale de Musique, Paris. Dancers: Carlotta Grisi, Lucien Petipa, Jean Coralli, and Adele Dumilatre. Filipino Giselles: Pacita Madrigal-Warns, MaureenTiongco, FelicitasLayag-Radaic, Purita Asiniero, MaribelAboitiz, ManiyaBarredo, EsterRimpos, AnnaVilladolid, LisaMacuja, CecileSicangco, ToniLopezGonzalez, and Gina Katigbak.

This ballet in two acts centers on Giselle, a Rhine Valley maiden deceived in love by Duke Albrecht. When Giselle discovers Albrecht’s true station and engagement to Duchess Bathilde, she dies of a broken heart. Like other maidens who died before their wedding, Giselle is turned into awili, a female spirit of the glades and vales who lures men to dance to their death. She is initiated as a wili by their queen, Myrtha. The wilis force Giselle’s peasant suitor, Hilarion, to dance to his death. They would have done the same to Albrecht but for Giselle’s pleas and the timely coming of the dawn when the wilis must disperse or return to their graves. With a heavy heart, Albrecht returns to his society and laments the fate to which he had unwittingly sent the innocent Giselle.

Of the ballet classics, Giselle has been performed the most in the Philippines. It was first staged in the Philippines by RicardoCassell in 1950 for the Manila Ballet Academy, with Pacita Madrigal as Giselle and BenjaminVillanuevaReyes as Albrecht. It was restaged by AnitaKane in 1955 with Maureen Tiongco and Antonio Tarrosa in the lead roles, and Carmencita Barredo as Myrtha. Felicitas Layag-Radaic was Kane’s other Giselle. In Cebu, FeSala-Villarica staged the ballet in 1956 for her Studio of Ballet Arts, with Purita Asiniero, Nene Cui, and Emma Sanchez. In 1961, at the UP Theater, Diliman, Quezon City, SonyLopez-Gonzalez staged the ballet, starring Maribel Aboitiz, EddieElejar, and Amelia Garcia. For the Manila Metropolitan Opera and Ballet Association, Lopez-Gonzalez staged Act 2 in 1963 at the Rizal Theater for Nora Kovatch, Istvan Rabovsky, and Alicia Parham. In 1965 Le Grand Ballet Classique de France performed the work at the Rizal Theater, with Liane Dayde and Nina Vyroubova as Giselle, Juan Giuliano and Michel Bruel as Albrecht, and Maina Gielgud as Myrtha. In 1973, the Kirov Ballet performed Act 2 at the Cultural Center of the Philippines, with Xenia Ter-Stepanova and Anatoly Nisnievitch. In 1976, IndayGaston-Mañosa and Lopez-Gonzalez staged Giselle for the Ballet Federation of the Philippines, with Maniya Barredo, Burton Taylor, Nida Onglengco, and VellaDamian.

Several Philippine productions followed. Three were from BalletPhilippines: in 1982, by AliceReyes, with Yoko Morishita, Ester Rimpos, NonoyFroilan, Robert Medina, EdnaVida, and Gina Mariano; in 1986, by WilliamMorgan, with Anna Villadolid, Cecile Sicangco, Froilan, BrandoMiranda, and Mercedes Mañago; in 1991, by Froilan, with Sicangco, Toni Lopez Gonzalez, Gina Katigbak, Julio Bocca, Ou Lu, Brando Miranda, HazelSabas, and Sofia Zobel.

In 1983, Villadolid danced Giselle with ManilaMetropolisBallet with LutherPerez and Rebecca Rodriguez. In 1986, Act 2 of the ballet was performed at the Manila Metropolitan Theater: first with Lopez Gonzales and RupertAcuña, and second, with Lisa Macuja (a noted Giselle in the former Union of Soviet Socialist Republics) and Froilan; both performances featured Mara Eileen Viado as Myrtha. In 1988, DanceTheaterPhilippines staged Giselle with Macuja, Froilan, Sabas, and Angela del Pilar at the Meralco Theater. The same production was staged later in the same year for PhilippineBalletTheatre with Macuja, Vivencio Samblaceño, and Pilar Borromeo—in a special tribute to Anita Kane. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history
text:
1940. Ballet in one act. Choreography, David Lichine; music, Johann Strauss, as arranged by Antal Dorati; costume and set design, Alexandre Benois. Premiered by Col de Basil Original Ballet Russe on 28 Feb 1940 at the Theatre Royal in Sydney, Australia. Dancers: Tatiana Riabouchinska and David Lichine.

RicardoandRobertaCassell restaged their own version in Manila in 1955, following the original story. The students of a girl’s school in Vienna in the mid-1800s meet cadets from a military academy in celebration of the end of the school year. The headmistress keeps the eager girls in order, and an elderly general does the same for his charges, the cadets. But the young people flirt with each other. The cadets and girls dance, while a boy delivers notes between them. Among the featured dances are those for a drummer boy, a young girl in pigtails, an evocative recollection from La Sylphide (a ballet of the period), a turning competition between two girls, a sequence—“Mathematics and Natural History”—which is no longer done, a mazurkabetween the headmistress and the general, which is cut short by the returning boys and girls, and a final “Perpetuum Mobile.” All bid goodbye, but a cadet and a girl sneak back into the ballroom for a kiss, are caught, and sent off by the headmistress.

TonyFabella made his own version, which was premiered by ManilaMetropolis Ballet on 13 Jun 1986 at the Rizal Theater. He set his own order, while keeping much of the story intact. He added the dance of the headmistress and her pupils, a “See No Evil, Hear No Evil, Speak No Evil” dance led by a trio, and an open mazurka between the headmistress and the general with the cadets and the girls. Lead dancers were Joey Villadolid, Maricar Hernandez, Sol Fernandez, Violeta Hizon, Noreen Ostrea, EddieElejar, and James Lopez.

JulieBorromeo set the work for PhilippineBalletTheatre on 16 Sep 1988 at the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP), as a tribute to RicardoCassell. The same plot was followed, but without the La Sylphide pas de deux, and with a novel horse trainer or rider. Lead dancers were OsiasBarroso, Veronica Restituto, LisaMacuja, Raoul Banzon, Elejar, and Lopez.

Reviewing this last version by Borromeo, FelicitasLayag-Radaic said thatGraduationBall was a refreshing, hilarious ballet recalling Ricardo Cassell’s own version and described Elejar’s headmistress as possessing subtle humor and Osias Barroso’s drummer boy performance as a challenging number, rhythmic, fast and precise, with a light and cheery style where he showed his versatility as a dancer. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history
text:
(Adarna Bird). 1970. Modern ballet in one act and three scenes. Choreography and libretto, RemediosdeOteyza and IndayGaston-Mañosa; music, RodolfoS.Cornejo; lighting design, TeodoroHilado; costume and set design, ArturoCruz. Dancers in premiere: EffieNañas / Carmina Gutierrez (Ibong Adarna); Conrad Tiolengco (Don Juan); EricV.Cruz (Don Pedro); June Dalit (Don Diego); Nida Onglengco, VellaDamian, Amelia Yulo-Garcia (princesses); Rene Dimacali (King); and Arturo Cruz (royal physician). Singers: Luzviminda Azarcon, Conchita Casas de Leon. Premiered by the HarirayaDanceCompany on 5 Nov 1970 at the Main Theater, now the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, of the Cultural Center of the Philippines.

The story is told in a purely classical ballet idiom in one act and three scenes, complete with the typical grand pas de deux. Set in Berbania, the story begins with a court scene. The three sons of King Fernando are betrothed to three beautiful princesses. But the king falls ill and the three sons—Pedro, Diego, and Juan—must look for the cure: the Ibong Adarna’s song.

The princes set out on their search. Pedro meets a leper woman, and is unkind to her. He finds the magical tree where the bird roosts, sleeps beneath it, and is turned to stone when the bird sings and sheds a feather on him. Diego also rebuffs the leper and suffers the same fate. Juan, however, shares the last of his bread with the leper, who gives him a potion to overcome the bird’s soporific song. Juan finally captures the creature. His brothers, who awaken, connive to kill him and bring the bird home themselves. But the Adarna refuses to sing until Juan, who is thought dead, returns with the leper. In a grand pas de deux, Juan takes the bird, which now sings. The king revives, and Berbania is restored to peace and harmony.

This production is significant for its use of folkloric material, and because it is the first major attempt to adapt the famouskorido(metrical romance) into dance. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history

photos.photodesc: Igorot, Ballet Philippines, CCP, Manila, 1989 (Rudy Vidad, Ballet Philippines Collection)

text:
1987. Modern ethnic ballet in one act. Choreography, libretto and costume design, Agnes Locsin ; music, LucreciaR.Kasilag; lighting design, Tony Esteban. Premiered by Petit Ballet Theatre in Amsterdam on 9 Nov 1987. Premiered in the Philippines by BalletPhilippines in Female Moves on 30 Sep 1988 at the Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino, CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP). Dancers in Manila premiere: Camille Ordinario, Jean Salas, Jun Mabaquiao, Paul Ocampo, Alla Hioca. Ballet Philippines added the work to its repertoire in 1989.

Igorot, Bagobo,and Encantada all use a choreographic style Locsin calls neo-ethnic. She describes Igorot as a series of Igorot dances translated as a neoclassical ballet. The modern ballet in one act plays up the characteristic birdlike gestures and earthy footwork of the quintessential Cordillera dances. It sets off key figures, like a prayerful woman prostrate at the start of the ballet, a trio in rivalry over a woman, and a priestly female leader. The music keeps on shifting or doubling with voice (chanting) and instruments (gangsaor gong, flute, and bamboo or wooden percussions). The costuming is stylized, with the women wearing G-strings like the men, and traditional wide blankets or narrow scarves..

After some women trace a winding path around the crouched supplicant, the praying woman gradually stands with accented movements and sharp poses. The other women soon return to join her in a file, their feet puncturing the ground with their pointes to the melody and rhythm of asalidummay(folk song in Cordillera).Their knees and feet are earthbound, but their torsos and arms are upright and almost birdlike—dancing in unison to gongs but in various directions. They scrape the ground with their feet or leap like birds in flight. To a chant, they kneel, while a female leader dances with arms carried up, flat and bent. They all dance together, the leader weaving in or leading. Left alone, she simply swings an arm and bounces to amplified bamboo sounds and under an overhead light, as though entranced by the gongs and her own movements. She then leaves.

To powerful gong playing, two men enter, earthbound, yet leaping, crawling, sometimes hopping. The women join them in unison, but go in various directions. Left together, the two men squat, crawl, and jump, their arms in accented flying gestures. A woman enters and one of the men courts her by taking one of her two scarves—symbols of choice. Their dance is a contest to frenetic gongs and bamboo percussion, sometimes to chanting, which sometimes sound like taunting. At the end they separate. The other man reenters and he seems to be the woman’s choice. He takes her remaining scarf. Their dance is more intimate, although it still has the character of a contest. She is lifted a few times, and is finally caught in one of his arms. The other women dance around them, as though approving and celebrating their union.

Igorot is startling in its virtuosity, testing the marriage of the ethnic and the balletic. Classical pointework, supposedly to transcend gravity, is used for attack, punctuating the earth, cutting the air. Arms, rhythm, and energy are as native as the terraces, but virtuosity is pure balletic technique. At midpoint, the tone somehow shifts to modern style, the balletic mode recaptured only in the second pas de deux. A more singular merger could have unified the tone. Nevertheless, choreographic invention and tension are sustained to the end. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history

photos.photodesc: Indios Bravos, Airdance, Quezon City, 2004 (Airdance Collection)

text:
(Brave Natives). 2004. Contemporary dance in three acts. Choreography, Dwight Rodrigazo ; direction, Paul Morales; libretto, Nicolas Pichay and Paul Morales, inspired by Jose Rizal’s “The Song of the Traveler;” music, Bob Aves and Grace Nono, with additional music performed live by Julius Mocorro; lighting design, Shakira Villa; set design, Jet Melencio; costume design and execution, Gino Gonzales. Premiered by Airdance on 26 Feb 2004 at Teatro Aguinaldo, Camp Aguinaldo, Quezon City. Dancers: Dwight Rodrigazo (Pepe), Sharon Brendia (Maria), Paul Morales, Christine Maranan Novales, Lynley Tan, Avel Bautista, Nordic Caraig, Reagan Cornelio, Proceso Gelladuga II.

Indios Bravos was presented by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts and the British Council. It shows the parallel lives of national hero Jose Rizal, and abagong bayani(new hero), the overseas Filipino worker (OFW) in the person of Maria, who travels to Europe and endures loneliness and hardship to offer her family a better life. Act 1, “Ang Paglayag” (Departure), shows Pepe, the humanized figure of Rizal, and Maria sharing the stage as they wake up on the day they leave for Madrid. An ensemble dance depicts travelers either shoving each other in crowds, or restlessly waiting in line at a sea port / airport terminal. They swing around heavy hand-carried luggage. This movement which is the main motif of the dance suggests that traveling outside one’s country to give those left behind a better future is a necessary burden.

Act 2, “Buhay sa Europa”(Life in Europe), shows how the protagonists try to adjust to a European “rhythm” and climate. A video is projected on the cyclorama during the solo of Maria to magnify her loneliness, dejection, and suffering in the unbearable cold climate. Her solo is abruptly interrupted by a ringing phone, and she answers a call from home. Parallel to this incident, Pepe receives a letter sent by his mother who expresses her anxiety over his ambitious pursuit of a better education far from home. Simultaneously, a “live exhibit” of indigenous Filipinos in Madrid in 1887 is reenacted, a precursor of the 1904 St. Louis Exposition featuring Igorot “villages.” The dancers start off as mannequins and perform a stylized Igorot dance, symbolizing how Filipinos were seen as cultural objects. This intimates how Pepe and Maria must deal with the same prejudice through their journeys. Pepe travels throughout Europe, as does Maria who escapes from her abusive employer. Act 2 ends when Maria discovers the statue of Rizal in a park in Germany and, by resting at its feet, finds solace.

Act 3, “Ang Bayan Ay Nasa Puso” (The Moving Homeland), shows Maria and Pepe better adjusted to their European lives in Paris. Pepe and hisilustrado(educated) friends see an American Indian in another live exhibit at a later world exposition. They are inspired to form a loose organization of Indios Bravos, determined to propagate the strength and pride of their countrymen through their writing. This scene is rendered by a powerful ensemble of dancers with canes.

The movement vocabulary in Indios Bravios is from an experimental technique that Rodrigazo was developing at that time he choreographed the work. He called this “pulling technique.” Instead of releasing the limbs from the body to create the dance, the movement continues inward, into the core, lengthening the rest of the body as energy is drawn within. To successfully use this technique in Indios Bravos, Airdance company members took a daily syllabus class which Rodrigazo devised. This technique was kept by Rodrigazo after he retired as artistic director of Airdance and eventually used the name for his new company and school, Dance Pull in Bacolod City.

The riveting ilustrado dance, featuring the ensemble with canes, is often staged by Airdance in mixed bill repertoire performances, sometimes with a mixed-gender cast. Indios Bravos was restaged for the French Spring in Manila in 2005 at OnStage, Greenbelt 1, Makati City, organized by Alliance Française where Rodrigazo reprised his role of Pepe while Nina Hayuma Habulan did Maria. Excerpts were restaged in 2008 at the WiFi Body Festival, with John Philip Martir as Pepe and Marielle Alonzo as Maria. Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history

photos.photodesc: Itim Asu 1719-2009, Dance Forum M. B., Quezon City, 2009 (Gibbs Cadiz)

text:
(Onyx Wolf: 1719-2009). 2009. Contemporary dance in four scenes. Choreography, libretto, and concept for set design, Myra Beltran , based on the play The Onyx Wolf by Virginia R. Moreno; music design by Teresa Barrozo from compositions by Teresa Barrozo, Henryck Gorecki, Joaquin Rodrigo, Ki-Young Kim, Arcangelo Correlli, and Alfred Schnittke, with sound recordings from Filipinas Heritage Library and the archives of the US Library of Congress, as included in the research of Elizabeth Enriquez; visual score by Sherad Anthony Sanchez; associate video direction by Ruelo Lozendo; lighting design by Joseph Mateu; costume design and execution by Carlo Valderrama; graphic design by Don Salubayba. Premiered by Dance Forum M.B. on 26 Nov 2009 at Dance Forum Space, Quezon City. Cast: Marielle Alonzo (Itim Asu), Reagan Cornelio (Gov. Gen. Bustamante),

Myra Beltran, Angela Sebastian, Sarah Maria Samaniego, Chaya Joyce Baris, Marielle Baylocon, Dina Magat, Al Bernard Garcia, Japhet Mari Cabling, Jan Parangat, Erl Emmanuel Sorilla, and Jeiel Hernandez. Succeeding stagings: Melanie Motus as Itim Asu at the Carlos P. Romulo Auditorium in RCBC Plaza Makati on 24 Feb 2010; Ava Maureen Villanueva as Itim Asu and Johnny Amar as Bustamante at Dance Forum Space on 4-5 Mar 2011; and Villanueva and Cornelio at the Media Center, UP College of Mass Communications on 15 Feb 2012. Myra Beltran’s contemporary dance interpretation of Virginia Moreno’s play incorporates dance with drama, text, and multimedia in retelling the assassination of Gov-Gen Bustamante and the creation of Itim Asu as a legend. The play-within-a-play that deals with the Burgos account as an alleged forgery includes Beltran’s own deliberations on “real” events that inform and accompany the work, hence the inclusion of the dates 1719-2009. The dates imply the significance of the Bustamante legend in Philippine history since 1719 and Moreno’s belief that history repeats itself, to which Beltran also subscribes. The multilayering of texts in the choreography echoes the ideas in Moreno’s play, allowing Beltran to incorporate her reading of history. Each restaging of the work shows the historical present by changing the year in the title, such as Itim Asu: 1719-2011 for a 2011 staging in UP College of Mass Communication.

Scene 1 presents the UP Dance Company (UPDC) as the Filipino Youth of Today, the storytellers in a dance rendering of “A la Juventud Filipina” (To the Filipino Youth). The dancers/storytellers lay the ground for the legend of Itim Asu by preparing for a film shoot. This is a contemporary version of Moreno’s play-within-a-play.

Scene 2 shows the shooting of the “play” within the “play,” a presentation of the relationship of Bustamante and his wife Maria, and the oppression of the womenfolk by the friars. The scene is constituted by intensely foreboding images of wailing women, scheming men, all hinting at the violence to come. Bustamante’s death is not portrayed directly. Rather, it is Maria’s grief that allows the audience to assume that he was killed. When Maria transforms into Itim Asu, she dances one last time with her husband’s spirit, expressing a widow’s grief and acceptance. They are joined onstage by the rest of the company, performing the same duet, effectively multiplying the emotions of the principal couple.

Scene 3 plays a voice recording of Beltran expressing her interpretation of the previous scenes. Two men dance in an athletic duet, at first mirroring each other and then eventually conversing. One man is Rizal addressing anotherilustrado(educated), who, in Beltran’s mind, is Luna. Other interpretations consider the second conversant as Burgos, chronicler of Bustamante’s story. The next part of the scene is Beltran’s solo to her own reading of Rizal’s poem “Mi Ultimo Adios.” Her sharp, powerful movements struggle with an invisible force that she successfully conquers. Toward the end, Itim Asu joins her onstage, imbibing Rizal’s strength and resolve.

Scene 4 is a filming of Paulita’s wedding scene from El Filibusterismo, a light scene that turns ominous when repeated at different angles for retakes, which Beltran uses to show how history “rewinds” itself. This scene is taken from Moreno’s play, where a character, alluded to as Macario Sakay, portrays Simon Ibarra and Bustamante in the same play. He is a revolutionary disguised as an actor. An American actor in the cast believes that Sakay the actor has planted a real bomb to throw into the audience, in an attempt to assassinate the American dignitaries coming to see the play. He shoots Sakay the actor. In Beltran’s staging, the dancer portraying Bustamante takes the place of Sakay in the third take of the filming. He is then shot in a scene that refers to the earlier murder. Moreno’s scene depicted the blurring of fiction and reality, in light of Burgos’s account of Bustamante’s story being declared a forgery. But its myth lives on, inspiring revolutionary ideals.

In reaction to the shooting, the character of Itim Asu storms in on a murderous rampage, her fury duplicated by the female ensemble; her struggle and quest for justice are multiplied and her mission becomes that of the masses. This is an articulation of Beltran’s idea that we are all in “the middle of history.” The scene where Bustamante is taken away and killed is blocked from sight, in the same way that Benigno Aquino Jr was escorted out to the side of the airplane to his inevitable death. Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history

photos.photodesc:
Itim Asu, Alice Reyes and Modern Dance Company, CCP, Manila, 1970

(Rudy Vidad, Ballet Philippines Collection)

text:
(Onyx Wolf). 1970. Modern ballet in one act and three scenes. Choreography, AliceReyes ; scene based on VirginiaMoreno’s play TheOnyxWolf; music, AlfredoS.Buenaventura; lighting design, TeodoroHilado; set design, JaimedeGuzman; costume design, ArturoV.Cruz. Premiered by the AliceReyes and ModernDance Company, now known as Ballet Philippines, on 5 Nov 1970 at the Main Theater, now the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, of the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP). Dancers: Alice Reyes (Itim Asu), ManuelMolina (Gov-Gen Bustamante), JoyCoronel (Sandugo), EddieElejar (Indio Juan), TonyFabella (His Son), LuisLayag, Gener Caringal, SteveVillaruz, Jose Antonio, TommySabarre, Tommy de Jesus, Romy Go, Nini Gener, Cecile Santos, Irma Bringas, Josette Salang, Tessie Reyes, Deidrie Watts, EsterRimpos, DenisaReyes (friars and townsfolk). In subsequent performance: Set design, RayAlbano and SalvadorBernal; lighting design, MoninoDuque, KatschS.J.Catoy, and Alex de Guzman.

Itim Asu is the near-legendary heroine of Aztec origin whom the Spaniards calledLa loba negra,the black she-wolf who, like an avenging she-wolf, kills the assassins of her husband, Gov-Gen Bustamante. Itim Asu’s revenge is further carried through by Sandugo, her daughter, and a son-in-law by a subsequent marriage to anindio (Christianized native).

Fernando Manuel de Bustamante y Bustillo began his tenure as governor-general of the Philippines on 9 Aug 1717. His discovery and investigation of anomalies and corruption in the Public Treasury and the Galleon Trade set him at odds with the religious orders and influential persons in Manila. In 1719, after several personages had been jailed on his orders, a procession of friars and religious escalated into a mob, and Bustamante was assassinated in the Residencia in Intramuros.

Three ritual scenes from the play are the literary source for the ballet. “The Assassination,” where the Indio Juan and Angelito Soliman are terrified onlookers to the murder of Gov-Gen Bustamante; “The Transfiguration,” where the vengeful wife seeks refuge in the hut of Indio Juan and transfigures herself into Itim Asu, who vows perpetual revenge on the assassins, performing a ritual dance as she holds the Aztec lamp that lighted up the death of Bustamante; “The Revenge,” where ItimAsu, attended by Indio Juan, pretends to need a confession and goes from convent to convent to reenact her ritual killing, each announced by a frantic ringing of thecampanilla. Her victims are ushered out from the confessional box which, when carried out by the townspeople, looks like a coffin. She is pierced by a mysterious bullet in the midst of her vendetta but rises in her death pangs like a woman, not a beast. She blesses the blood marriage of her daughter to the son of Indio Juan as Sandugo. The two later carry out her primitive justice.

Itim Asu was presented by the CCP in association with the League of Filipino Composers as its second offering in the 1970 PhilippineMusic and Dance Festival. The concert premiered two one-act ballets, IbongAdarna performed by the Hariraya Ballet Company, and Itim Asu performed by the Alice Reyes and Modern Dance Company (later known as Ballet Philippines) to the commissioned works of composers RodolfoCornejo and Alfredo S. Buenaventura.

Itim Asu was hailed by critics as a landmark in Philippine dance and the leading cultural event of the year after its world premiere at the CCP Main Theater in 1970. Written by Edna Vida

photos.photodesc: Juliet and Her Romeo, Alice Reyes and Modern Dance Company, CCP, Manila, 1970 (Edna Vida Collection)

text:
1970. Ballet in one act. Choreography and libretto, EddieElejar ; music, Dimitri Shostakovitch; lighting design, TeodoroHilado; set design, RayAlbano; costume design, Marcella Lopez. Dancers: Alice Reyes (Juliet), Manuel Molina (Romeo). Premiered by the AliceReyes and ModernDance Company, later known as BalletPhilippines, on 24 Dec 1970 at the Main Theater, now the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, of the Cultural Center of the Philippines. Regular in the early repertoire of BalletPhilippines, the ballet was last repeated by the ManilaMetropolisBallet at the Rigodon Ballroom of the Manila Peninsula in 1980.

The one-act ballet retells the story of Italy’s most famous lovers. Juliet is already presumed dead in a crypt, and Romeo rushes back to Verona. Both characters reenact the story in a stiff and somber flashback. Leading characters were totally in grey as distinguished from the corps de ballet in total black. The corps generally functions as a chorus but members occasionally take on specific characters.

In a few strokes, Elejar captures the quintessence of Shakespeare’s universal story, reminding one of Michelangelo Antonioni’s love scene in ZabriskiePoint. The use of grey and black for the dancers, other characters, and the sets, is clever. These characters produce a hazy background which highlights the pearly richness and perfect innocence of JulietandherRomeo, their love and inevitable death. Juliet and Her Romeo is one of Elejar’s best ballets, and one of the best produced in the country. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

photos.photodesc:
Juru-Pakal, CCP Dance Workshop Company, CCP, Manila, 1971

(Manila Chronicle Photo Collection, courtesy of Lopez Museum)

text:
(The Enchanted Kris). 1971. Modern ballet in one act and three scenes. Choreography, EddieElejar ; libretto, Eddie Elejar with AnacletaM.Encarnacion and RusticaC.Carpio; music, JoseMaceda; lighting design, TeodoroHilado; costume design, ArturoCruz; set design, JoseJoya. Premiered by the CCP Dance Workshop Company, now BalletPhilippines, at the Main Theater, now the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, of the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP). Dancers: ManuelMolina (Indarapatra), Eddie de Guzman (Sulayman), AliceReyes (Moon Goddess), Irma Bringas (Sarimanok), Eddie Elejar (Rinamuntaw), Josette Salang (Rinayung), Basilio (Sultan), EsterRimpos (Sultan’s Daughter), Arturo Cruz (King of the Court), Bubut Guevarra (Queen), AurelioEstanislao (Bard), Nereo Torres (Tarabusao), FranklinBobadilla (Pah), EnricoLabayen (Balbal).

The performance was accompanied by instrumentalists playing Jose Maceda’s Agungan, Ugma-ugma,and Kubing,as well as a band, the UPMadrigalSingers, the UPConcertChorus, and vocal soloists Aurelio Estanislao, AndreaOfilada-Veneracion, and Annette Belen.

This one-act modern ballet in three scenes starts with a recitation of the story of the legendary brothers Indarapatra and Sulayman.In the opening court scene, the brothers are warned of the dangers infesting Maguindanao, such as the many-limbed and -headed amphibian Kurita, the human-eating giant Tarabusao on Mount Matutum, the winged tiger Pah, and the bane of the constellations, Balbal. Indarapatra sends Sulayman to subdue these monsters with the enchanted kris, Juru-Pakal; Sulayman’s life is symbolized by a magical tree which flourishes or withers. Sulayman conquers all except Pah, who kills him. Indarapatra searches for his brother’s body, finds it, and prays to the gods to bring him back to life. Indarapatra himself goes on to subdue the mighty Balbal, is hailed by the populace, and marries the sultan’s daughter. They have a daughter, Rinayung, and a son, Rinamuntaw. Later, Indarapatra bestows his magical kris on his son. The last part of the epic finds Rinamuntaw on a hunt. He spies the Moon Goddess and her maidens, and catches the goddess’s pet, the Sarimanok. In exchange for her liberty, the heavenly bird flies Rinamuntaw to the skies where he has a celestial wedding with the goddess.

The ballet was described as belonging to the tradition of Asian theater, with elements of Kabuki drama, as well as dance movements from Thailand, Indonesia, and Cambodia. Although the dance utilizes the Mindanao epic, the choreographer went beyond territorial boundaries to present what he felt was dance in the Asian tradition. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz
