Kapinangan, CCP Dance Workshop Company, CCP, Manila, 1972

(Bayani ng Sayaw 1998 Dance Calendar, NCCA)

text:
1972. Modern ballet in one act. Choreography, EddieElejar ; libretto, Eddie Elejar, based on JoseLardizabal’s Dularawan : Salakot na Ginto (Image Play: The Golden Salakot) music, LucreciaR.Kasilag; lighting design, TeodoroHilado; costume design, ArturoCruz; set design, RayAlbano. Performed by the CCP Dance Workshop Company, later called Ballet Philippines, at the Main Theater, now known as Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, of the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP). Dancers: EsterRimpos (Kapinangan), ManuelMolina (Datu Sumakwel), Romy Go (Gurong-gurong), Eddie Elejar (Datu Puti).

The ballet dramatizes one episode on infidelity from the Maragtas epic. It tells of the wife of Datu Sumakwel, Kapinangan, who secretly loves Datu Puti. Instead, she turns to Gurong-gurong, Sumakwel’s overseer. In a fit of jealousy, Sumakwel slays Gurong-gurong. Kapinangan chops up her lover’s body and buries the pieces in the forest. She is discovered, tried, and condemned to be thrown into the sea.

The work highlights involved relationships, which occasion interesting dances, including the dramatic drowning of Kapinangan in a weighted net. The ballet marked the distinct maturing of Ester Rimpos as an artist in modern dance. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history
text:
(Cut and Load). 2008. Contemporary dance in one movement. Choreography, Dwight Rodrigazo ; music, Tribu Africano and Dance Pull Company; costume design, Rodrigazo and Gino Gonzales. Premiered by Dance Pull Company at the 2008 WiFiBody Festival at the Tanghalang Huseng Batute, Cultural Center of the Philippines.

Rodrigazo returned to his hometown of Bacolod in 2006 with a plan to distinctly establish a school, company, and ultimately a dance community away from Manila. In his school, he developed his choreographic style, based on what he calls “directional motivation,” or moving in the opposite direction of what is considered “natural.” This is basically a rebellion against the standard movement of classical ballet and modern dance, resulting in “dance and pull,” which is also the name of his dance company and school. The technique was first explored in his Indios Bravos (Brave Natives) and further developed in Karga Tapas.

Karga Tapas was inspired by the migrantsakadaor seasonal plantation workers who toil in the sugarcane haciendas of Negros cutting (tapas) and loading (karga) sugarcane into trucks for a miserable daily wage. These tasks are transformed by choreographer Dwight Rodrigazo into a repetitive, almost ritualistic movement executed with variant gestures. In the dance, the sakada wear burnt sienna red masks underneath layers of rough clothing which protect them from the heat of the sun. They carry scythes for cutting the sugar canes. Rhythm is provided by a hand-held drum and stomping of feet.

From the beginning until the end of the choreography, dancers spring like rubber bands stretched to full length from positions close to the floor, sometimes jumping away only to be pulled back close to the ground. At the same time, the dancers slash their surroundings with their scythes. During intervals, the dynamics of the stomping and slashing magnify and relax, mimicking the rising and falling levels of energy of the sakada out in the field. Two female dancers stand taller than the male dancers and do not stomp as hard. Rodrigazo abruptly breaks the momentum of cutting and carrying by gathering the sakada to one corner of the stage to watch an imagined delivery truck drive away with their day’s harvest. Then, the sakadaresume their toiling movements, their stomping, and their inescapable lives.

The premiere performance struck many members of the audience as an eye-opening portrayal of Filipino life. Some viewers criticized the work for presenting a harsh statement on local labor conditions while others praised it for its empathy with the working class. Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history

photos.photodesc: Kayaw, Larawan Dancing Group, CCP, Manila, 1974 (Photo courtesy of Ramon A. Obusan)

text:
(Headhunt).1974. Folk dance choreography in two acts. Choreography, RamonObusan ; music, Kalinga Performers; lighting design, Teodoro Hilado; set design, Dennis Tan; costume design, Ramon Obusan and the ICM Sisters headed by Aurora Zembrano ICM. Premiered by Larawan Dancing Group on 16 Feb 1974 at the Cultural Center of the Philippines.

Kayaw is a two-act staging of the dances of the Cordilleras, set against a giant stairway to simulate the rice terraces. Act 1 revolves around the headhunting of the Kalinga, and a courtship-into-wedding scene. Called the peacocks of the mountains, the Kalinga men are decked out in plumed headdresses. Everyone listens for the sound and flight of the ominousidawbird—telling of victory or defeat in a kayaw. Themangayawenacts the swift attack to decapitate the enemies and to gain honor in one’s own tribe, especially for those who aspire for leadership and the titlepangat.In the clash of spears and shields, two of their own are left dead, one headless. Lamentation of the women and children pierce the silence, as though to bestir the dead to avenge themselves. Amandadawak(priestess) does the same with a ceremonial china bowl into which she seems to catch hair from the air, believed to be of their ancestors. Hair is planted on the heads of grieving relatives. Donning red which is the color for mourning, the women light a fire, as though to burn away the spirits of the dead so they will not bother the living. To the victorious warriors calledminger,the maidens give thedangas(headbaskets) while singing thebalugay.The warriors themselves are absolved of their bloody act by eatingbinurbur(rice), and are anointed by the mandadawak with the blood of a black rooster. In theulawi, the mingers do the victory dance called takiling where they are crowned withlawi(feathered headdresses) reserved only for successful headhunters.

A warrior chooses a girl, bestowing her a gift as he dances the la-ay.Ngilinis the wedding proper where the bride accepts firewood as proof of matrimonial agreement. Musicians play thetuppaya beat on the gongs for the wedding, to which the groom dances like a rooster in a love-play with his bride who balances pots of oil on her head, symbol of a smooth married life. In the tuktukyod,they enact a contest on who is to bathe after the wedding. The rest of the maidens balance pots on their heads as they skip and sing on their way to a waterfall, dancing thebanga.

Act 2 enacts thebodongwhere the tribes forge a peace pact; otherwise a kayaw could be renewed. To the solitary tune of a nose flute, later joined by mouth lutes, gongs, guitars, violins and voices, a pangat leads a conference among various tribal chieftains. Pakupak is invocation for the meeting of elders. Palpaliwat boasts of the triumphant exploits of warriors. Tarektek imitates the woodpecker in a dance whose participants are armed with a gong and a blanket. Bendiyan is an Ibaloy victory dance with the hands and feet directed downwards to the earth. An Isneg duet depicts the character of the most bashful of the northern tribes. Chun-no of the industrious Bontok is a rice-pounding dance, done while singing. Ulok displays the treasured blankets of the Ifugao. Tajuk is another festival dance of the Kalinga, showing off their finery. With the celebration, the bodong is consummated.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history

photos.photodesc: Kundiman, Noon at Ngayon, Philippine Ballet Theatre, CCP, Manila, 1992 (CCP Collection)

text:
(Love Songs, Past and Present). 1992. Neoclassical ballet in six songs. Choreography, Tony Fabella ; musical arrangement, Rey Paguio; costume design, Arturo Cruz. Premiered by Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT) in Nov 1992 at the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, Cultural Center of the Philippines. Dancers: Lisa Macuja, Osias Barroso Jr, Maritoni Rufino, Raoul Banzon, and the artists of PBT.

Kundiman, Noon at Ngayon was premiered at the third Celebration of PBT concert in Nov 1992, and featured the University of the Philippines Concert Chorus (UPCC) singing the classickundiman(love song) and contemporary pop songsfor the company. The UPCC sings Felipe de Leon’s “Ako Ay Filipino” (I Am Filipino) as a prelude to the suite. PBT joins them only on the second song, “Sa Kabukiran” (In the Countryside) medley, an ensemble piece for the ladies, highlighting Fabella’s love for contrapuntal ensemble work, where the dancers make pretty patterns around each other. “Sa Kabukiran” is abstract and focuses on the dancing, particularly the juxtaposition of elaborate pointe work with the graceful sweeping of arms and upper bodies, further enhanced by the dancers’ flowing dresses, with sleeves cut to resemble thekimona, a traditional female garment.

This is followed by a pas de quatre to “Hindi Kita Malimot” (I Cannot Forget You), featuring two couples falling in love: the first, sweet and poignant; the second, giddy and breathless. The steps in these duets are not as elaborate as those in the first piece, as Fabella meant to emphasize the emotions in each gesture more. The tone becomes playful as the ensemble enters, skipping and galloping around to “Ay, Ay Pag-Ibig”(Oh, Oh, Love). The next kundiman is a pas de trois to Restie Umali’s “Ang Pag-Ibig Mo”(Your Love), full of quiet yearning and unrequited love between the three dancers. A happier pas de deux is then performed by Lisa Macuja and Osias Barroso to “Tuwing Umuulan at Kapiling Ka”(Whenever It Rains and You’re With Me), before Maritoni Rufino leads the ensemble in a finale, “Dito Nagwawakas”(It Ends Here).

Although Fabella’s previous suite of pop songs, Pinoy Talaga (Truly Pinoy), was popular with audiences because of the familiar music that accompanied the dances, it was criticized for being forgettable and cutesy. In contrast, Kundiman, Noon at Ngayon ,while still retaining humorous moments and cute accents, stands out with its elegance and fulsome, gorgeous dancing. A short version of Kundiman was regularly staged from 2001 to 2006. Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history

photos.photodesc: La Lampara, CCP Dance Company, CCP, Manila, 1980 (Steve Villaruz Collection)

text:
(The Lamp). 1980. Ballet in one act. Scenario and choreography, Basilio ; music, JerryDadap ( Life-force ); lighting design, KatschS.J.Catoy; set and costume design, SalvadorBernal. Premiered by the CCP Dance Company, now BalletPhilippines, on 14 Nov 1980 at the Main Theater, now the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), as commissioned by the CCP for the 1980 Philippine Music Festival. Dancers: Mario Esperanza (Rizal), Maricar Drilon (Josephine), CecileSicangco (Doña Teodora). Restaged by PhilippineBalletTheater on 14 Nov 1991 for the centennial of ElFilibusterismo (Subversion), with set and costume design by ArturoCruz and lighting design by EricV.Cruz. 1991 Cast: Raoul Banzon / OsiasBarroso (Rizal); Melanie Motus / Maritoni Rufino (Josephine); Noreen Ostrea / Rosalie Carreon (Doña Teodora).

The ballet enacts the last hours of Jose Rizal in his cell in FortSantiago and uses as central symbol the lamp in which the hero was supposed to have hidden his poem“MiUltimoAdios” (The Last Farewell). Suspended through most of the ballet, the lamp stands for Rizal’s ideals, which helped bring about the revolution. He is hoisted twice towards the overhanging lamp in order to identify his own life with the symbol, and to suggest that he is the moth attracted to and burned by the flame. Its “explosion” refers to the lamp meant to signal the outbreak of a rebellion in El Filibusterismo, the sequel to the NoliMeTangere (Touch Me Not). In the novel, the explosion does not happen; the ballet takes the liberty of suggesting that Rizal foresees his own death in that explosion.

The one-act ballet opens with Rizal lighting a lamp that explodes. After an emotional solo, Rizal is visited by priests asking for his retraction, by several Katipunero (revolutionaries) soliciting his support for the revolution, by his wife Josephine Bracken with whom he dances an intimate pas de deux, and by his mother Doña Teodora and his two sisters. A transition comes when he is fetched by theguardias civiles(constables) for his execution in Bagumbayan, later known as Luneta. His fall leads to his dream of a revolutionary encounter. He wakes up. In another brief episode, he is again visited by his disconsolate wife and weeping family, who later take away the lamp supposed to contain his poem “Mi Ultimo Adios.” He is fetched once more by the guards. The fort setting changes to a projected photograph of Rizal’s actual execution. He and his guards mime a walk downstage as the curtain slowly falls. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history

photos.photodesc: La Revolucion Filipina, Ballet Philippines, CCP, Manila, 2014 (CCP Collection)

text:
(The Philippine Revolution). 1996. Modern ballet in two acts. Choreography, Agnes Locsin ; music composed and performed by Ryan Cayabyab; libretto, Dennis Marasigan; lighting design, Shoko Matsumoto; set design, Mio Infante; costume design, Victor Ursabia. Premiered by Ballet Philippines (BP) on 23 Feb 1996 at the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, Cultural Center of the Philippines. Cast: Alden Lugnasin (Apolinario Mabini); Nonie Buencamino (Emilio Aguinaldo); Gerald Mercado (Andres Bonifacio); Brando Miranda (Oppressor); Camille Ordinario, Judell de Guzman and Annette Cruz (Muses of Liberty, Equality, and Fraternity).

As BP’s contribution to the centennial celebration of the Philippine revolution, La Revolucion Filipina traces the events and circumstances that led to the 1896 revolution against the Spanish colonial rule and the aftermath of the declaration of Philippine independence in 1898. The story is told from the perspective of Apolinario Mabini, the “sublime paralytic” of the Philippine Revolution, and focuses on his contentious relationship with Emilio Aguinaldo, the first and only president of the Revolutionary Government.

The production consists of a prologue and two acts, and utilizes dialogue, movement, and music to create a powerful dance-theater fusion. The prologue sets the tone of the ballet as Mabini rests on a hammock on a roadside en route to Kawit, Cavite, where Aguinaldo is set to proclaim Philippine independence from Spain. Mabini and Aguinaldo disagree on issues related to the declaration of independence.

Act 1 takes the audience back to the 16th century when Filipinos enjoyed freedom. The coming of the Spaniards results in the subjugation of the archipelago as the colonizers inflict cruelty on the Filipinos. Amidst all these, three Filipino figures stand tall in defiance of the Spanish rule during the 19th century—Andres Bonifacio, Aguinaldo, and Mabini. Inspired by the muses of Liberty, Equality, and Fraternity, Bonifacio forms the Katipunan, a secret society to fight for Philippine independence. Aguinaldo joins the Katipunan while Mabini chooses to remain with the reformists. When the Spaniards discover the Katipunan, the Philippine revolution begins. Aguinaldo is elected president of the revolutionary government and Bonifacio is tried for treason and ordered killed.

In Act 2, the Americans join forces with the Filipinos in their war with Spain. Aguinaldo leads the fledgling government, orders the sewing of the Philippine flag, proclaims Philippine independence, and convenes the Malolos Congress to ratify the declaration of independence and write a Constitution. Through all these developments, Mabini, who has become an influential adviser to Aguinaldo, cautions him against the Americans and the Malolos Congress led by theilustrado(educated). After the Spanish-American War, Spain cedes the Philippines to the United States of America which thereafter refuses to recognize the declaration of Philippine independence. Armed conflict with the Americans begins. Aguinaldo becomes disillusioned with the treachery of fellow Filipinos and contemplates on a peaceful settlement with the Americans. He is captured and is forced to pledge allegiance to the American flag. Aguinaldo steps down from power and becomes witness to the continuing division of his countrymen. Mabini bewails their defeat and expresses a deep sentiment that if Filipinos do not change their ways, the country will never reach greatness and will remain an illiterate race.

Locsin’s close collaboration with librettist Dennis Marasigan, a stage director and actor, inspired her to tell the story in a dance theater style. The casting of theater actor Nonie Buencamino as Aguinaldo allowed the utilization of dialogue interspersed with music to create a more effective retelling of history. The choreography is markedly neo-ethnic in style as is typical of Locsin’s other modern dance pieces. She drew inspiration from various forms of traditional and ethnic dances for the ensemble choreography and used percussive, earth-bound, and angular movements, as well as lyrical contemporary dance styles for the dance sequences of the three muses and Mabini’s solos.

La Revolucion Filipina was lauded by critics and audiences alike for its compelling narrative, powerful choreography and effective retelling of Philippine history. After its world premiere in Feb 1996, it was performed in Los Angeles and San Diego, California, in Jul 1996 and at the Kennedy Center in Washington DC and Honolulu in 1998. It was restaged by BP as part of its annual CCP season in 1997, 1998, 2008, and 2014. For its 2008 restaging, La Revolucion Filipina garnered three Gawad Buhay awards from Philstage: namely, Outstanding Dance Production, Outstanding Original Choreography for Agnes Locsin, and Outstanding Male Lead Performance in a Dance Production for Biag Gaongen. Its 2014 restaging was presented in commemoration of the 150th anniversary of the birth of Apolinario Mabini. Written by Nestor O. Jardin

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history

photos.photodesc: Legend of Sarimanok, Hariraya Dance Company, Rizal Theater, 1968 (Vella C. Damian Collection)

text:
Modern ballet. Choreography, ReynaldoAlejandro and Roberto Caballero; music, BayaniMendozadeLeon; costume design, ArturoCruz. Premiered by HarirayaDanceCompany on 5 Nov 1968 at the Rizal Theater, Makati. Dancers: ManiyaBarredo (Sarimanok), EricV.Cruz (Prince), EffieNañas (Enigambara-ulan), Nini Mendoza (Sultana). Accompanied by the ManilaSymphonyOrchestra under the baton of OscarYatco.

The story was adapted from the legend of thesarimanokas recounted by A.V.H.Hartendorp, about the love affair of a Muslim prince with the goddess of the moon. This ballet was first tried out in 1965 at University of Santo Tomas, and premiered in 1968 at the Rizal Theater. For the Meralco Theater production in 1969, Sarimanok was revised and restaged by Remedios“Totoy”deOteyza and LuluPuertollano as part of the “Stars of the Bolshoi Theatre” program.Written by Reynaldo G. Alejandro and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

text:
(Five Armstretches). 1981. Modern ballet and jazz. Choreography, TonyFabella ; music, RyanCayabyab, SantiagoSuarez, Dominador Santiago, and TitoArevalo; lighting design, Raymond Salvacion; costume and set design, RupertAcuña. Premiered by DanceTheaterPhilippines on 19 Sep 1982 at the Meralco Theater. Dancers: AnnaVilladolid, Mike Uy, LisaMacuja. It has been acquired by PhilippineBalletTheatre in its regular repertory.

Set to six Filipino popular songs as arranged and sung by Cayabyab, the ballet presents: straightforward dancing to “KayGandangAtingMusika” (How Beautiful is Our Music); a piece for four gossipy girls, full of rushed and vibratory movements in “Tsismis” (Gossip); an introspective solo in “BakyaMo,Neneng” (Your Wooden Clogs, Neneng) that exploits the use of pointe shoes to suggest the bakya;a quick and familiar scene for two dancers, intruded into by another pair, in “Mamang Kutsero” (Mr. Rig Driver); a lyrical pas de deux, with four heckling voyeuristic boys in “Minamahal, Sinasamba” (Loved and Adored); and a crowded street scene with its surprises, accidents, and chance drama, depicted in various locomotive and partnering combinations and styles, in “Limang Dipang Tao” (Five Armstrecthes).

The popular work was described by LeonorOrosa-Goquingco as an interesting mix of ballet, jazz, and modern jazz that is mostly witty with touches of the literal and the abstract.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

Linggisan, AlunAlun Dance Circle, Paris, 2007

(Richard de Guzman, AlunAlun Dance Circle Collection)

text:
(The Bird). 1978. A dance solo in pangalay dance style. Choreography by Ligaya F. Amilbangsa . Music,kulintangan(gong) ensemble recorded by Amilbangsa or live kulintangan accompaniment. Amilbangsa herself danced the linggisan in its numerous performances. Premiered in Aug 1978 during the Pacific People’s Theater Festival, San Jose, California, USA; in 1988, at theNational Theaterin Seoul, Korea, in the International Dance Festivaland the 24thSeoul Olympiad; in 1994, at the11thGeneral Assembly and International Dance Colloque, International Council of Dance and the National Dance Council of Italy in Turin, Italy; in 1995, in theORFF-100 International Conference of Music and Dance, Monash University Auditorium, Melbourne, Australia; and in the 1995 United Nations Fourth World Conference on Women / NGO Forum on Women in Beijing, China.

Linggisan is an original choreography based on the field research of Amilbangsa. She created a coherent scenario with a beginning, middle, and end that showed a bird in flight, landing on soil or water’s surface, looking for food, and enjoying its freedom in the natural environment. This variant of the pangalay or igal (dance style from Sulu Archipelago) not only has its own character, but also has a distinct melodic pattern in the kulintangan ensemble. Linggisan used a variety of hand and finger movements that were exaggerated through the use of metal claws calledjanggay,sulakengkeng, orsaling-kuku. Amilbangsa first saw this mimetic dance in 1969 at Plaza Tulay in Jolo, Sulu when gay dancers converged after supper to perform the dalling-dalling, a humorous song-dance, that has a serious segment imitating a bird called “linggisan.” Amazed by the sophistication and variety of its movements, Amilbangsa continued to document linggisan among Sama and Tausug dancers who use the janggay for the dance. Then she waited for several months for a serendipitous occasion when a good dancer could show new techniques. For instance, in Jolo, the best linggisan movements were demonstrated by a woman who showed exceptionally beautiful dance combinations.

She continued her research on linggisan in Tawi-Tawi starting in 1973 by memorizing dance steps performed by students and ordinary people during school celebrations and social gatherings. But learning the movement vocabulary needed a sharp and quick memory so she developed a method of remembering dance steps, stances, and gestures through her own shadow cast on the wall by a lighted candle or lamp. There was no electricity in Tawi-Tawi until 1983 which made the shadow dancing a natural habit for her after field work. From her dancing shadows, she codified the dance by drawing stick figures until she was able to put together and refine poses, stances, gestures, and footwork recorded from numerous dancers. The stick figures were replaced by the pangalay silhouette figures which first appeared in Amilbangsa’s Pangalay published in 1983.

In 1994, Linggisan was performed by Hwa Yi Ethnic Dance Center’s principal dancer Abigail Yu at the Second Seoul International Dance Competition, winning the Silver Award in the solo category. In 1996, it was performed by Tambuli Cultural Troupe’s principal dancer, Sakinur-ain Mugong, at the XIV International Music Festivalin Cantonigros, Catalunya, Spain, with kulintangan accompaniment by Aga Mayo Butocan and Muhan Julasman. In 2001, Amilbangsa performed it at the Malay World Arts Festival and Conference, Johor Bahru, Malaysia. In 2007, it was danced by Louanne Mae Calipayan of the AlunAlun Dance Circle in various theaters and galleries in Paris, France, in celebration of the109thAnniversary of the Proclamation of Philippine Independence and the60th Anniversary of Franco-Philippine Relations. Written by Rosalie S. Matilac

Anita Kane’s Mariang Makiling, Ateneo de Manila Auditorium, Manila, 1939

(Excelsior 1939, University of the Philippines Archives)

text:
1939. Ballet in two acts. Choreography, AnitaKane ; music, RamonTapales; costume design, A. Villegas, Badillo, and Asuncion de Castro; set design, RichardAbelardo. Premiered on 22 Nov 1939 at the Ateneo de Manila Auditorium. Dancers: Elisa Robles (Mariang Makiling); Milagros Gonzales (Vision); Felipe Librojo (Barrio Hero); Nina Estrada (Barrio Belle); Carlos Cajulao (Barrio Fool); Godofredo Angeles (Teniente del Barrio); Emma Aenle (Tindera); Patria Panajon (Old Woman); LucioSandoval (Old Man); Emiliano Pineda, RicardoReyes, Vicente Paradela, Alfonso Faustino, Eduardo Robles (Hero’s companions). The cast also included dancers of FranciscaReyes-Aquino’s UPFolkSongandDanceTroupe, the Torres High School, the Philippine Women’s University, and the Arellano High School.

Kane and Tapales worked together on this two-act ballet, selecting scenes from JoseRizal’s account of the popular Laguna legend, and producing the first Filipino ballet in the classic tradition. Tapales composed a score inspired by the lush forests and mist-covered peaks of Makiling, and used themusikong bumbong(bamboo-band musicians).

In Act 1, the villagers at the foot of Mount Makiling await the legendary vision of Maria Makiling as a sign of a bountiful harvest. The characters include a vendor, the belle, the fool, the barrio captain, the local hero and his companions, and a pair of an old man and woman, a brass and bamboo band, children, other villagers, and the vision.

In Act 2, the mountain goddess meets with the barrio hero in the depths of the forest. Intervening, the people propitiate her with a white chicken, and convince the hero that earthly love is more reasonable than fantasy.MariangMakiling retires to her mountaintop, forever to weep over her unfaithful mortal lover. Her tears form the mists around the peak.

The work is a landmark piece because it was the first to use a local legend and a composition originally created for ballet. Later choreographers consider this piece as their inspiration as well as the point of departure for their own original ballet choreographies. Written by Anita M. Kane and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

text:
1981. Modern ballet in one act. Scenario and choreography, EddieElejar , based on the poem “Order for Masks” by VirginiaMoreno; music, RamonP.Santos ( Five Pieces for TwoPianos ); lighting design, Raymond Salvacion;costume and set design, RupertAcuña. Dancers: AnnaVilladolid (Girl); Mike Uy (Lover), Raul Sauz / Robert Policarpio (Brother). Premiered by DanceTheaterPhilippines in 1981 at the Meralco Theater. Restaged by PhilippineBalletTheatre on 14 Nov 1991 at the Tanghalang NicanorAbelardo, Cultural Center of the Philippines with lighting design by EricV.Cruz and dancers Mylene Saldaña / Rosalie Carreon (Girl), Mike Uy (Lover), Joey Herrera (Father).

The one-act ballet sketches the relationships of a girl with three men in her life—her brother, father, and lover. Throughout the ballet, Moreno’s poem is read, interspersed with the sections of the music. The girl in white unitards tries out her own dexterity with balances and turns, and finally falls, rocks herself, and mirror mimes with her hand. The brother’s jumpy solo is to a stanza. Then, brother and sister dance to music with playful movements like clapping and skipping. The father’s clenched-fist solo is to another stanza. The playful trio which shows the father catching, lifting the daughter and son is to music. After each relationship is sketched, the girl goes up an appropriate platform with its respective mask. After all these, the girl is left alone. The man in black slides off his ramp as a new stanza is read. He does a sensual, jazzy solo, playing with his stiff hat which he throws at the girl’s feet. To silence, he invites her to dance, waltzing, turning, and lifting her.Seduction comes after she is divested of her headcap; they dance and end up lying on the floor on their sides. The brother and father leap over them and the girl sits up, protesting their questioning looks and gestures. Toward the end, even the lover leaps around her together with the brother and father.All the men walk away. Alone, the girl slips to the floor gazes at her mirror hand again. The final line, “make me three masks” is heard before the total blackout. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

text:
(Eye in the Dream). 2006. Contemporary dance in one movement. Choreography, Elena Laniog ; music, Teresa Barrozo; costume design, Elena Laniog. Premiered by the University of the Philippines (UP) Dance Company at the 2006 Mindanao Modern Dance Festival in Koronadal, South Cotabato, and presented at the WiFi Body Festival 2006, at the Cultural Center of the Philippines. Dancers: Ava Maureen Villanueva, Rhosam Prudenciado Jr, Angela Lawenko, Bea Puno, Marlon Cabiting, Jantu Revilla, Chantal Primero, and Nicole Primero.

Mata sa Damgo is Ilonggo for “Eye in the Dream.” This abstract piece presents a hurricane of bodies characterized by jagged and abrupt movements alternating with fluid transitions traveling across space. The choreography is distinguished by frenetic energy that pervades much of Elena Laniog’s later works. The bodies collect, build, and explode into convulsions tantamount to receiving a giant jolt of electricity. Yet, all the seemingly wild movements are precisely controlled and technically maneuvered. Striking movements include percussive breaks in the hips and shoulders, with arms making repetitive circular patterns around various select parts of the upper body. Many moments find the dancers’ hands brushing across their own faces as if soothing a headache, brushing away wayward locks of hair or a sheen of sweat, and masking anxiety. They appear to be in the vortex of a dream and trying to make sense of it.

This is not Laniog’s first choreographic work but it showed her evolving signature style as she had been experimenting with a peculiar manner of movement that suited her loose-limbed and double-jointed body. The powerful attack of each dancer was a result of intensive training to master the wild gestures which were initially painful on the knees and lower back.

Although Mata sa Damgo did not win in the 2006 Mindanao Modern Dance Competition in Koronadal, it was thought to be ahead of its time. Years after, the movement vocabulary that developed from Mata sa Damgo inspired choreographic works by the younger generation of choreographers, especially from the UP Dance Program, who were trained in this technique and performed in Laniog’s succeeding choreographies.

Mata sa Damgo was shown in Kuala Lumpur at the Tari International Dance Festival in 2007 by Villanueva, Prudenciado, Revilla, Chantal and Nicole Primero, Yvonne Torres, Yasnina Jumalon, and John Philip Martir. Lighting design for this performance was by Mele Yamomo. It was also restaged for the Dance, Young People, and Change Global Dance Festival at the Taipei National University, Taiwan, in 2012, performed by Chaya Joyce Baris, Sarah Maria Samaniego, Angella Betina Carlos, Angela Sebastian. Marielle Baylocon, Al Bernard Garcia, Japhet Mari Cabling, and Michael Barry Que. Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

text:
1971. Modern ballet in one act. Choreography, FelicitasLayag-Radaic ; libretto, Felicitas Layag-Radaic, after NickJoaquin’s short story, “MayDayEve;” music, EliseoM.Pajaro; lighting direction, MoninoDuque; set design, Dave Harvey; costume design, Rose Pah. Premiered on 20 Mar 1971 by DanceTheaterPhilippines at the Meralco Theater. Dancers: Irma Bringas (Agueda), ManuelMolina (Montiya).

The one-act, three-scene ballet juxtaposes the Spanish-era Doña Agueda and Don Badoy Montiya, an embittered old couple, with their young selves, Agueda and Badoy. The central images are a candle and a mirror, which reveal one’s future husband during a bewitched midnight rite. Layag-Radaic employs flashbacks, and in the last scene past and present surrealistically merge, putting frustration and romance side by side.

RosalindaOrosa noted the ballet’s success in creating a melancholy atmosphere especially with the music of Pajaro.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

Mir-i-nisa, Dance Theater Philippines, CCP, Manila, 1969

(Philippine Dance: Mainstream and Crosscurrents by Reynaldo G. Alejandro. Vera-Reyes Inc, 1978)

text:
1969. Modern ballet in three acts. Choreography, JulieBorromeo (Acts 2 and 3) and FelicitasLayag-Radaic (Act 2); scenario by Julie Borromeo, based on a short story by JoseGarciaVilla, “Mir-inisa;” music, EliseoM.Pajaro; lighting design, TeodoroHilado; set design, JohnnyHubilla; costume design, ArturoCruz and Marcella Lopez; artistic direction, EddieElejar. Premiered by DanceTheaterPhilippines (DTP) on 28 Nov 1969 at the Main Theater, now the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, of the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP). Dancers: Mary Anne Garcia / Nini Gener (Mir-i-nisa), OdonSabarre (Tasmi), TonyFabella (Achmed), TonyLlacer (Datu), TinaSantos (Slave), Julie Borromeo (Pink Pearl), Tina Santos (White Pearl and Queen of the Undersea), Eddie Elejar (Consort), and Felicitas Layag-Radaic (Black Pearl); with support from Folklorico Filipino, BayanihanPhilippineDanceCompany, and selected dancers from CebuBalletCenter. In its more or less original version, Act 2 was restaged for BalletPhilippines on Sep 1979 by Odon Sabarre and Lucy Layag de los Reyes.

Act 1, “The Triangle,” revolves around the rivalry between two Muslim princes of different tribes, Tasmi (“noble and strong”) and Achmed (“aggressive and boastful”), for the hand of a princess, Mir-i-nisa. Ceremonial entertainment is presented before the royal court of the datu and his many wives with a special slave dance and other court dances. Although Mir-i-nisa favors Tasmi and consorts with him in the woods, she cannot make a decision.A mock combat set between the tribes gets heated up, so the datu has to intervene. He drops a black pearl into the sea which should be recovered by whoever wants to be worthy of his daughter.

Act 2, “The Underwater,” is a fantasy with varicolored pearls guarded by their respective nymphs.The pink-pearl dancers cascade like running waves, the blue-pearl dancers flow serenely on, and the white stalk and turn sharply. The black pearl is in a closed shell guarded by a sultry, almost jazzy, nymph, but Achmed seductively persuades her to give him the choice pearl. Earlier on, Tasmi had struggled with sea creatures and monsters but found no pearl at all.

Act 3, “The Victor,” shows Tasmi coming to shore tired and wounded. He is attended to by Mir-i-nisa who realizes he is the one she truly loves. But Achmed returns triumphant and declares himself the worthy man. The next scene is the celebration for the wedding, with Mir-i-nisa kept away in a high chamber, to be sought by her groom. In the tribal parade, the unhappy Mir-i-nisa is brought face to face with her groom. Many are surprised to find out that her groom is not Achmed but Tasmi. The datu explains that he actually threw not a pearl but a ball of black salt into the sea, and Tasmi proved to be the honest man.

Mir-i-nisa was completely choreographed by EricV.Cruz for DanceConcertCompany, backed by some folk dancers and the UPFilipinianaDanceCompany, for performances at the Meralco Theater on 28 Nov 1976, at the University of the Philippines Theater on 1 Dec 1976, and at the CCP on 1 Jan 1978. Arturo Cruz also designed new costumes, sets, and lights. Dancing as Mir-i-nisa was Heidi Domingo; Tasmi, RupertAcuña; Achmed, Louis Bayquen; and the datu, Patrick Baynes. Among the leading nymphs were Teresa Bautista and ShirleyHalili (Blue Pearl), Marivic Mapili (White Pearl and Queen of the Undersea), and Myra Beltran (Black Pearl).

Mir-i-nisa was last revived with new choreography by Borromeo and Layag-Radaic on 7 Apr 1989 at the CCP. It also marked the 21st anniversary of DTP, which was backed by PhilippineBalletTheatre and Maharlika Dance Group,with RamonObusan as ethnic dance consultant. New costume design was by Arturo Cruz, new set design by Carlito Señeres, Arnold Limjoco, and Marlon Reyes, and lighting design by Eric V. Cruz. Mir-i-nisa was played by Mylene Saldaña; Tasmi, NonoyFroilan and OsiasBarroso; Achmed, Raoul Banzon; and the datu, Sol Fernandez. The leading nymphs were Rose Miranda (Pink Pearl), Katrina Santos (Blue Pearl), Anna Marie Tirol (White Pearl and Queen of the Undersea), and Melanie Motus (Black Pearl).

Mir-i-nisa has the distinction of being the first full-evening Filipino ballet, and the first Filipino ballet presented during the inaugural season of the CCP in 1969. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

photos.photodesc: Misa Filipina, Philippine Ballet Theatre, CCP, Manila, 2008 (Ador G. Pamintuan)

text:
(Filipino Mass). 1984. A ballet for the mass. Scenario, choreography, and costume design, Basilio ; music (a capella in Latin), RyanCayabyab. Premiered by DanceTheaterPhilippines on 15 Dec 1984 at Puerta Real, Intramuros, Manila in practice costumes.

The ballet follows the structure of a Catholic Mass, with sections called “Kyrie,” “Gloria,” “Credo,” “Sanctus,” and “Agnus Dei.” The storyline narrates the martyrdom and resurrection of a central character called the Man in White.

“Kyrie” is an exhortation for mercy. Like the music that starts with an alto solo, soon joined by other voices, a file of dancers spills out in various directions, urgent in their pleas. The dancers weave in and out, crouched low or stretched up in supplication. With diminished energy, they gather into a line downstage.

“Gloria” starts quietly. In turns, the dancers run and turn to break away. The music builds up, the dancers form a cross pathway, and the Man in White wearing a bush jacket and a cloak and carrying a white flag rushes in. Everyone hails him. Soon left alone, he kneels. Four men, dressed in blue and silver as soldiers, hesitantly approach him, then assault and pin him down. Ironically, to the music’s exultation, the Man in White is stabbed by his own banner-staff as “Jesu Cristo” is sung. The soldiers raise the flag to signify their own victory and abandon his body.

“Credo” is the simplest section. Ten women stretch a scarlet cloth and walk a solemn procession from the wings or through a church aisle. Like many Veronicas, they wipe the man’s face, and prop him up with the red cloth. He falls again. As the music crescendos, the soldiers drive away the women and carry the body away. The women sustain each other and dance out their distress, but end with a whispered “Amen.”

“Sanctus” has the two men at the beginning rejoining the women’s circle. The music and movement are full of high hosannas. The revived Man in White returns, now stripped down to his white trousers.He comforts the women, especially the four Marys. The ever-intensifying action climaxes in a tableau. Like its ponderous music, “Agnus Dei” begins emotively.

Following a canonic sequence, the dancers flagellate themselves. Ending in two distant lines, they tread towards each other to reach an invisible communion table with the Man in White at the head. As he slowly raises his arms, the communicants reach out to the audience, inviting them into the suggested sacrament.

The ballet was dedicated to “Marcial Bonifacio,” the alias of Benigno Aquino Jr, used when he returned to the Philippines and was assassinated in 1983. The Man in White is dressed as he was then, but universalized when stripped of his jacket.

It was previewed unfinished at Puerta Real on 21 Apr 1984 and in full at the University of the Philippines (UP) Church of the Risen Lord on 6 May 1984. It was performed on 30 Apr 1985 at the ManilaCathedral, before Jaime Cardinal Sin and Aquino’s widow Corazon C. Aquino before she decided to run for president. It also celebrated the EDSA revolution in Pagdiriwang, Bayan Ko (A Celebration, My Country), 24-25 May 1986, at the Manila MetropolitanTheater. A choreographed version of the Misa,also by Basilio, was done by the UPConcertChorus in their 1983 international tour. In 1990, the UP Dance Company (UPDC) performed it at the Hong Kong International Festival of Dance Academies. In 1995, UPDC performed it for Pope John Paul’s World Youth Day visit in the Philippines. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

text:
(Muse of the Sea). 1950. Modern ballet in one act. Choreography, AnitaKane ; music, Claude Debussy; costume design, Anita Kane and Asuncion de Castro. Premiered on 25 Feb 1950 at the University of the Philippines Theater. Dancers: Milady Janario (Girl), Israel Gabriel (Hero), JulieBorromeo, Elizabeth Guasch, Serafina Guinto, EsterRimpos, TonyLlacer, Herminio Maximo, Exequiel Banzali.

Mutya was also performed on 23 Mar 1961 at the Elizalde Hall, and during the 1966-1967 Pamana Ballet national tour. The 1961 cast included Serafina Guinto, Herminio Maximo, Rene Dimacali, John Ting, KristinJackson. The Pamana Ballet presented GretaMonserrat / Ester Rimpos (Girl), EddieElejar / Teofilo Pila / Lito Capiña (Hero) with LucioSandoval, LuisLayag, Solita Santamaria, Conrad Tiolengco, Bert Escolastico, Kristin Jackson, and Florence Perez.

Debussy’s powerful seascape inspired the choreographer to create this one-act ballet based on her memories of the fishing villages around Paracale and Gumaos in Camarines, where she spent her early childhood. Early in the morning, the fishers depart for the sea. There is a flurry of activities as the town goes about the business of the day. The women and children settle down for the long wait for the return of the fishers. Then follows the storm and the anxieties it brings. The men return but for one, he who has saved all but has lost his own life. A great calm comes after the tragedy, and the folk accept their fate as people of the sea. Written by Anita M. Kane

photos.photodesc: Muybridge Frames, Ballet Philippines, CCP, Manila 1983 (Edna Vida Collection)

text:
1983. Moderndance in three segments. Choreography, DenisaReyes ; music, Fabian Obispo; set design, SalvadorBernal; lighting design, KatschS.J.Catoy. Premiered by BalletPhilippines on 1 May 1983 at the Main Theater, now the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, of the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP). Dancers: BrandoMiranda, Edward Malagkit, Ric Culalic, ConradDy-Liacco, Jinn Ibarrola, Jojo Lucila, and Ramon Victoria.

This modern dance in three segments was inspired by photographer Eadweard Muybridge’s motion studies wherein he took stop-action pictures of people exercising and horses running. These studies pioneered the “moving pictures” that later became known as the cinema. Muybridge Frames begins with seven men clad in white shorts doing muscle-flexing movements in slow motion. Large shadows are cast on the backdrop. The shadows fade out, the men exit and the second section begins with movements that typify a race progressing into simultaneous individual and multiple images, leaps and runs freezing into shapes, then flowing into poses as in a multiple exposure. The third segment returns to the initial focused energy of the first movement with the shadows coming back, and ends with the men in a muscle-beach pose facing camera flashbulbs before the final blackout.

This piece was premiered during the CCP Dance School’s 14th Summer Dance Workshop under a different title, Photography, A Gentleman’s Honor,the title of the Philip Glass music which was used originally for the ballet. It was included in the program for Ballet Philippines’ performances at the 50th anniversary celebration of the American Dance Festival in North Carolina in Jun 1984. Filipino composer Fabian Obispo was commissioned to write a totally new score for the ballet.

The revised version in Obispo music became very popular among American critics, who described it as “delightfully unpredictable and original” and “the company’s best work, and the only one with a thoroughly modern look.” It has since continued to reap rave reviews in countries like the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, China, France, Singapore, Taiwan, Japan, Hong Kong, and India. Written by Edna Vida

Nasalapu-an, University of the Philippines Diliman, Quezon City, 2013

(Lawrence Edward Ng, photo courtesy of Angella Betina Carlos)

text:
(Birthing). 2013. Contemporary ballet in one act and four scenes. Choreography, Angella Betina Carlos and Japhet Mari Cabling; music, Toni Muñoz with Hazel Gutierrez on bamboo flute and djembe; costume design, Carlo Valderrama; lighting design, Sueyen Austero; set design, Ohm David. Premiered by the dance major students of the University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman on 21 Mar 2013 at the College of Music Annex Garden, UP Diliman. Lead dancers: Michael Barry Que (man), Marielle Joy Baylocon (woman), Gillianne Therese Gequinto (babaylan), and Rolinda Gilbaliga (chanter).

Nasalapu-an, or birthing in Hiligaynon-Kinaray-a dialect, is a contemporary ballet choreographed as part of Sa Kamalig: Manood, Makinig (In the Granary: Watch, Listen), the production of Carlos and Cabling in 2013.It is a choreographic translation of the Panay Bukidnon tribe’s binanog (hawk dance) and their birth ritual into contemporary dance. It is based on the research and fieldwork done by the choreographers and co-researcher Michael Que. Since chanting is a component in the tribe’s birth ritual, the choreographers suggest this with the use and manipulation of colored cloths to symbolize the different functions of the chants; thus, the use of cloths introduces each segment of the ballet.

The ballet opens with a chant in Kiniray-a by Rolinda Gilbaliga, a Panay Bukidnon native, asking the gods to bless the child. She holds a long white cloth, unfolds it as she sings, and then hangs it on a bamboo pole. This creates an illusion of the literal “passing through” of the chant to the cloth which the woman in a later scene pulls on as she gives birth. The chant slightly overlaps with the dance of two groups of women stomping around the space, mirroring each other’s movements and depicting a flock of birds. Each one holds a cloth, and all move together like birds soaring high. This scene called the “Pagpapakilala at Pagpili ng Napupusuang Babae” (Introducing and Choosing the Chosen Woman) also introduces the male protagonist who chooses his bride indicated by the play of scarves. The steps are close to the original binanogwith its stomping, leaning back, and capturing of each other with scarves.

After this, the man and the woman tie the ends of their scarves to signify their union, in a duet titled “Pagtatalik” (Lovemaking). This has the enticing counter-pulling of the tied scarves. Then the couple moves among nine girls with their own scarves. They weave in and out of the girls, and pause at several points to show the passage of time. Meanwhile, the nine girls vigorously flourish their own scarves, hop, rock, and stomp. These girls represent the nine months of pregnancy, while the stage space indicates time. After the section with the nine girls, the scarves are then tied together to encircle the woman. They surreptitiously put their scarves under the woman’s blouse and then exit. With this the woman is revealed as pregnant and ready to deliver. The man then seeks the babaylan’shelp to drive away the evil spirits that may make his wife’s delivery difficult.

The next scene is “Nasalapu-an” (Birthing). A babaylanenters with a large red cloth. She goes into a trance—undulates, isolates parts of her body, turns, and extends her legs and arms, all the time flourishing the cloth to drive away the evil spirits. Then the babaylan places her cloth over the woman, symbolizing the chant’s efficacy. To indicate birthing, the woman pulls on the white cloth that was earlier hung by the chanter on the pole. She mirrors the movements of the babaylan and joins her in pleading to the gods. To dramatize this scene, the corps of dancers surrounds the couple while beating their sticks on standing bamboos which make up the set. They count from one to nine in Tagalog, and go faster and faster to climax the scene with the child’s birth.

Again the chanter enters to sing the same chant she sang at the beginning, but this time in Tagalog. After this, she dances the authentic binanog to thank the gods. As a community, the dancers join her in a dance as done by the traditional Panay Bukidnon, all to mark the birth of the child in this last scene called “Pagdiriwang”(Celebration).

After the show’s premiere the choreographers were invited by Professor Christine Muyco of the UP Diliman College of Music to present Nasalapu-an in Pagbayaw: A Conference on the Sugidanon in UP Visayas-Iloilo in 2013. The piece was performed by the Claravall-Gonzales School of Ballet at the UP Visayas-Iloilo auditorium. Written by Angella Betina Carlos with notes from Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz and Ruth Jordana L. Pison

“Asalto for Maria,” part of Noli Dance Suite, CCP, Manila, 2011

(Niki de los Reyes-Torres)

text:
1955. Modern ballet in one act and five scenes. Choreography, LeonorOrosa-Goquingco ; music, AntonioMolina, FelipePadilladeLeon, LucreciaR.Kasilag, Leonor Orosa-Goquingco and Luisa Torres, and Nonato. Stories, JoseRizal. Premiered on 17 Jun 1955 at the Girl Scouts of the Philippines Auditorium. Dancers: RosalindaL.Orosa and Jose R. L. Orosa/Erlinda Benetua and Gilbert Perez/Rachel Goquingco and Ronnie Alejandro (Maria Clara and the Leper); Remy Yrastorza and CesarMendoza, Anita Buendia and Juan Singson (Salome and Elias); Ofelia Gaerlan (Sisa); Eric Abad Santos/Alvaro Arayata (Basilio); Diana Javier, Marcia Ruiz, Lydia Lim Gandionco (The Gossips); Carmen Blanco/Nita Hontiveros/ Rachel Goquingco/Regina Goquingco (Maria).

The story of the one-act ballet includes several episodes from Rizal’s NoliMe Tangere (Touch Me Not). “Maria Clara and the Leper” is set on the eve of the town fiesta, when Maria Clara meets the town leper. Not having anything else to give, she drops before him the diamond-studded locket Kapitan Tiago has but recently presented to her. The choreographer has changed the site from the street to the church interior. Music is by Antonio Molina.

“Salome and Elias,” based on an unpublished chapter of the NoliMeTangere,shows Salome, the sweetheart of Elias as the unhappy victim of misfortune and oppression. A young barrio lass, she awaits Elias. He arrives, and the two dance the joy of reunion. A friend signals that civil guards are near. Elias leaves. Music is by Felipe Padilla de Leon.

“The Gossips” is a Terpsichorean caricature of Rizal’shermanaswhich is inspired by a single line from the novel: “Sisafelt their icy stare and heard their whispers.” Music is by Lucrecia R. Kasilag.

“Sisa” shows the demented Sisa after Crispin’s death, “smiling, singing, and talking with the creatures of wood and field.” She runs after a butterfly, falls, and bruises herself. The moments of her deepest anguish return. These are eased by the sweet recollection of a babe in her arms. Suddenly, out of the shadows, she imagines seeing the evil Doña Consolacion, who, to make her dance, has whipped her with the Alferez’s whip. She relives the episode. Sisa’s son Basilio, who has been looking for her for days, witnesses the scene. She does not recognize him. She tries to flee but is too exhausted. She falls. Basilio approaches and finds his mother dead. The boy throws his arms around her and weeps. Music is by Leonor Orosa-Goquingco and Luisa Torres.

“Asalto for Maria Clara” opens with Maria Clara at the azotea,sad and alone. It is her birthday, and none of her friends seem to have remembered. But her friends give her anasaltoor surprise party. The bits of innocent merriment are typical of Maria Clara’s circle of friends. Music is by Nonato.

“Maria Clara and the Leper,” to Molina’s Preludioy Romanza (Prelude and Romance),was premiered at the Escritores Hispanistas Velada de Gala on 18 Jun 1946, at the old Villamor Hall of the University of the Philippines. In 1965, Orosa-Goquingco created a new “Maria Clara and the Leper” to Molina’s Malikmata (Phantasm), and added “Salome and Elias,” “Sisa,” “The Gossips,” and “Asalto for Maria Clara.”

Noli Dance Suite represents the dance part in Orosa-Goquingco’s production of A Rizal Sketchbook, which also includes her original play, My Son, Jose, and some songs by Jose Rizal. In 1957, NoliDanceSuite was performed with Orosa-Goquingco’s TheFirebird and The Clowns, by the MusicPromotionFoundationof thePhilippines at the Far Eastern University Auditorium in a triple bill titled A Ballet andDance Concert.

“Asalto for Maria Clara” became part of Filipinescas:PhilippineLife,Legendand LoreinDance, and was shown, together with a recreation of “Maria Clara and the Leper,” to a modern-day audience in Celebrazione ’89,which marked Orosa-Goquingco’s golden year as choreographer. Both performances earned standing ovations. Written by Leonor Orosa-Goquingco

text:
1958. Dance drama in one act. Scenario and choreography, RosaliaMerino-Santos , based on a short story by AlejandroR.Roces; music, LucreciaR.Kasilag ( Fantasie on a Four-noteTheme )arranged by Edith Albaladejo-Dizon; costume design, Esmeraldo Josue; lighting design, Justo Montemayor. Premiered by the FEUModernExperimentalDanceWorkshop (later called Group) at the Far Eastern University (FEU) Auditorium on 19 Dec 1958.

The dance drama was restaged on 20 Sep 1979 by BalletPhilippines at the Cultural Center of the Philippines, with set and costume design by SalvadorBernal, and lighting design by MoninoDuque. The story of this one-act dance drama revolves around an ancient Filipino king whose crown is coveted by his two sons. When the king falls ill, the rivalry turns heinous, as the siblings plot to hasten their father’s death.The god Bathala is so incensed that he turns the two princes into roosters. As roosters, the brothers continue to fight, especially in the traditional cockfight.The modern ballet occasions the delineation of their characters and motives, their schemes and conflicts.

Critic MorliDharam (1958) believed that the piece evoked “the universal sentiments of love and hate and avarice and terror and awe but all within a unique Philippine context” and thought it to be “a contribution to the world’s treasury of dance dramas.”.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

text:
1979. Solo dance in three parts. Concept and choreography, Denisa Reyes . Premiered in 1979 in New York City, in the concert titled Neo-Filipino.

This solo and the concert proved crucial in Reyes’s choreographic development. The name “Neo-Filipino” eventually became the title of a choreographic series which best articulated Reyes’s main choreographic interest.

One Ton Pinay, which is composed loosely of three parts, is a 15-minute solo where Reyes grapples with the subject of Filipino identity vis-à-vis colonial mentality, patriarchy, and Catholic suppression of sexuality. In a voice-over phone conversation, the woman soloist reveals that she is a waitress in New York. In a casual and carefree manner inflected by an American accent, the woman says she feels “othered” in this foreign country. A subsequent phone call disrupts her earlier brashness, self-confidence, and liberated attitude, replacing these with meekness, physical subservience, and a kind of obedience borne out of a Catholic upbringing. She is talking to her mother in the Philippines. From this palette, Reyes illustrates the contradiction of being a Filipino. As the woman reflects on her image on a mirror, her multiple selves unfold and unravel.

Between conversations that are heard as subtext in her mind, the woman articulates through her body the different cultural influences on the Filipino identity. That identity is a melange of Hispanized rural folk dances with gestures indicating Catholic fervor, traces of southern Philippine Muslim dance steps, interspersed with and disrupted by American military and jazz music. The solo climaxes in an appropriation of Cordillera dance and music, but it is at this point when the woman, in utter frustration, dances in frenzy and confusion. Getting a hold on herself, she then folds her skirt away, seemingly hiding her own contradictions from the audience. She snaps back to the present, and engages in another phone call.

Reyes’s piece bemoans the loss of the Filipino self and soul. In depicting the contradictory present linked to a complex past, Reyes traces the imprint of colonialism on the Filipino body that has perhaps, even altered the Filipino soul. Indeed, this lone woman in New York who waits on tables and serves the former colonizer of her home country, is tragic yet gallant in the ways she strives to survive and negotiate her contradictory realities. With the play on the words “one ton” and “wanton,” Reyes’s solo takes a semi-autobiographical, self-reflexive stance that challenges too-neat conceptions of Filipino identity. Written by Myra Victoria C. Beltran

text:
(A Plea: A Mail-Order Bride Story). 1991. A contemporary dance solo with a narrator. Scenario and choreography, Kristin Jackson ; music, Francisco Santiago’s “Pakiusap”(Plea) recorded by Kuh Ledesma; light design, Suzanne Poulin; costume design, Cathy Hazeltine; set design, Genara Banzon and Warwick McLeod. Premiered at Dia Art Foundation on 5 Sep 1991, New York. Cast: Kristin Jackson as dancer and Ramon Hodel as narrator. Philippine premier in Ballet Philippines Neo-Filipinoseries on 12 Nov 1992 at Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). Cast: Kristin Jackson and Wendy Panganiban (alternating between 12-15 Nov), and Audie Gemora as narrator.

On stage are two folding screens, one standing and another, flat on the floor. A man walks in to introduce a story. It is about the seated woman dressed in a skirt and a blouse cut as a kimono. By the folded screen on the ground, she repetitively mimes rural tasks like clearing the ground, planting, harvesting, and winnowing. Then she carries the folded screen on her back and plods upstage. Beside the screen she mimes preparing food, offering it to an unseen person, and receiving payment. Again she moves away, now to downstage-right. There she dances sensually as though to entertain a client-spectator. All throughout, the narrator dispassionately watches her. He leads her upstage-right to the second, standing screen and opens it to show a heap of clothes. From there the woman picks up a white chemise and a white flower. She goes to the left, puts on the shift and the flower on her hair. Looking dejected, she sits, raises her hands only to lower them on her lap. Alerted to the singing of Santiago’s “Pakiusap,” she rises and goes into a spell of abstract dance-moves. She goes back to the standing screen. There, she dips and zips herself into a lacy white gown from the floor. The narrator arranges the two screens beside her, to box her in. Before he finally does, she stops him, holds on a panel, and closes herself in. An overhead light starkly shows her silhouette. Slowly she sinks down with an upraised hand, until she completely disappears from view.

Suggesting an immaculate Madame Butterfly, the woman contrasts her dutifulness with her commodification. All along this is how the narrator advertises her, a packaged bride, sealed in her uncertain fate, yet a source for cash for those at home. Pakiusap shows these with candor and forceful conception. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

text:
(Cleansing). 1989. A staged Bagobo ritual dance. Choreography, Ramon A. Obusan ; evocative accompaniment with voices and rattling sounds played off-stage. Performed in Ritual: Rare by the Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group, at the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, Cultural Center of the Philippines, 1 and 2 Sep 1989.

Thepamaluguis part of the four-day Bagobogin-um,a river ritual officiated by two characters. One is a Bagobodatuor chief who addresses Tigayama, protector of men, and Pamulak Manobo, creator of nature. The other is ababaylan(female shaman) who offers betel nuts to the gods in a shrine, and gathers branches and flowers of the areca. Both minister to the datu’s sons and other Bagobo youths, all imitating flying eagles to attain the status ofbagani(warrior).This rite supposedly washes away “sins” and leads to a new life (Obusan 1989).

In the staged ritual, the youths are dressed in knee-length pants and open shirts or jackets, both dyed with geometric patterns. Wound around their heads are colorful kerchiefs. Tied to their arms are wooden shields representing wings of eagles. The babaylan wears a sweeping dark skirt and loose blouse. In a short prologue, she brandishes around the areca branches to call on the spirits. She dips the branches in an imaginary river on stage and with its water anoints the youths on their heads. This is done nine times, repeated when the men face the east. All these transpire to the eerie sounds of a wild forest, created by voices, creaking sounds, and rattling gongs.

The scene gets more active as the young men run and leap toward a suggested boulder downstage right corner. Their arms and shields look like wings in flight. At turns or intervals, they run, leap, and fall, in an attempt to fly. Obusan describes each one as “a newly hatched egret ready to try his wings against his enemy, the menacing wind” (Obusan 1989). At the end, they succeed and earn the status of bagani. In an epilogue, the babaylan returns to “close the forest once more, only to be opened for the next Pamalugu” (Obusan 1989).

The dance conveys the thrill of running and saulting, falling and rising, boldly attempted by the bagani individually or together. Portraying vigor and valor, the dance captivates with its kinesthetic dynamism and the exclusive mystery of the ritual happening in a dark forest by a river.Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

Source

Obusan, Ramon A. 1989. RITWAL: Rare and Unpublished by the Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group. Video documentary. Manila: Cultural Center of the Philippines.

text:
(Dream/Dreaming). 1991. A staged Matigsalug folk dance. Choreography, Ramon A. Obusan ; music with live gongs; traditional costumes. Presented by the Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group in Unpublished Dances of the Philippines-II at the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, Cultural Center of the Philippines on 25 and 26 Oct 1991.

The dance tells the story of a barren Matigsalug woman in Bukidnon who dreams of having a daughter. For mothers, a daughter opens the prospect of securing a bountiful dowry. Pandamgo tells its story in episodes before a seated audience. At the start, the mother sings to a baby represented by a folded cloth ormalong(tubular skirt). She shuffles and shuttles around a small space. A little girl, dressed like her mother, enters and dances. With a slight stoop, the mother circles the girl and prettifies her. They dance an affectionate duet. In the next segment, the daughter is replaced by a young lady in similar clothes and ornaments. Again, the dance revolves around the daughter, with the mother ministering to her looks and needs. Then a young man shuffles in to join them. He solicits the attention of the young woman and offers her a necklace to represent his suit. The mother, however, does not like the man. Another man joins the trio, and he also offers another necklace to the young lady. The mother shows she favors this man, but the young woman refuses the necklace of the second man because she likes the first man. The circular shuffling leads to the young woman’s explicit rejection of the second man. She throws his necklace to the ground. Because of this, a fight ensues between the two suitors. With long knives, they battle each other in a circle. The combat results in the death of both men and the women grieve over their favored one.

Pandamgo shows a mother’s story of raising a daughter. For the dance, the mother is dressed in traditional embroidered long-sleeved blouse and a multicolored woven malongfolded over her waist. Around her waist and hips is a brass belt made of strung chains that end in clinking bells. She also wears a necklace of beads, complemented by rows of beads over her hair. Her daughter, both as a little girl or adult wears a similar costume. For mother and daughter, the necklace is a running motif. The men wear dark-colored open shirts (jackets) and knee-length pants, both dyed and embroidered with geometric patterns. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

text:
(Peter the Cook). 2003. Modern ballet in one act. Choreography by Herbert Alvarez and Elena Laniog; libretto by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz after the original Petrouchka by Alexander Benois and Igor Stravinsky; music by Igor Stravinsky; set design by Lex Marcos; costume design by Mimi Santos; lighting design by Shakira Villa. Premiered by University of the Philippines Dance Company (UPDC) with guest artists in 2003 at the Nicanor Abelardo Hall Auditorium, University of the Philippines. Cast: Rizal Maribbay (Pedro Kusinero), Ava Maureen Villanueva (Bailarina), Barney John Baris (El Kano), and Avel Bautista (Bugaw).

Pedro Kusinero is a deconstruction of the original ballet, 1911, set in a typical Russian fairground. Reset in Subic, Zambales, it calls attention to social and political issues in the Philippines, specifically the presence of American military bases. The four contending characters are Pedro Kusinero (Peter the cook), Bailarina (dancer-prostitute), El Kano (The American, a US serviceman), and Bugaw (Procurer-bouncer), all caught in a small bar-saloon by a US naval base. Pedro, an energetic but gawky cook, is infatuated with the club’s choice and seductive Bailarina. But she is more enticed by the suave and cocky El Kano. Considering this mismatched triangle, Bugaw relegates Pedro to the kitchen. There Pedro vents his frustration in a percussive but puny frenzy, with a ladle and a potcover. Together, the otherbailarinasentice the club clients by their sexually aggressive dancing. On the other hand, Bailarina and El Kano indulge in a flirtatious dalliance. Seeing this, Pedro rushes into the bar to disturb them. Offended, El Kano strangles Pedro to death and as a result, disorder and divided loyalties permeate the atmosphere. Bugaw tries to pacify everyone. Pedro’s body is dragged out before a policeman arrives. In the end, everything seems quiet and fine, until the ghostlike Pedro slowly walks across the stage, before the eyes of Bugaw, Bailarina, and Kano—as though to haunt them in a kind of revenge.

Later performances gained from greater exploration of movement and plot, and more intensity in the projection of social issues. In these productions, Pedro Kusinero became a signature role for Al Bernard Garcia, 2009, 2010; with remarkable portrayals as Bailarina by Jantu Revilla, 2009, and Chaya Joyce Baris, 2010; as El Kano by Gerlin Francisco, 2009, and Japeth Mari Cabling in 2010; as Bugaw by Herbert Alvarez, 2009, and Peter Partida, 2010. For 2009 and 2010, Carlo Valderama designed new costumes and Joseph Matheu provided the lighting design. The ballet was featured at the WiFibody Festival in 2009 at the Cultural Center of the Philippines. In 2010, during the 30th anniversary of the dance degree program at the UP College of Music, it was performed with the first live performance of Stravinsky’s music in the Philippines, played by the UP Orchestra conducted by Edna Marcil Martinez.Written by Angela Lawenko Baguilat and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

text:
1976. Abstract ballet. Choreography, RemediosdeOteyza ; music, Peter I. Tchaikovsky; costume design, Arturo Cruz. Performed by HarirayaBalletCompany at the Main Theater, now the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo of the, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). Dancers: Nida Onglengco, Rita Garda, Gina Katigbak, Malou Maglutac, and MaiquiMañosa.

The last four important performances of the ballet were in 1976, during the Nuit du BalletClassique at the CCP; in 1977, for the Divertissement Gala with ManiyaBarredo and Burton Taylor for the BalletFederationofthePhilippines at the Folk Arts Theater; in 1978, in the Tribute to Remedios de Oteyza program at the Meralco Theater; and in 1979, with BalletPhilippines at the CCP.

Considered the last important piece of Remedios de Oteyza for the Hariraya Ballet Company, this ballet is in the so-called abstract style, following the structure and dynamics of the first movement of the Tchaikovsky concerto. Similar to de Oteyza’s one-movement GriegPianoConcerto in A Minor,it has more contemporary touches. This “black and white” ballet is considered by many her best work.

In 1976, LeonorOrosa-Goquingco observed that “de Oteyza’s choreography to Tchaikovsky’s PianoConcerto demonstrated her preoccupation with classicism.” This author added: “It is in this kind of massive architectonics that Ms Oteyza is masterful at drawing out brisk flow and lambent lines from soloist (particularly female) and exact and exciting running formations from the corps de ballet. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

text:
1940. A suite of dances.Choreography and costumes, TrudlDubsky-Zipper ; music, Modeste Mussorgsky; picture backdrops, Hans A. Heimann (later with Robert Long for no. 5 and added scenic design by Ernest Korneld in 1961). Premiered by the Manila Ballet Moderne on 22 Nov 1940 at the Manila Metropolitan Theater. Restaged in 1941, and after World War II, in 1952 and 1961.

This suite of eight dances opens with a young woman in resplendent finery visiting an exhibition. Her promenade serves as transition to present the eight pictures. The first, “The Gnome,” reveals an unearthly Gnome half-hidden in the dense undergrowth of a primeval forest. Its dance builds on deliberate and slow lengthening of its body, as if trying to escape its own form. In contrast, “The Castle” finds a medieval scene and a sleeping troubadour who awakens to four elegant yet delicate princesses. He has amorous dalliances with them, each one seemingly unmoved by his fleeting attention. Romantic lyricism is evoked through the unhurried, leisurely movements and pace of the Middle Ages. At the end, the princesses return to the castle, the troubadour to his sleep, leaving the audience to wonder whether it was dream or reality. Easily the most impressive is “The Cart.” It shows a haggard-looking Dubsky-Zipper in a deep lunge, dragging behind three men linked at various levels. Against a bare tree backdropped by endless rows of barren, furrowed earth, she dramatically enunciates—in heavy, wearisome, segmented undulations—the hopelessness of the peasants in their toil. A spark of rebellion flashes, but hopelessness dispels the independent spirit. The cart symbolizes an eternity of toil. “Children in the Tuilleries” charms with its beribboned children in pastel shades, playing with a golden ball. Their energetic play develops into a petty quarrel, which is soon forgotten when they attend to the ball again.

A sharp, cleverly paced comedy, “The Marketplace” captures the inherent energy of vendors and onlookers. To spite a finicky spinster, the vendors connive to ignore a light-fingered thief. The rousing pace and staccato movements build up to an unexpected finish, leaving the audience laughing and breathless. As respite, “The Catacombs” captures the stillness and near-ritualistic mien of monks. In the silence of a Gothic crypt, the monks dance with minimal expression and movement. At the end, they dance with lighted candles which help to bring up the scene. In contrast, “The Witch” is vigorous. With her hair down and in her garb in hues of orange, gold and black, Dubsky-Zipper as the witch effortlessly displays her extraordinary ballon. From a crouch, she leaps to uncoil her body in the air, head thrown back. Then she spirals her torso as her arms circle overhead, legs tucked underneath her. She runs around an immense cauldron with flames effected by dancers in black, arms with red and yellow strips, simulating flames. For a breather, three affectionate cats slither close to her. She tires of them, resumes her jumps, and returns to her smoking cauldron.

The last painting, “The Great Gates of Kiev,” is performed in formal balance and linear movements.These emphases are repeated in the silver decor on the skirt, sleeves, pockets, belt, and headdresses of the Cossacks. Sequential, straight arm movements, rebounding points of the feet, and formal groupings symbolize the gates of Kiev.

A.V.Hartendorp sums up his impression of the ballet: “One can hardly conceive of a program more inclusive in scope and more perfectly balanced than that offered, which ranged from the lyric, through the dramatic and comic with an unfailing sense of proportion and value in line, movement and color, and which throughout gave evidence of her most original genius” (Hartendorp 1940).Written by Corazon Generoso-Iñigo

text:
(Rama, King). 1980. Rock opera ballet in two acts. Choreography and stage direction, AliceReyes ; music and musical arrangement and direction, RyanCayabyab; libretto, BienvenidoLumbera, with English translation by RolandoS.Tinio; lighting design, KatschS.J.Catoy; set and costume design, SalvadorBernal. Premiered on 8 Feb 1980 by BalletPhilippines at the Main Theater, now the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, of the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP). Cast of dancers and singers: NonoyFroilan / Robert Medina, and BasilValdez (Rama); EsterRimpos / Effie Nañas, and KuhLedesma (Sita); Butch Esperanza and Leo Valdez (Ravana); EdnaVida and Gigi Escalante (Soorpanakha). Accompanied by the CCPPhilharmonicOrchestra, session musicians, and ethnic percussionists. Other dancers who portrayed the roles: Alice Reyes, ManuelMolina, Gina Katigbak, Jun Mabaquiao, Jinn Ibarrola, HazelSabas, Sofia Zobel. Other singers: Ric Segretto, Jacqui Magno, Eugene Villaluz, Ray-an Fuentes, Roro Wijangco, Janet Sabas, Zebedee Zuñiga, Louie Pascua, Bimbo Cerrudo, Celeste Bueno, Isay Alvarez.

A Filipino modern rock opera ballet adaptation of the Indian classic, the Sanskrit epic poem TheRamayana,the ballet tells of the adventures of Rama, prince and incarnation of the God Vishnu, who comes to earth to save the world from Ravana, the most powerful of demons. It dramatizes his love for Sita, and the trials he must undergo before he becomes a mighty ruler.

Act 1 opens with Rama and his brother Lakshmana being warmly welcomed home by the people of the kingdom of Mithila. Later, the brothers hear that Sita, the beautiful daughter of King Janaka, is throwing aswayamwara,a contest by which a girl would choose a husband for herself. At the said occasion, Rama meets Sita, and he immediately falls for her. After passing a tough test given by King Janaka, Rama is wedded to Sita in a grand and royal ceremony. Meanwhile, the ailing King Dasaratha has already decided to pass on the crown to his son, Rama—a gesture that angers Kaikeyi, Dasaratha’s third wife. Aided by the dubious Kooni, Kaikeyi plots to disrupt the coronation of Rama. In exchange for saving the king’s life in the past, Kaikeyi demands that her son Bharatha be crowned king, and that Rama be banished from the kingdom. Dasaratha reverses his decision, and Rama is exiled with Sita and Lakshmana.

Act 2 follows the journeys of the three exiles as they head for the woods of Panchavati, where the chameleonlike demon Ravana persistently attacks the lovely Sita, even as the impish Soorpanakha, Ravana’s sister, wildly pursues Rama. Lakshmana mutilates Soorpanakha’s ears, nose and breasts; and Ravana, avenging his sister’s mutilation and using various disguises, succeeds in abducting Sita. The aggrieved Rama seeks the help of Sagreeva, king of the monkey people in Kiskinda. The king, who is indebted to Rama who helped him regain his crown, orders his army and his general, Hanuman, to assist Rama in rescuing Sita from the lair of Ravana. The battle is later won by Rama, Sagreeva, Hanuman, and the monkey army. Rama kills Ravana and Sita is freed. In the end, the people of Mithila celebrate the return of Rama and Sita with Lakshmana, and their coronation as rulers of Mithila .

Alice Reyes interprets the ballet in the rock opera medium in two acts and nine scenes, as a way of introducing the Indian classic to contemporary Filipino audiences. Instead of separating the singers from the dancers, as in her previous hits, Tommy and TalesoftheManuvu,Reyes challenged herself in Rama, Hari by weaving them in and out of dancers and dances. She also used diverse elements of Asian theater, such as the shadow play and various hand props, as well as Indian dance movements interpreted in modern choreography.

Librettist Lumbera wrote a script with varying levels of usage: an elevated diction for the protagonist and Filipino slang for the demons Ravana and Soorpanakha. The theatrical reason for this, he explains, was that “the intrusion of a very contemporary diction could jar the audience into perceiving that the ancient epic of India is also ‘now’ and ‘Filipino’.”

Complementing Lumbera’s libretto is Cayabyab’s musical score, which incorporated the Filipinokundiman, Indian melodies, Asian percussion and popular tunes in his first rock opera ballet composition. Designer Bernal, in keeping with the theme of Rama, Hari,designed sets and costumes in a stylized Oriental look which were further enhanced by Catoy’s lighting design.

After its premiere presentation in Manila, Rama,Hari was performed by Ballet Philippines at the Musika Malaysia Festival in May 1981; the Sixth Hong Kong Festival of Asian Arts in Oct 1981; the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei, Taiwan in Nov 1982; and during the Visayan-Mindanao Cultural Circuit Tour, sponsored by CCP, in Jun 1982. Written by Edna Vida
