text:
1998. Modern dance in two acts. Artistic direction and choreography, Denisa Reyes ; music, Rahayu Supanggah; libretto, Nicanor G. Tiongson; lighting design, Katsch S. J. Catoy, Shoko Matsumoto, and Joey Nombres; set design, Salvador Bernal; costume design, Salvador Bernal; videography, Ami Miciano and Mark Gary. World premiere on 16 Dec 1998 at the Hanoi Opera House in Vietnam.Original cast: Rudy de Luna, Jr (Rama), Sirilak Songklib (Sita), S. Pamardi (Ravana), Aries Clemeno (Lakshmana), Pham Anh Phuong (King Dasaratha), Meenakshy Bhaskar (Kaikeyi), Manop Meejamrat (Bharata), Kuo Jing Hong (Surphanaka), I Gusti Ngurah Sudibya (Khara), Saveng Seng A Phay (Hanuman), and U Thein Aye (Golden Deer).

In 1997, the ASEAN Committee on Culture and Information (COCI) organized integrated, high-impact projects that would promote ASEAN awareness within and outside the region. The Philippines proposed Realizing Rama, a collaborative modern dance production based on the Asian epic Ramayana, as one of these flagship projects. The proposal was approved by COCI and the project planning began in mid-1997 with the proponent Nestor Jardin as project director. The production team was composed of representatives from the ten ASEAN member countries. The cast consisted of twenty-two traditional, classical, and contemporary and dance artists from the ten member countries.

Tiongson wrote the libretto for the full-length production as a contemporary adaptation of the epic. He focused on the theme of selfless leadership with Rama representing the ideal statesman. The production consists of a prologue, two acts with five scenes, and an epilogue. The prologue, set in the Kingdom of Ayodhaya, depicts the competition for the hand of Sita which Rama wins by bending the bow into the shape of a heart.

Act 1 begins with the wedding of Rama and Sita at the court of Ayodhaya. King Dasaratha decides to bequeath his crown to Rama but Kaikeyi, one the King’s three wives, objects and demands that her son, Bharata, be the anointed one. Exacting a debt of gratitude from the King, Kaikeyi succeeds and demands that Rama be exiled. Together with Sita (his Heart) and Lakshmana (his Mind), Rama traverses mountains and rivers, always trying to create a balance between heart and mind. He first encounters three monsters, representing the opportunism, frivolity and pragmatism of Wealth, which try to manipulate him. He is also seduced by Surphanaka, representing Lust, who tries to arouse his basic instincts. Lastly, he comes upon the monster Khara, representing Power, which entices him to manipulate people. With the help of Sita and Lakshmana, Rama’s willpower prevails and he successfully overcomes these temptations laid out by the evil God, Ravana. Undaunted by these failures, Ravana unleashes his monster machine of Wealth, Lust, and Power and lets loose the Golden Deer of Materialism to lure Sita as a prelude leading to her abduction.

Act 2 is set in the forest of Lanka where the army of Bali, composed of black monkeys, destroys the trees to feed Ravana’s monster machine. Rama aids Sugriva, King of the good monkeys, and his general Hanuman to battle and defeat the army of Bali. Meanwhile, Ravana attempts to seduce and force himself upon Sita but she drives him away. Hanuman is able to get to Sita who gives him her wedding necklace as a symbol of her undying love for Rama. Upon learning of Sita’s fate, Rama, assisted by Sugriva, Hanuman, and their army, builds a bridge to Lanka where they rescue Sita. In the final battle, Rama fights Ravana in a hand-to-hand combat symbolizing the fight between good and evil, and the struggle against poverty, environmental destruction, exploitation of labor, women, and children, and drug trafficking. Rama is victorious and gouges out Ravana’s black heart.

In the epilogue, Rama returns to Ayodhaya and ascends to the throne with Sita and Lakshmana beside him. Finally, after his travails, balance is achieved and he is freed from obsession with Wealth, Lust, and Power, thus transforming him into a true leader of his kingdom.

Reyes closely collaborated with the ASEAN dancers to create movements and choreographic patterns that fuse modern dance with indigenous, folk, and classical dances. While the result is an eclectic dance vocabulary, the contemporary dance base provides a choreographic style combining all the elements into a cohesive and expressive production. Rahayu Supanggah, a noted composer and ethnomusicologist from Java, created a contemporary musical score fusing traditional Javanese and ASEAN musical idioms, musical instruments. The visual aspects of the production which consist of costumes and sets by Salvador Bernal (later National Artist of the Philippines), lighting design by Katsch S. J. Catoy and subsequently by Shoko Matsumoto, as well as the videography by Ami Miciano and later on by Mark Gary, provided an effective visual support for the story-telling and choreography.

After the world premiere of Realizing Rama in 1998 in Hanoi on the occasion of the 6th ASEAN Summit, it had a second performance also in Hanoi and a third in Ho Chi Minh City. In Sep 1999, the artistic team revised and polished some aspects of the production before embarking on its first touring phase. From Sep 1999 to Apr 2000, the production toured the Philippines, Brunei Darussalam, Indonesia, Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, Lao PDR, Myanmar, and Cambodia, thus completing its circuit tour of ASEAN. The success of the show was evident in the rave reviews it received from critics.

Realizing Rama ’s huge impact on creating ASEAN awareness prompted the COCI to organize tours of the production outside the region. From May to Jul 2001, it was performed in four cities of Europe, namely Berlin, London, Luxembourg, and Brussels. In 2002, the show toured Seoul, Beijing, Hangzhou, Shanghai, New Delhi, Chennai, Bangalore, and Mumbai. The most successful run of the show was in India, the birthplace of the Ramayana. In Oct 2003, the production was restaged in Manila and brought to Japan for performances in Yokohama and Osaka. Its last performances were held at the Cultural Center of the Philippines Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo in 2006 as part of the 31st UNESCO International Theater Institute World Congress.Written by Nestor O. Jardin

951. Ballet in one act and 13 scenes. Choreography, AnitaKane ; music, Marcelino Carluen Jr; costume design, John Dolby. Premiered on 8 Jul 1951 at the Far Eastern University (FEU) Auditorium. Dancers: LucioSandoval (Spirit of the Philippines), ShirleySantos (Spirit of Virtue), Angelita Barredo (Spirit of Evil), Florencio Andrade (Spirit of Indecision), Jose Limlengco (Spirit of Urban Society), Amelia Medina (Spirit of Rural Society), Carmencita Barredo, Marinela Katigbak, Julia Roxas, Roberto Escolastico, Herminio Maximo. Accompanied by the Filipino Youth Symphony Orchestra conducted by Carluen with Consorcia Mercado at the piano.

Kane worked closely with Carluen on this ballet. She put into dance the exciting times of the reconstruction period after World War II. After the devastation of war, the people grabbed at any opportunity to survive. Then, they are swept by the forces of evil and seek profit at any cost. Finally, they embark on constructive industry to rebuild their lives. The spirit of virtue, unmasking evil, lets the true spirit of the Philippines grow in statesmanship and prosperity.

The scenes are: “Destruction and Devastation,” “The Will to Live as the Victory Parade Passes,” “The Dance of Youth,” “Revival of Society,” “Degradation of Society,” “Restlessness of Society,” “Evil Unmasked Is Blind,” “Awakening of State,” “The Revival of Morality,” “Industry Establishes a Normal Society,” “Statemanship Restores the Sight of Repentant Evil,” and “Consciousness of God.Written by Anita M. Kane

text:
1981. Three-act ballet with 12 scenes. Choreography, AliceReyes , based on the tragedy by William Shakespeare; music, Sergei Prokofiev; lighting design, MoninoDuque; set and costume design, SalvadorBernal. Premiered by BalletPhilippines on 14 Feb 1981 at the Main Theater (now Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo), Cultural Center of the Philippines. Dancers: Gina Mariano / Maricar Drilon (Juliet); NonoyFroilan (Romeo). Restaging in 1984: EsterRimpos and Nonoy Froilan alternated by ToniLopezGonzalez and BrandoMiranda (Romeo and Juliet); in 1988: AnnaVilladolid and Nonoy Froilan alternated by Nicole Gaston and ConradDy-Liacco (Romeo and Juliet).

This ballet closely follows Shakespeare’s plot. Alice Reyes uses a brisk pace, devising ways of changing sets and properties without intervals. Her intricate dance patterns for the group dances were cleverly woven into Prokofiev’s musical score. Her choreography heightened the pathos of this great Shakespearean tragedy, especially in the difficult death scenes

To highlight the choreographer’s translation of the plot into dance, Bernal’s designs of the costumes and set used color, material, and shapes that evoked the romanticism and tragedy of the story. In the catacomb scene, for instance, the ancestral statues of the Capulets loomed over the lovers in a scale that demonstrates the large social forces that dominate their lives. Duque’s atmospheric and poetic lighting, particularly in the chapel and balcony scenes, and in Juliet’s funeral procession in the Capulet crypt, highlighted the concept of Bernal’s design, and added to the dramatic commitment of the ballet. The magic spell cast upon Manila balletomanes by this production of RomeoandJuliet moved the audience to give Reyes a standing ovation for her first choreographic work in the classical ballet idiom.Written by Benita Maria P. text:
(At the Beginning of Life). 1991. Contemporary dance in one act. Choreography, Eli Jacinto ; music collage by Eli Jacinto from compositions of Joey Ayala, Lucrecia R. Kasilag, Bayanihan Dance Company, Roger Walters, Mike Oldfield, and Kayaw (Kalinga) recordings; music engineering, Jaime Sarthou; costume and lighting design by Eli Jacinto;costume execution by Paterno Booc and Marcelina Esplago. Premiered by Theatrical Ensemble and Artistic Movement (TEAM) Dance Studio on 14 Jun 1991 at the Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino, Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). Dancers: Jacqui Jacinto, Anna Marie Bartolome, Quincy Jacinto, Lucas Jacinto, Sol Ogatis, Joelle Jacinto, Cecilia Bartolome, Margarita Santos, Louella Alfonso. A smaller cast performed this work in 1992 at the Meralco Theater, with some rechoreographed sequences.

Jacinto was the recipient of the CCP’s 1991 venue grant, and he produced a mixed bill show titled Dating Gawi, Bagong Anyo (Old Ways, New Image). Included was a suite titled Sa Panimula ng Buhay, which explored the Filipino creation myth where the first peoples were molded from clay by Bathala (God), thereafter populating the world. Jacinto had been experimenting with abstract forms in the 1980s but started to adapt folk dance gestures into more fluid, contemporary movement later in that decade. He melded these two choreographic styles in Sa Panimula ng Buhay.

The first section is the creation myth, where a figure arises from the earth, shaking as if life were breathed into her body. She then becomes a medium for the unseen deity which starts to mold a second figure from the clay, grabbing light and air from the sky, pressing hands down on the figure’s back, and shaking violently as she breathes life into this new figure. “Breathe” is used to describe the movement because the accompanying soundscape is a recording of actual breathing—of inhaling and exhaling. When the two figures are formed, they squat side by side and assess the rest of the lonely earth, arms stretched out and resting over their bent knees, mouths pouting, resembling the traditional Ifugaobulolor rice deity icon.The two move across the stage, breathing life into several other bodies in succession, and therefore into the rest of mankind which, when fully formed, begin to dance. The second and third sections show the formation of the community, the people’s observation of the laws that were put in place, and the empowerment of their children. Still quite abstract, the dance has no story, only a general impression of what early civilization must have looked like. The movements are mostly a fusion of modern dance and folk dance steps, punctuated by modernized ballet poses and combinations.

One section has two female dancers sharply hopping on one leg while the other leg and both arms are bent angularly. The hands are thrown out as one leg straightens and the grounded foot rises on toes. The hopping is taken from folk dance, abstracted by the flexed feet and turned-in legs that are definitive of modern dance; the rising of the feet on toes is a relevé in ballet.The two women introduce tension in the otherwise placid community when they confront a male warrior. The warrior writhes on the ground while the chief female passes judgment on him as she steps into a posé attitude over his supine body, her arms raised in a V-form with hands flexed. The female corps behind them are in lower attitudes en fondu, the fingers of their flexed hands flicking as seen in several dances from the Cordillera region. Another section has the female dancers carrying two large bamboo poles across the stage while executing a simple, repetitive step-close pattern, to symbolize the building of material dwelling places.

Although all performers are dressed and dancing as a neutral corps de ballet in most parts of the work with, some dancers break out from the corps to perform a specific function, such as the medicine woman emerging from the bamboo poles in order to perform a blessing ritual. Her movements combine knee and head jerks, contracted bowing of the head to the ground in angular poses, and legs bent in a balletic second position. Jacinto’s work ends with a proud community, untouched by foreign influence. Jacinto draws much from his folk dance background when he performed for Rosalia Merino-Santos at FEU and the side projects of Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula. Contemporizing folk movements, which was Santos’s influence, was a signature of much of his later works, particularly Bathala (God), 1998; and Giri (Strut), 2004, both for TEAM Dance Studio; and Magdaragat (Seafarer), 1996, for Philippine Ballet Theatre. Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

text:
(Seven Sorrows). 1988. Moderndance in nine sections. Choreography, DenisaReyes ; libretto, NicanorG.Tiongson; music, Fabian Obispo; lighting design KatschS.J.Catoy; set and costume design, SalvadorBernal; visuals, Jaime Zobel. Premiered on 18 Feb 1988 by BalletPhilippines at the Tanghalang NicanorAbelardo, Cultural Center of the Philippines. Dancers: EdnaVida (Inang Bayan),ConradDy-Liacco, Jun Mabaquiao, Sofia Zobel, CecileSicangco, Tina Fargas, Paul Ocampo, and Edmund Gaerlan (Children of Inang Bayan).

Inspired by the seven sorrows of the Blessed Virgin Mary, the nine-section modern ballet shows Inang Bayan (Motherland, as the Philippine parallel to the Virgin) lamenting over the sorrows/problems faced by each of her seven children: the Youth, whose creativity and idealism are destroyed by the very social institutions (government, religion, education) which are supposed to protect and develop it; the Women, who still have to liberate themselves fully from male chauvinism; the Politicians, who shift from one political party to another for as long as their own personal interests are served; the Artists, who are still forced to conform to aesthetic standards that have been set by Spain and America; the Peasants, who have been enslaved for centuries by a feudal order that bends and shapes them to fit traditional feudal roles; the Military, who use violence and macho tactics on their own people to in the guise of preserving peace and democracy; and the Workers, who are forced to be cogs in a huge profit machine controlled by capitalism. At the end of the exposition of each section, Inang Bayan performs a dance exhorting her children to struggle free from the fetters that bind their own sectors, prefiguring the triumphs of each of her children and of the country as a whole. The performance ends as it began—with a child’s continuing search for the truth that will finally set the people free. Written by Edna Vida

1957. Folk dance choreography. Choreography, LucreciaReyes-Urtula ; music, Lucrecia R. Kasilag. Premiered by BayanihanPhilippineDanceCompany in 1957 in Manila.Lead dancer: HenriettaHofer (Princess).

The dance is based on an episode of the old Maranao epic poem, Darangen.The Prince Bantugan is noted for his amorous exploits. Thediwataor guardian spirits disapprove of the libertine exploits of Bantugan and want him tosettle down with a princess.The diwata decide to kidnap Princess Gandingan, whom they would like Bantugan to marry, and bring her to an enchanted forest where he will be passing. Passing through the forest, the prince feels an earthquake caused by the diwata. Gandingan herself is terrified, and to save herself, she leaps, jumps, and hops from rock to rock. Bantugan notices that even in her fright, her movements are light and graceful. He falls in love with Gandingan, and saves her from danger. As told by Maranao anthropologist Mamintua Saber, the dance imitates the graceful movements of Princess Gandingan as she leaps from rock to rock. Bamboo poles are struck together to imitate the crashing of rocks during earthquakes.

Bayanihan’s signature piece, Singkil,takes its name from the heavy metal anklets calledsingkilworn by Maranao princesses. It is also a Lanao court dance. Every young woman of royal blood is expected to learn this dance for her peers’ entertainment, but never for the public. The traditional dance was taught to Reyes-Urtula by Princess Tarhata Alonto Lucman. Written by Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula

text:
1978. Moderndance in one act. Choreography and costume design, Corazon Generoso-Iñigo ; based on a play by AmeliaLapeña-Bonifacio; music, Antonio Ruiz Pipo, William Walton, Mauricio Ohana; lighting design, Jose C. Generoso. Premiered by the UPFilipinianaDanceGroup in Mar 1978 at the University of the Philippines (UP) Theater. UP premiere cast: Nadine Guytingco (Sisa), DouglasNierras (Padre Salvi), Jinn Ibarrola (Basilio), Alex Lanag (Crispin), and Ma. Concepcion Alano, Alma Garcia, Leilani Ladera, Mercedes Locsin, and Annette Malixsi (Koro, fisherfolk, and townspeople). Restaged for BalletPhilippines on 20 Sep 1978 at the Cultural Center of the Philippines: new music, Lucrecia R. Kasilag; lighting design by MoninoDuque; costume and set design, SalvadorBernal. Cast: AliceReyes (Sisa), NonoyFroilan (Padre Salvi), Jinn Ibarrola (Basilio), NesJardin (Crispin), EdnaVida, Gina Mariano, Florence Perez, Emellie Rigonan, Malu Rivera, and Maribeth Roxas (Koro).

The modern ballet highlights the transformation of the characters in Jose Rizal’s Noli MeTangere (Touch Me Not). In the novel, Sisa is mute and defenseless, in the mold of the downtrodden peasants in the Spanish colonized Philippines while Padre Salvi, the antagonist, is the epitome of the arrogant colonizer, devoid of altruism and compassion. Drawing her picture from the Noli,playwright Lapeña-Bonifacio resurrected Sisa as vindictive and eloquent, and Salvi as troubled and repentant.

The ballet opens with Padre Salvi looking for Sisa’s grave to seek atonement for his sins. In the manner of thenoh,Sisa enters from the shadows, leading her two sons, Basilio and Crispin. They dance their thoughts and grievances, their bodies and arms often upturned to the heavens as if asking, “why?” They are linked to each other throughout, symbolic of the close bond between mother and sons. In the ensuing confrontation with Salvi, Sisa poignantly reviews, through merciless tirades, the events of her tragic life. She condemns Salvi to eternal unrest and warns the audience not to suffer in silence like her but to find their voices, declare their rights and finally recreate a free Philippines.

True to the traditional noh, a chorus of women with sphinx-like faces weave in and out of the scenes. They are all knowing, all-seeing, yet unmoved by the occurrences.The music combines the hispanic air and the emotion-filled, rhythmically diverseutai(the chanted text). The choreography follows the rhythmic patterns and moods evoked by the utai and added chants composed by AntonioMabesa. Written by Corazon Generoso-Iñigo

Star Maiden, Dance Forum Studio, Quezon City, 1997

(Norman Jaravata, photo courtesy of Myra Beltran Collection)

text:
1997. Full-length solo. Choreography, story based on folktale, and performance by Myra Beltran ; music by Johann Sebastian Bach. Premiered on 19 Mar 1997 at the Dance Forum Studio, Quezon City.

Star Maiden is a full-length solo comprising of seven dances tied together by a narration which presages each solo. Based on a folktale found in the Cordillera and Bukidnon regions in the Philippines, it is about a farmer and a star maiden who becomes his wife. The narrative about a farmer stealing the wings of a maiden who comes down from the heavens, a narrative signifying the marriage of heaven and earth, is a common motif among Asian folktales. Because it is believed that the Igorot Bontoc people come from the marriage of this farmer and the maiden, the tale is essentially an origin myth.

In Beltran’s version, the story is given a feminist reading and rendered in more poetic terms. While other feminists would read the story as a form of betrayal and a clipping of women’s powers, Beltran looks at the story in terms of the inner journey of a woman who realizes her gifts and powers and eventually experiences a rebirth.

All seven dances of five to seven minutes each with accompanying narration conveys the various steps taken in a mythic and inner journey. Loosely and visually based on various Philippine legends, all dances could be considered complete and stand-alone pieces.

In the first dance, “Silver Streak of Wings,” the maiden finds her broken wings hidden in an attic, a metaphor for the discovery of one’s woundedness. Beltran expresses in dance how the maiden as wife of the farmer, learns the earth’s various cycles—“of loving, dying, of giving one’s self, and of waiting.”

The second dance titled “Beginning” is about liberation. Beltran’s airy delicacy conveys a certain joy of solitude under the freedom of moonlight.

The third dance, “Cloak of Midnight,” is performed with three grey stones on the floor to establish a river setting that introduces floor work movements. The universe quietly grieves with the maiden, providing her comfort and enabling her to hear the “light tapping of wings” on the water, a reminder of her destiny to be free.

The maiden continues her journey by climbing a mountain to claim the lessons learned in her earthly life. The fourth dance titled “Rock Me to Sleep” renders the image of Sisyphus with Beltran pushing a rock-like set.

“Air,” the fifth dance, shows the maiden coming “to the edge of the earth” and with “just another stretch of soul,” she crosses the water. In the sixth dance, “Song,” the heavens celebrate the star maiden’s life on earth and lift her up to her original abode in a carpet of white flowers strewn across the floor. The final dance, “Star Maiden,” reveals that the narrator is actually the child of the star maiden and the farmer. The entire solo reaffirms the tale as a traditional origin myth made poetic by the presence of both the artist who is its storyteller and the artist as the child, the realization of the marriage between heaven and earth.

Beltran’s performance evokes the anguish of leaving a loved one despite one’s own decision to do so. Beltran’s willowy form shows the lines of classical ballet redefined in her own way within the intimate venue and non-proscenium stage. She conveys the story by using simple and minimal props like stones and flowers. Change in the color of costumes signifies the inner transformations of the maiden. Her movements express the shift in emotions and evoke the geography of the Philippine archipelago. The Philippine landscape is a shorthand for the mythic journey to the self; the traversing of land, mountain, and water parallels the transition to a new life, and finally to a rebirth.

Star Maiden ’s premiere in Mar 1997 marked the opening of a studio as an alternative performance space. The opening could be likened to a gathering of storytellers or shamans as Beltran’s studio is structured like thedap-ay(an indigenous house) of the Northern Philippines. The show was restaged for Casa San Miguel, Zambales, in 1998 and its various solos were shown separately on several occasions.

Star Maiden was crucial in Beltran’s choreographic career because it announced to the arts world the workings of contemporary choreography and production. The artist as producer, writer, choreographer, and dancer ushered in a new way of working as independent artist. Written by Ruth Jordana L. Pison

article_title: Suwana: A Reconstruction of a Myth
description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history
text:
1994. Modern ballet in two acts. Choreography, Denisa Reyes ; libretto, Al Santos; costume design, Ann Wizer; set design, Alwin Reamillo; lighting design, John Batalla; music collage, Denisa Reyes from compositions by Ryuichi Sakamoto, Laurie Anderson, Dead Can Dance, Michael Nyman, Laurent Petitgant, Graeme Revell, Disappearing World, and Sergei Rachmaninoff. Premiered by Ballet Philippines on 17 Mar 1994, at the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, Cultural Center of the Philippines. Cast: Ditchay Roxas (Suwana, the Storyteller), Camille Ordinario (Suwana, the Mirror and the Skeleton Woman), Cecile Sicangco (Mother), Gerard Mercado (Birdman and Fisherman), Melissa Cuachon (Maid), Wendy Panganiban (Prostitute), Grethel Domingo (Nun), Judell de Guzman (Housewife), with Dwight Rodrigazo, Monette Victoria, Anton Perez, Alden Lugnasin, Edmund Gaerlan, Lee Wen Chen, Brando Miranda, Jin Ibarrola, Edward Malagkit, Elmer Domdom, Neil Cambay, Orly de Leon, Victor Ursabia, Perry Sevidal, Annette Cruz, and Christine Crame. Suwana is played by two people. The actor Ditchay Roxas is Suwana the narrator and the private self, while the dancer Camille Ordinario is Suwana the mirror, and the public self, or how Suwana shows herself to other people. For example, when the public self gets married, the private self screams, “Huwag!” (Don’t!). Suwana’s grey-haired mother in blue also symbolizes both Mother Earth and the Wise Woman.

Suwana is seen as Reyes’s most feminist work, although she claims that it promotes the interdependency between man and woman, rather than denying a woman’s need for a man. As portrayed, the first section is Suwana’s retrospective account of her life, with Suwana commenting on it while watching. It is a very angry portrait of the roles women are forced to take on. The dance opens with a woman reflecting on her life, sitting in a hammock held aloft in the shape of a triangle across the cyclorama, made to resemble a vagina, while another older woman in blue is bound while giving birth. The woman in the hammock is actually watching over her own birth as she recites a story about a skeleton woman. She says, “Suwana,babae(woman) … Suwana,anak(child/daughter) … Suwana,kabiyak(partner) …” as if to declare the roles that she was born into. Other voices emphasize this imposition of roles, as they accompany the scenes from Suwana’s childhood with “yes” phrases, such as “Yes, dear,” and “Yes, sir.” There are negative phrases admonishing daughters, such as “Put down your skirt so that we don’t see your panties” or “You won’t find a husband if you act that way.” Overheard are common descriptions of a woman’s ideal man.

Both the public and private selves of Suwana dance with a group of girls who put on blouses onstage as they assume prescribed roles or costumes: office secretary, house maid, nun, and whore. When it is the whore’s turn to dance, only the private self dances with her while the rest watch, appalled. Ironically, the private self of Suwana and perhaps all the women seem to want to be as wanton and uninhibited as the whore. But the other women restrain themselves due to social constraints. Then the women put on long Maria Clara skirts, again taking on societal roles. Male characters enter the scene and dominate the last scene of the first section. They objectify the women, surrounding and watching them with blank faces. Other men dressed as priests enter when the Wise Woman falls to her death and they remove her body/presence. The men return to surround Suwana’s private and public selves, assume alternatively sexual and religious poses, before attacking her. The private self is tied to large ropes, in a position similar to how the Wise Woman was bound in the earlier birth scene. Meanwhile the men encircle the public self, forcing her into submission. When the public self successfully pushes the men away, the private self is freed from her bonds, after which the two selves embrace each other.

The second section is shorter and focuses on the story of the Skeleton Woman. The private self repeats her recitation of the story about a fisherman who pulls out his nets from the sea and finds the skeleton woman amid the garbage from the bottom of the ocean. While speaking, the fisherman sheds a tear while dreaming, and the skeleton woman drinks that tear as if it were a river. Then her bones fill out with flesh; she is made whole by the fisherman’s tear and by singing, she stirs a happiness inside him. They spend the rest of their lives together, singing and dreaming. In the dance, Suwana the mirror is also the Skeleton Woman. She and the fisherman discover each other through both violence and tenderness. She alternately grabs him and pushes him away, traumatized by her own past. In the end, she refuses to lose herself to the man. But they finally meet halfway and accept each other. Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

(Bayani ng Sayaw 1998 Dance Calendar, NCCA)

text:
1966. Folk dance choreography in one act. Choreography, LucreciaReyes-Urtula ; traditional music arranged by LucreciaR.Kasilag. Premiered by the BayanihanPhilippine DanceCompany in honor of Dr Francisca Tirona Benitez, Philippine Women’s University (PWU) president emeritus, on 4 Jun 1966.

The Tboli, also known as the Tagabili of Lake Sebu in South Cotabato, provides the subject for this one-act folkloric ballet. The theme is based on a research effort by the Bayanihan team headed by Helena Z. Benitez, with Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula, Jolly Benitez, and Ileana Maramag. The dances, chants, music, costumes, epics, folklore, brass work, and weaving were studied and gathered through the cooperation of the Santa Cruz Mission of Lake Sebu, with Fr Rex Marsmann, and Datu Mafok Yet-lu, the first of his four wives, and his people.

The plot sequence was inspired by a Tboli story that has traditionally been woven into a beautiful abaca cloth calledtinalak.The dramatic suite is a tale of retribution. A ruling datu has a favorite wife, who attempts to seduce her lord’s younger brother. In a fit of jealousy, the datu slays his brother.As punishment of the god Diwata, the datu’s one and only daughter falls ill. According to traditional Tboli belief, the daughter can only be saved through marriage. Neighboring tribes and four noble suitors vie for her hand, each with a different dance. A poet-prince is finally chosen by the princess, but she goes into a trance from which she never awakens. The tale ends with the symbolic burning of the datu’s house and village by the datu himself, in recognition of the death of his line and to get rid of the evil spirits lurking around.

After its premier, the dance was included in the Bayanihan’s repertory for its 1967-1968 world tour. It has since been periodically revived. Written by Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula

(Rudy Vidad, Ballet Philippines Collection)

text:
1977. Rock opera ballet in five parts. Choreography and stage direction, AliceReyes ; script and libretto, BienvenidoLumbera; music, Nonong Pedero and the Afterbirth; musical direction, ReyPaguio; lighting design, MoninoDuque; set design, Santiago de Manila. Premiered by the CCP Dance Company, now BalletPhilippines, on 25 Feb 1977 at the Main Theater, now the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, of the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP).Cast of dancers and singers: Gener Caringal and Boy Camara (Manama), TonyFabella and Anthony Castelo (Ogassi), ReyDizon and HajjiAlejandro (First Man), Gina Mariano and CelesteLegaspi alternating with Leah Navarro (First Woman),accompanied by the Afterbirth with the UPConcertChorus.

Tales of the Manuvu is a Filipino rock opera ballet in five parts. The play begins with a traditional prologue, “Tabbayannon,” in which the content and method of the presentation are explained. The story narrates the beginning of all things with the good god Manama who is surrounded bydiwata(guardian spirit)andanitoand is confident of his omnipotence.

Counteracting his powers is the evil god Ogassi who is assisted by thebusaw(bad spirits). With only akatungaw-tungawtree growing in his realm, Manama’s land is barren, in contrast to Ogassi’s which is lush with vegetation. This starts the enmity between them or between good and evil.

Manama is asleep for the greater part of the year, but wakes up for a brief while to get his divine tasks done. He thinks up Man and the entire skyworld is mobilized to realize his grand project. But when he dozes off, Ogassi manages to subvert the project and messes up Manama’s plan to give Man eternal life. When he comes to life, Man is only too grateful for the opportunity to explore the world, and cannot care about the brevity of existence. Defeated, Ogassi persists in creating discontent in Manama’s creature by asking Man why he is alone. In turn, Man asks Manama why he is without a counterpart. Manama knows that his creation would cease to depend on him once he is given a counterpart; however, to deny him a partner would be giving Ogassi his victory, and so Manama creates the First Woman. Ogassi stirs up indefinable longings in the First Woman. She is disconsolate over a sense of incompleteness she cannot understand. Before Ogassi scores another victory, Manama drops akakapa(worm) on the buttocks of man, whose resultant movements lead to the discovery of the pleasures of sex.In the course of time, Nature becomes less benign, and the goodwill among men disappears. Men and women pounding rice disrupt Manama’s sleep, and, in a fit of irascibility, he orders the skyworld to be raised beyond the reach of people so he can sleep unperturbed.

Now unhampered by his rival, Ogassi creates the giant Makarallig who drives people away from their lands, spreading death and destruction everywhere. Realizing that they have no one to turn to but themselves, the people organize themselves to fight off the giant, and succeed in driving the marauder and Ogassi away. The people realize through their struggle that they have within themselves the resources to create their own fate. Written by Edna Vida

text:
(Elopement). 1969. Modern ballet in one act and three scenes.Choreography, FelicitasLayag-Radaic; music, JuanSilosJr; lighting design, Mitos Villareal; set design, German Lazo; costume design, Marcella Lopez. Premiered on 24 Apr 1969 by DanceTheaterPhilippines (DTP) at the Meralco Theater.Dancers: Tina Santos / JulieBorromeo (Maria); Israel Gabriel (Kardo); TonyLlacer (Mang Basio); Pilar Borromeo (Doña Pepang); JoyCoronel / Delia Javier (Aling Tale); OdonSabarre (Lad).

Among the notable subsequent Marias have been FelicitasLayag-Radaic, Lourdes Dalupan, Malu Rivera, Mary Mae Asensio, SoniaDomingo, Mary Anne Santamaria, Heidi Domingo, LisaMacuja, Maritoni Rufino, and Katrina Santos. In 1972, Tanan was restaged for BalletPhilippines with sets by Johnny Manahan and costumes by ArturoCruz. In 1990, it was brought into the repertoire of PhilippineBalletTheatre with sets by Rollie de Leon and costumes by Arturo Cruz.

Scene 1 opens with Mang Basio flirting with Aling Tale, asari-sari(variety) storekeeper. A habitual drunkard andsabungero(cockfight enthusiast), Basio mimes out his vices and dances with Tale all the way up a long bench (a stylizedsayaw sa bangko) until he falls. A lad finishes the dance for him. Maria, daughter of the rich Doña Pepang, comes out with her friends and dances with her suitor, Kardo, son of Basio. But Doña Pepang comes looking for Maria, who hides among her friends. Spotted, Maria is pinched on the ear to an instantaneous blackout.

Scene 2 finds Maria unable to sleep, mooning around her room and preparing a bundle for an elopement. To guard Maria, Doña Pepang sits and dozes in a rattan rocking chair outside the door. Outside the house, Kardo and his father dance while carrying a bamboo ladder. Leaning the ladder by Maria’s window, the old man climbs up but falls upon Kardo’s whistled signal. Kardo climbs up.Basio is still on guard, but soon falls asleep. Inside, Maria is surprised in her chemise; with a shawl, she dances out her love with Kardo, with some sulking. Hearing the noise, Doña Pepang knocks on Maria’s door. Kardo scampers around but finally dives into a large bamboo clothes hamper. Maria pretends to sleep. With her sharp fan, Doña Pepang wakes Maria up and gesticulates her questions. At times, Kardo sticks his head out of the hamper. Doña Pepang catches sight of him and promptly faints.

Scene 3 witnesses the merrymaking of Maria and Kardo’s friends. A bamboo arch stands for a church door from where the bride and groom dance out, followed by Doña Pepang and Basio, followed in turn by Aling Tale. Photography freezes everyone in various poses for an instant. Then everyone files out in parade, dancing and miming the passing of a calesaas the music diminishes.

Tanan is a short but popular comedy, a ballet showing local color in dancing, acting, and the style of the production and costume designs. The music by Juan Silos Jr is made up of familiar folk melodies, arranged to fit exactly the swift scenes, short dances, and rollicksome miming. It has enjoyed 23 years of performances and has been danced in England, Scotland, Hong Kong, and in various Philippine provinces. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

Tchaikovsky Fantasy, Dance Theater Philippines, Meralco Theater, 1982

(Felicitas Layag-Radaic Collection)

text:
1982. Modern ballet. Scenario and choreography, Basilio ; music, Peter I. Tchaikovsky ( Souvenir de Florence ); lighting design, Raymond Salvacion; costume and set design, Raquel Rey.Premiered by DanceTheaterPhilippines on 20 Nov 1982 at the Meralco Theater, to herald the 90th death anniversary of the Russian composer Tchaikovsky in 1983. Dancers: AugustusDamian (Peter), AnnaVilladolid (Antonina), Sophia Radaic (Nadezhda).

This ballet had an earlier, capsulized version in 1976, Perjured Hearts (to Tchaikovsky’s “Autumn” in The Months ),choreographed for OdonSabarre (Peter), VellaDamian (Nadezhda), and Josette Salang (Antonina). In some way the notes to that piece summarizes Tchaikovsky Fantasy :“A lyric and liberal interpretation of Tchaikovsky’s affairs. He and Madam (Nadezhda) von Meck, his patroness, were supposed to have never met but exchanged ardent letters, while Antonina, his wife of an impulsive marriage, he never truly loved.” The latter ballet further develops a “fantasy” about this aspect of the life of the composer. The added corps de ballet also functions as a chorus.

Before the curtain rises, the theme of the “Allegro con Spirito” is established. The stage opens on three cages which enclose the three main figures of the ballet. One of the cages rises, freeing Antonina to dance her feelings out with the corps de ballet. After a brief absence, she returns to draw out Peter from his caged spot to dance with her, and Nadezhda to establish her mysterious presence. The dance of Antonina and Peter grows from hesitancy to fuller involvement. In the “Andante Cantabile e con moto,” Nadezhda replaces Antonina in a pensive solo. Then Peter joins her for an involved pas de deux. The two avoid each other’s eyes—to suggest that in real life they were never close. A series of swirling musical and dancing passages separate them. Left alone, Peter gives vent to his longings and anguish to a sad melody. Three female “images” confront him, but they are later replaced by the more real Antonina and Nadezhda who surround him. He turns perplexed, and is left as though awakening from a dream. The “Allegro Moderato” has Russian qualities to which the mature Nadezhda, in an authoritative solo of balances and turns, and the young Antonina, in her own brisk solo of rhythmic and directional changes, dance out character and classical steps and poses. The final “Allegro Vivace” is introduced by the corps in a linked and weaving dance. Peter dances before them jovially, Antonina dances to be encircled by part of the corps, and Nadezhda, too, surrounded by her own side. Peter brings both of them to his center spot and dances with them briefly, after which the corps seems to push them upstage like waves. With the complete corps of eight somehow screening them from the audience, Peter lifts Nadezhda while Antonina falls by his feet in a final tableau. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

(Ballet Philippines Collection)

text:
1985. Moderndance.Choreography, DenisaReyes ; music, Georges Bizet; costume design, SalvadorBernal; lighting design, KatschS.J.Catoy. Premiered by BalletPhilippines on 8 Nov 1985 at the Main Theater, now Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, of the Cultural Center of the Philippines. Dancers: HazelSabas, Mercedes Mañago, ConradDy-Liacco, NonoyFroilan, CecileSicangco, Tina Fargas, Jinn Ibarrola, Romy Roxas.

Reyes choreographed the piece during a period of political uncertainty. Taking an age-old and deeply rooted religious theme and one of the world’s most beautiful hymns, she embarked on an interpretation that reflected her own ambiguities about national issues.Set against the huge cross with a halo-host at its center, the ballet develops movements that crystallize into symbolic visions of the Carrying of the Cross, the Crucifixion, the Pieta, and the Resurrection and Transfiguration of Jesus Christ. The spasmodic and angular movements vividly evoke Reyes’ inner anguish and turmoil as a Filipina beset by her country’s ills.The result is a unique and refreshing dance interpretation of musical scores and hymns. Written by Edna Vida and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

photos.photodesc: Testament, Dance Theater Philippines, Hong Kong, 1980 (CCP Collection)

text:
1998. Modern ballet in three movements. Choreography and scenario, Basilio ; music, Bela Bartok ( Piano Concerto No. 3 );projections, OfeliaGelvezon-Tequi; costume design, Raquel Rey; lighting design, Raymond Salvacion. Premiered by DanceTheaterPhilippines (DTP) on 19 Oct 1980 at the City Hall Recital Hall, Hong Kong. Dancers: Gina Katigbak (Protagonist), Marivic Mapili Vela (Vision), Mary Anne Santamaria and RicardoElla (Horizon pas de deux), LisaMacuja, RupertAcuña, and Victor Madrona (Tetrad and pas de quatre).

This ballet in three movements was premiered by DTP for the Festival of Asian Arts. When the curtain rises, a woman (Protagonist) with fire designs on her body is caught alone in a weighted pose. She dances perturbed. Soon other dancers similarly costumed rush about and sustain her, but they all go away. The Protagonist then sees a Vision in a pas de trois. A woman soars over her two male partners. After a sharp solo and poses with her partners, she is again borne away. Another confident woman enters alone and is soon joined by a virile partner. Their pas de deux is framed by a corps de ballet. They all finally form a brief tableau and file out, the woman carried off by her man as the music diminishes in intensity. The Monologue of the Protagonist follows, a gliding yet weighted solo. To an introspective melody, she tests her sureness with balances, but often drops over sharply. Sadly, she goes to the floor, reaching and crying. This develops into extended and turning movements. As the music slackens, she glides away, reaching up and out. A birdlike allegro introduces two pairs for the Tetrad (or “Of the Same Feathers”) pas de quatre.In an adagio, they strike symmetrical and asymmetrical poses and sequences, sometimes expansive, sometimes contracted. They end quietly in a harmonious line, comforting one of the men. They go to separate places and bow, ready for the Epode (or “Jubilation”). This third movement starts with the two men’s vigorous variations, followed by the two women’s own sharp variations. Two other men and two other women join them to frame the Protagonist’s crossing the stage, and continue their own driven dancing together. The women are all borne up and out. A corps de ballet enters gradually for a pas de six. The marked music brings back the four men. The complete cast now frames in various formations the Protagonist with whom they alternate steps or statements. She leaps over the men, who bring her up and down. Everyone moves to the music’s increasing climaxes. All end around the Protagonist, who is hoisted by the men, even as she reaches out to the audience with her unappeased alienation and despair. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

article_title: The Dupe of Time / Icarus Eternally Damned
description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history
text:
1991. Moderndance in one act. Choreography, EnricoLabayen ; libretto, Enrico Labayen, based on a poem by AlfredA.Yuson; music, Shant Verdun; lighting design, KatschS.J.Catoy; set design, Santiago Bose. Dancers: ConradDy-Liacco (Icarus); Wendy Panganiban (female sun); Perry Sevidal and Tina Fargas (satellites). Premiered by the Lab Projekt on 11 Apr 1991 at the Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino, Cultural Center of the Philippines.

According to Labayen, this modern ballet in one scene depicts man’s yearning for limitlessness by portraying Icarus’ ambition and the threat to his daring. It was inspired by Yuson’s poem:

Hanging, Poised on poisoned sense, essences dripping on his head, centered. Were the dancer

To do a cartwheel His figure would show

In the revealed arc as the Hanged Man.

This man knows. He stays there.

He falls. And His Falling

He knows. He knows he is falling

He is falling. He has fallen

The story is deceptively simple. Icarus is ordained by two female satellite figures who come from suspended beams. This set of bamboo poles, strung horizontally together against a cyclorama of changing colors, dominates the whole ballet as an overhanging, swaying but predetermined sky. Even while on the ground, Icarus feels as if he is up in the clouds, riding a bicycle, and wearing a black helmet. The helmet is changed to a white one with a red crest. Icarus climbs despite the swaying of the bamboo and the risk of falling and kisses a female sun. He then rides a suspended bicycle, sculpts his moving body on the objective article, and climbs further up even above the sun. From there he falls. From rung to rung of bamboo beams, he seems to fall again and again, until he reaches the ground. As he falls, the bird sounds grow in intensity and end in silence.

Icarus is an expanded form of Labayen’s multigravitational art, which he does with ropes in Maya which is named after the Hindu measurer or law of polarity. Both ballets show and signify the risk of heights; the indeterminacy of movement while up above and the limitation of the same by the chosen setup; and the process from the mind, not simply from the senses. The dance plays with the idea of human ambition driven to doom. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

photos.photodesc: Edna Vida’s The Nutcracker, CCP, Manila, 1987 (Edna Vida Collection)

text:
1892. Ballet in two acts. Choreography, Lev Ivanov; libretto, Marius Petipa; music, Peter I. Tchaikovsky. Premiered on 18 Dec 1892 at Maryinsky Theater, St. Petersburg, Russia. First British production, Nicolas Sergeyev for the Sadler’s Wells Ballet; first American version, William Christensen for the San Francisco Ballet, 1944. A shorter version was done by the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo in New York, 1940.

In 1955, Alexandra Danilova and Michael Maule led a season of “Great Moments of Ballet” at the Far Eastern University on Oct 1-3 in Casse-Noisette with Filipino dancers organized by the AnitaM.Kane School of the Classic Dance and the Arts Council of the Philippines. From 1958 on, Kane herself produced the ballet in Manila. Among her Sugarplum Fairy dancers were FelicitasLayag-Radaic and GretaMonserrat. RemediosdeOteyza also presented the dances from Act 2. In 1962, FeSala-Villarica premiered for Cebu Ballet Center a version by Maria Nevelska, after Ivanov, in the Cebu Coliseum. Emma Sanchez was the Sugarplum Fairy and Mario Recto the Nutcracker Prince. Kane’s last Philippine production was in 1965 under the auspices of her school and the ManilaTheatreGuild, a shorter version as the evening also featured Charles Dickens’ A Christmas Carol which Kane directed. Ester Rimpos was the Sugarplum Fairy and John Ting the Nutcracker Prince. In 1984, VellaDamian choreographed a complete veision for DanceConcertCompany at Puerta Real, Intramuros, Manila, with YvonneCutaran as the Sugarplum Fairy and RicardoElla as the Prince.

At the Cultural Center of the Philippines, BalletPhilippines presented Act 2, “The Kingdom of the Sweets” in 1971, with choreographers Basilio, TonyFabella, and LuisLayag, and dancers EsterRimpos and EddieElejar; in 1973, with choreographers Eddie Elejar, TonyLlacer, CorazonGeneroso-Iñigo, Tony Fabella, GenerCaringal, and Norman Walker (Chinese Tea Dance: FranklinBobadilla), and dancers Linda Di Bona and Robert Brassel, or EffieNañas and TommySabarre; in 1975, with the same choreographers but without Walker (Caringal took over his number) and Llacer (Fabella replaced his number), and dancers Robin Haig and NonoyFroilan.

In 1976, Ballet Philippines presented a full version by Alfred Rodrigues, featuring lead dancers Effie Nañas or Ester Rimpos, and Nonoy Froilan. This was repeated in 1977 with additional choreography by Nañas and Caringal, with dancers Rimpos and ReyDizon, or Nañas and Froilan. In 1978, the same choreographic credits were shared, with Armin Wild, and the setting was Spanish Philippines, specifically, the house of apresidente del municipio(mayor).The “Snow Scene” was called “The Star Kingdom,” the dances in Act 2 had Hispanized titles, and Mother Ginger (TonyEspejo) was indigenized as Señora Bibingka. In 1980, Ballet Philippines presented Wild’s European version, with the “Waltz of the Flowers” turned into the “Waltz of the Seasons.” The Sugarplum Fairy was Gina Mariano or Emellie Rigonan, with Sofia Zobel as Clara.

In 1982, AliceReyes reset her version in the Philippines at the turn of the century. Through the character of Don Manolo (the Drosselmeyer role), she gave unity to the ballet and turned the flowers into Viennese dolls. Leading dancers were Leslie Brown and John Meehan, Maricar Drilon, and BrandoMiranda, or Nañas and Froilan. In 1987, EdnaVida made her own version, renamed Clara’s family, created a Don Alfonso Quintero (the Drosselmeyer), renamed the “Snow Scene” as “Kingdom of the Fireflies,” kept the dances in her Act III as doll dances, except for the “Waltz of the Bougainvillas.” The Sugarplum Fairy dancers were LisaMacuja, CecileSicangco, Gina Katigbak, Melissa Caachon or Ida Beltran, while the Nutcracker prince were Froilan, Miranda, ConradDy-Liacco or Jun Mabaquiao. Designers for sets and/or costumes of Ballet Philippines productions have been Johnny Manahan, Toto Sicangco, ArturoCruz, and SalvadorBernal.

All these versions stuck to the essential story of the girl Clara brought to the “Kingdom of the Sweets” (or of dolls) by either the Nutcracker transformed into a Prince or by her godfather (Drosselmeyer, Don Manolo, or Don Alfonso), or by both. The dream ends and Clara is brought back to real life and her family’s home. The grand pas de deux is usually danced in the surviving Lev Ivanov version. However, in 1969, a Soviet group called the Grand Yunost Cultural Troupe danced what was probably a Vainonen version. This version was danced by Lisa Macuja in the Vaganova Choreographic Institute production; in Manila, she performed her variation from this version. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Significant dance pieces in Philippine dance history
text:
1941. Folkloric ballet in five segments. Choreography, LeonorOrosa-Goquingco . Premiered in Feb 1941 at the MetropolitanTheater. Cast: Leonor Orosa-Goquingco, Conchita Luzurriaga, Hortensia Gustilo, Carlos Blanco, Ricardo Pastor, Albert Gaskell, JessAyco, NickAgudo, GildaCordero, Cecile Yulo.

The 40-minute folkloric ballet is one of three original ballets in Orosa-Goquingco’s two-hour Philippine Youth in Ballet. The other two were the classic-styled “Idylls” and the modern “Sports,” which featured a cheering squad, tennis, and basketball.

Trend runs through five segments: “Primitive,” the first theatrical rendering of Mountain Province styles, such as rituals to beg the gods for rain; “Vinta,” the first stylization of dance forms from the Philippine south, which previously premiered at the ManilaGrandOperaHouse in 1939, and also featured the first choreographed duel; the Spanish-influenced “La Festejada,” “American Jazz,” and “The New Native,” a prophecy and foretaste of return to Philippine styles, as Maria Clara returns to lead the search for a new, creative Philippine dance theater.

Over 100 dancers, including the choreographer—forming the cast in the “Jazz” and “New Native” sequences—performed in Trend,the first extended ballet of native theme to trace the history of Philippine dance styles. Written by Leonor Orosa-Goquingco

Tropical Tapestry, Dance Theater Philippines, Memorial Theater, Scotland,1975

(CCP Collection)

text:
1983. Ballet in three parts. Choreography, Basilio ; music, Ruben Federizon ( RitmosTabulare ), Joaquin Rodrigo ( Fantasia para un Gentil-hombre ),and Antonio Vivaldi ( Concerto in A minor for Piccolo,but played on a block-flute); lighting design, Raymond Salvacion; costumes, Raquel Rey (part 1) and Arturo Cruz (parts 2 and 3). The three sections representing Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao, were developed separately. “Mosque Baroque” was premiered by DanceTheaterPhilippines (DTP) in Webster Memorial Theater, Arbroath, Scotland, on 6 Aug 1975; “La Adoracion” and “Hidden Rites” (to Samuel Barber’s Adagio for Strings )by DTP and St. Theresa’s College School of Dance in Meralco Theater, Pasig, on 4 Mar 1978.“Hidden Rites” was replaced by “Paglalang” (Creation, to the Federizon score), premiered by DTP (with parts 2 and 3) on 9 Sep 1983 at the Cultural Center of the Philippines. Premiere cast of “Paglalang” had Regina Debuque and Jonathan Terry; “Adoracion” had Mary Anne Santamaria (La Dama), Joseph Rañola (El Hidalgo), AnnaVilladolid alternating with Lida Abad Santos (La Zagala), Victor Madrona and Benjie Lintag alternating with Jose Lirio (Los Zagales); “Mosque Baroque” had Irene Sabas (Sultana) and Mitto Castillo (Sultan).

“Paglalang” (Creation) is about the first man and woman, Malakas and Maganda (Strong and Beautiful), inpintado(body tattoo) costuming. They are first revealed behind branches which they hold; they dance a subtle flirtation in solos and duets and come to final union in an embrace.

“La Adoracion” (Adoration) is inspired by pandanggosailaw (pandanggo with light), but with only one lighted drinking glass in the hand or on the head for the women. It has accumulative movements in simple style, and features a pas de deux between La Dama and El Hidalgo amid lines of lights on the floor, a pas de trois among La Zagala and twozagales(young bachelors) that exploits lines and supple bends, and a lively jota for six women. As the ballet ends with everyone drifting away, it leaves the Hidalgo and the Dama with a single light on her head.

“Mosque Baroque” is a series of dances in three movements, set off by a grand vinta sail. It is echoed by the Sultana’s canopy of mat andmalong(tubular garment). In this series of dances with the Sultana and her female attendants, and the Sultan and his male attendants, a slightly flirtatious pas de deux ends with the couple under an upraised canopy; a finale elaborates movements with the women’s scarves. The ballet ends with everyone flailing their scarves or prancing about with ankle bells. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

photos.photodesc: Vinta, Philippine Ballet Theatre, CCP, Manila, 2016 (Erica Jacinto)

text:
(Sailboat). 1989. Modern ballet in two movements. Choreography, Gener Caringal ; music, Vangelis; set and costume design, Arturo Cruz; lighting design, Katsch S. J. Catoy. Premiered by Philippine Ballet Theatre on 22 Sep 1989 as part of Salute to Our Choreographers at the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, Cultural Center of the Philippines. Cast: Lisa Macuja and Manuel Molina III, with Maritoni Rufino, Liza dela Fuente, Joy Estiandan, Celeste Fuentes, Cathee Lee, Violeta Lising, Ma. Concepcion Regalado, Kenneth Santos, Jorge Laico, and Jake Paquing.

Vinta is inspired by the Tausug sailboat of the same name. It has no story, nor does it realistically represent Tausug culture; instead, it explores the many ways of using multicolored cloths with patterns associated with the Tausug sailboat. The ballet opens with a breathtaking scene that emulates a vinta sailing across the ocean. Two long cloths stretch across the stage like colorful vinta sails. The first cloth is held up by nine women in a V-formation, the second by three men behind them. The lead female and male, performed by Lisa Macuja and Manuel Molina III, are at the center of this boat representation. The two act as the masthead, while the ensemble unfold their legs into high side extensions ( developpe ala seconde ) that then circle forward ( grand rond de jambe en dedans ) to mimic the paddling of oars that steer the vinta over the water. The following ensemble section breaks into two trios with elaborate partnering. The two female leads are smoothly transported across the stage by the male dancers, before the two main dancers come together in a visual climax. The second section feels like a denouement, with all the flags and colors, and a recap of roles before everyone returns to the cloth-shaped vinta,as if sailing for home.

The cloths form part of the scenography and are worn by the dancers who manipulate them as choreographic exploration. Performed en pointe, the piece showcases an extensive ballet vocabulary that serves as a basis for experimentations with themalong, a tubular cloth that serves several purposes. An iconic pose from Vinta is of the corps de ballet wearing the malong around their bodies, stretched out in a tilted parallelogram as the dancers bend forward with their back leg raised high in the air ( pencheé en attitude ), and an arm each holding up a corner of the malong. The malong is also manipulated by sharply changing arm positions and swift turns, while the cloth is slung over on a shoulder. The balletic movements are “Asianized” by flexed hands and angular arms, shapes associated with dances from the Tausug, Maranao, and Maguindanao communities.

Vinta was regularly restaged in mixed bill productions. On tours, it offered an abstract visual showcase of Philippine culture. After Molina, Nicolas Pacaña, Osias Barroso Jr, Raoul Banzon, Quincy Jacinto, Ronilo Jaynario, Lucas Jacinto, and Marvin Ryan Arizo were cast as the male lead. After Macuja, Maritoni Rufino, Guada de Leon, Maricar Medina, Lea Baduria, Faye Abigail Tan, and Tara Ferrer performed the female lead. Written by Joelle Florence B. Jacinto

photos.photodesc: Vision of Fire, Ballet Philippines, CCP, Manila, 1982 (CCP Collection)

text:
1982. Moderndance in three sections. Choreography, EdnaVida ; music, Ruben Federizon; lighting design, KatschS.J.Catoy; costume design, SalvadorBernal. Premiered by BalletPhilippines on 1 Oct 1982 at the Main Theater, now the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, of the CulturalCenterofthePhilippines (CCP). Dancers: CecileSicangco, ToniLopezGonzalez, HazelSabas, Maricar Drilon, Mercedes Mañago, Tina Fargas, Perry Sevidal, Juliet Molina, Zaida Halili, BrandoMiranda, Jinn Ibarrola, Ramon Victoria, ConradDy-Liacco, NoordinJumalon, Ric Culalic, Jojo Lucila, Adam Sage.

This work was commissioned for the 1982 CCP Philippine Music Festival. The musical score of Federizon, a composer who has been inspired by indigenous music, is an ethno-jazz polyphony rich in texture, and an excellent match for the physical and immediate movements of the ballet.

Vision ofFire is a modern dance piece in three sections based on the story of Adam and Eve. It begins with man in his basic innocence. Then he is tormented by woman’s passion. The dance proceeds to dramatize their union in the primalstage, and the discovery of freedom, until passion locks them in a preordained destiny.

Vision ofFire has since undergone considerable revisions. The first section of the ballet has metamorphosed from grounded pagan movements into surreal flowing mannerisms inspired bytai-chi.The music has been edited and sections of the ballet shortened.

Vision ofFire was included in the company’s repertoire for the 50th American Dance Festival in Durham, North Carolina, in Jun 1984 as a personal choice of festival director Charles Reinchart. An American critic described the ballet as one in which “men and women whirl, reach and circle like flames in the cyclical pattern that builds in intensity, speed and complication … skirts catch color, dancers become half shadows of themselves, inhumanly beautiful.” The ballet has also been performed in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, China, Germany, France, Japan, a few Southeast Asian countries, as well as various cities and provinces in the Philippines. Written by Edna Vida

2006. Solo contemporary dance. Choreography and performance, Rhosam Prudenciado Jr ; music, Wade Robson and Matmos. Premiered at the Outlet Yard in Dec 2006.

Originally titled Possibility (Effects of Failure), the choreography started off as a short competition piece in Airdance Theater Inc.’s Airdance Idol 3, an informal competition meant to encourage members to create new works. This first version was awarded third place. Later, Prudenciado developed it as an entry to the WiFi Body Dance Festival’s New Choreographer’s Competition in Jul 2008.

Which Way? is a narration of a person’s struggles and choices—at a “crossroad,” as suggested by the constant repetition of that word in the music. The work starts with Prudenciado center stage, under a spotlight. He does a series of finger-pointing gestures as the thematic movement. The piece then narrates a dancer’s struggle for direction, ending with his inability to decide on the path he should take. Based on Prudenciado’s personal experiences, this piece also exemplifies his creative process, which requires multiple revisions. It has proved to be a constant crowd favourite for its organic and fluid movements.

As an eight-minute piece, Which Way? won second prize at the WiFi Body Festival. For the Yokohama Solo x Duo + competition of the Yokohama Dance Collection R in 2009, it was further expanded to 14 minutes, incorporating a video by Prudenciado and Crispin Urbanozo III, with lighting design by Sueyen Austero, and editing by Jordan Arabejo. It won for the choreographer the grand prize in Yokohoma and a six-month dance residency in France, where it was restaged for Theatre Darius Milhaud in 2009. Thereafter, it was restaged for festivals including mc2 (dance = musicconstructed2) in Manila in 2009; WiFi Body Dance Festival in 2009; and the 11th International Festival in Korea, also in 2009. Written by Chantal Primero

Moderndance in three acts.Choreography and libretto, AntonJuan; music, FranciscoF.Feliciano; lighting design, KatschS.J.Catoy; set and costume design, SalvadorBernal.Premiered by BalletPhilippines on 1 Oct 1982 at the Main Theater, now the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, of the Cultural Center of the Philippines. Dancers: EsterRimpos (Yerma), GenerCaringal (Juan), NonoyFroilan (Victor), Jojo Lucila (Devil Image).

This ballet in three short acts is based on Federico Garcia Lorca’s play, Yerma.It captures a surrealistic world, Yerma’s private world where she is dreaming as she embroiders. The prologue reveals Goyesca figures ofduende(dwarves) andencantada(enchantress), devout and devilish, some of them creatures with sagging bloody bosoms.

Act 1 shows Yerma and Juan yearning for an absent passion, for an unborn child. Victor comes to bid goodbye, his desire resisted because of society’spunto de honor(point of honor). Act 2 brings Yerma to the field of Granada where men and women give vent to their passion while old women pray. Yerma bitterly realizes the cause of her barrenness, then dances with a horned image of Victor. Act 3 brings Yerma to the mountains for a fertility rite. Shocking and entrancing; she lures Juan and awakens the sensual in him. But the possessed Yerma eventually strangles Juan, forever stifling her womb, but at the same time liberating herself forever. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

(Young Maidens of Manila). 1968. Modern ballet in one act. Choreography,JulieBorromeo ; composer, JulioNakpil; lighting design, Theatrical Services; costume design, Marcella Lopez. Premiered by DanceTheaterPhilippines (DTP) on 1 Oct 1968 at the Philamlife Auditorium. Dancers: TinaSantos, EddieElejar, FelicitasLayag-Radaic, June Dalit, Susan Vasquez, JulieBorromeo, Ely Rogado. A much revised version was rechoreographed by Borromeo in 1979 for DTP’s tour of England and Scotland in the course of the 11th International Festival of Youth Orchestras and Performing Arts. Dancers: Josette Salang, RicardoElla, Victor Madrona, Loy Molina, Sophia Radaic, EricV.Cruz, Irene Sabas, RupertAcuña.

A divertissement ballet in one act, it is conceptual in approach but recreates the Filipino lifestyle influenced by Spanish culture. This ballet presents the milieu of the social life during the era of Spanish colonization with male and female group dances and three featured pas de deux. Thezagalas(young maidens)wear stylized versions of national costumes.

The 1979 version retains the dances of the corps (entrada)and the respective dances for the male and female corps members, but these are now more elaborately patterned. In the same manner, the old pas de deuxes are changed: the first one becomes a pas de quatre with three zagalas and one zagala often lifted spectacularly; the second, to the melodious “RecuerdosdeCapiz” (Memories of Capiz), is disarmingly simple with its nostalgic gestures and alternating solos; the third pas de deux is brisk and virtuosic, leading to the company coda. To the original fans of the corps, there are added scarves that form interesting patterns. Its balletic style and native flavoring are evocative of the era’s dance styles including the polka, valse, and other Spanishdances that have become “Filipinized.”Some essential characteristics of Philippine dances are highly visible in the fusion of ballet steps with the sway and sweep of arms and the gestures culled from folkdances. The peculiar coyness of the Filipina female of that period shines through, as does the male’s gentle gallantry. Hands and arms are forever communicating as the male and female dancers seem to be playing ritualistic games of shy love. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz
